description: Kali Linux is an advanced, versatile penetration testing platform and has dozens and dozens of tools complied into it, making it a very powerful, yet highly customizable platform. These episodes will teach you how to install Kali Linux, and how to use Kali Linux to test the security of a network. You will learn how to effectively perform a penetration test using the various tools found in Kali Linux.
descriptionMD: Kali Linux is an advanced, versatile penetration testing platform and has dozens and dozens of tools complied into it, making it a very powerful, yet highly customizable platform. These episodes will teach you how to install Kali Linux, and how to use Kali Linux to test the security of a network. You will learn how to effectively perform a penetration test using the various tools found in Kali Linux.
name: Kali Linux (2017)
subtitle: Configuration of Kali Linux

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what Kali Linux is, a brief history of Kali Linux, how it is 'Debian' derived, best usues of Kali Linux, installation options, the requirements to run it, supported platforms, and features of Kali Linux.
episodes.title: History of Kali Linux
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:02.451
Welcome on ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.451 --> 00:00:06.546
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.546 --> 00:00:08.344
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.344 --> 00:00:12.340
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.340 --> 00:00:13.420
>> Hello again, thank you for

6
00:00:13.420 --> 00:00:17.475
joining us on ITProTV,
where we help you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:17.475 --> 00:00:22.563
I'm your host Zach Memos,
as we begin a new series, Kali Linux.

8
00:00:22.563 --> 00:00:25.434
And today, we're gonna learn a little
bit about the history of Kali Linux.

9
00:00:25.434 --> 00:00:29.223
And the person bringing us
that information is Kalima!

10
00:00:29.223 --> 00:00:31.052
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's Mike Roderick, right over here.

11
00:00:31.052 --> 00:00:32.568
>> Hey, Zack.

12
00:00:32.568 --> 00:00:33.810
>> Hey, Mike.

13
00:00:33.810 --> 00:00:38.642
>> Yeah, we're gonna be taking a look at
Kali Linux in this next several episodes,

14
00:00:38.642 --> 00:00:41.040
as we go through this series.

15
00:00:41.040 --> 00:00:44.148
And is all good things, we wanna start, we
need to know where we came from in order

16
00:00:44.148 --> 00:00:46.374
to really good idea of where
we're going and what can do.

17
00:00:46.374 --> 00:00:51.108
So I thought a little bit of history about
Kali Linux would maybe help us out here.

18
00:00:51.108 --> 00:00:52.361
Plus it's interesting,
it's fun stuff, right?

19
00:00:52.361 --> 00:00:53.340
>> It's very interesting, yes it is.

20
00:00:53.340 --> 00:00:54.600
>> It's good stuff, so.

21
00:00:54.600 --> 00:00:56.780
>> Especially the tassy with hearts.

22
00:00:56.780 --> 00:00:58.980
>> [LAUGH] And
we'll actually come back to that too.

23
00:00:58.980 --> 00:01:02.190
We will talk about Kali and
where that comes from as well.

24
00:01:02.190 --> 00:01:06.779
So we talk about Kali Linux,
obviously it's a Linux distribution, but

25
00:01:06.779 --> 00:01:09.199
it's a special Linux distribution.

26
00:01:09.199 --> 00:01:14.750
It's really designed to be
a penetration testing platform.

27
00:01:14.750 --> 00:01:18.340
And when we say it's designed to
be a penetration testing platform,

28
00:01:18.340 --> 00:01:19.900
what does that mean?

29
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:24.080
Really, it's all about the tools that
come pre-installed on this distribution.

30
00:01:24.080 --> 00:01:27.135
That's one of the big
drawing points to Kali Linux,

31
00:01:27.135 --> 00:01:30.050
is all these tools are available
that you can go and

32
00:01:30.050 --> 00:01:34.232
install on whatever distribution of
Linux that you wanna run, right?

33
00:01:34.232 --> 00:01:37.737
But I can go and out and
I can download an image of Kali Linux,

34
00:01:37.737 --> 00:01:42.455
and I can have most of the tools that
I need pre-installed, ready to go.

35
00:01:42.455 --> 00:01:45.345
>> Who would benefit from
having this installation?

36
00:01:45.345 --> 00:01:49.985
>> Anybody that does penetration
testing or any type of security work.

37
00:01:49.985 --> 00:01:52.714
There's several options as far
as running Kali Linux goes,

38
00:01:52.714 --> 00:01:54.648
we're gonna go through several of those.

39
00:01:54.648 --> 00:01:59.376
Like being able to run them off of a live,
we'll say CD or DVD, but that doesn't

40
00:01:59.376 --> 00:02:03.990
happen too much anymore, we'll say
USB drive is probably more likely.

41
00:02:03.990 --> 00:02:08.260
But being able to have my pen testing
platform with me all the time on a thumb

42
00:02:08.260 --> 00:02:13.210
drive that I can boot up at any time from
any machine is a fantastic capability.

43
00:02:14.370 --> 00:02:17.289
Also the fact, and like I said,
you can get these tools and

44
00:02:17.289 --> 00:02:19.564
install them in just
about any Linux distro.

45
00:02:19.564 --> 00:02:22.904
But the fact is that our pre-compiled,
it's there,

46
00:02:22.904 --> 00:02:27.734
they're very controlling about what is
allowed to go into the repositories.

47
00:02:27.734 --> 00:02:29.406
It all has to be signed,

48
00:02:29.406 --> 00:02:34.100
we wanna make sure that our platform
is stable and safe and secure.

49
00:02:34.100 --> 00:02:39.110
And that's one of the advantages that
we get of running this particular

50
00:02:39.110 --> 00:02:40.520
distribution of Linux.

51
00:02:40.520 --> 00:02:43.830
>> Now this sounds like Kali Linux is
very portable, and you mentioned USB,

52
00:02:43.830 --> 00:02:45.980
is that the only way you can transport it?

53
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:50.256
>> No, we'll show you several options
as far as running it from a USB.

54
00:02:50.256 --> 00:02:54.850
I'll show you how to make it from Windows,
from Linux, and we'll talk about Mac.

55
00:02:54.850 --> 00:02:58.560
I probably won't do it, but it's very
similar to doing it with Linux as well.

56
00:02:58.560 --> 00:03:03.060
But we could also run it in a VM, which
is another very common way to run Linux.

57
00:03:03.060 --> 00:03:05.120
Not quite as portable, right?

58
00:03:05.120 --> 00:03:07.770
But it's an easy way to
have an installation

59
00:03:07.770 --> 00:03:10.020
of Kali quickly available
when you need it.

60
00:03:10.020 --> 00:03:14.285
If you're primarily a Windows person for
your day-to-day job duties, but

61
00:03:14.285 --> 00:03:16.511
you need to pull up Kali once in a while.

62
00:03:16.511 --> 00:03:20.164
The VM, virtual machine,
might be the option you wanna go.

63
00:03:20.164 --> 00:03:21.600
Or dual boot, right,

64
00:03:21.600 --> 00:03:26.140
we can install it on side-by-side
with our Windows installation.

65
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:28.643
And I'll show you how to do that,
and that way you've got a permanent,

66
00:03:28.643 --> 00:03:31.304
you've just got reboot your system and
pick which one you wanna boot into.

67
00:03:31.304 --> 00:03:34.936
>> All right, we were talking about
dual boot on a becoming a Linux system

68
00:03:34.936 --> 00:03:37.620
administrator in another
episode with Don Pezet.

69
00:03:37.620 --> 00:03:40.240
So let's talk about
the history of Kali Linux.

70
00:03:40.240 --> 00:03:41.610
>> All right so-
>> Kalia, Kalima.

71
00:03:41.610 --> 00:03:45.890
>> Yeah, Kalima, it's Debian based now.

72
00:03:45.890 --> 00:03:50.551
It wasn't back in the day, but
we'll say one, as far as Kali itself,

73
00:03:50.551 --> 00:03:55.270
designed for digital forensics and
penetration testing.

74
00:03:55.270 --> 00:03:59.028
Maintained and funded by a group called
Offensive Security, most of you out there

75
00:03:59.028 --> 00:04:02.203
are probably familiar with them and
their wonderful site they have.

76
00:04:02.203 --> 00:04:06.100
And all the training that they provide and
a lot of great resources there.

77
00:04:06.100 --> 00:04:11.244
Core developers just to give everybody
credit, and I apologize if I mispronounce

78
00:04:11.244 --> 00:04:16.890
these names, Mati Aharoni,
Devon Kearns, and Raphael Hertzog.

79
00:04:16.890 --> 00:04:20.640
Those are the three core developers,
but obviously there's several people

80
00:04:20.640 --> 00:04:25.360
that help maintain Kali, but they list
those guys out as their core developers.

81
00:04:25.360 --> 00:04:28.940
And as I said, for installation options,
install it on a hard disk,

82
00:04:28.940 --> 00:04:33.480
boot it from a live CD,
USB, do a virtual machine.

83
00:04:33.480 --> 00:04:36.920
But for the history, we'll say that one,

84
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:40.790
Offensive Security puts this out,
it came out in 2013.

85
00:04:40.790 --> 00:04:45.690
It's Debian-based as of now, but as I
think Ryan put in our chat room there,

86
00:04:45.690 --> 00:04:50.060
he knows his history as well, he mentioned
one called WHAX, and even Whoppix,

87
00:04:50.060 --> 00:04:52.100
before that BackTrack.

88
00:04:52.100 --> 00:04:55.850
So if we wanna follow the timeline,

89
00:04:55.850 --> 00:05:00.679
a long time ago there was a couple
distributions called WHAX and

90
00:05:00.679 --> 00:05:05.450
Woppx, and another one called
Auditor Security Collection.

91
00:05:05.450 --> 00:05:10.746
And these were great Linux distributions,
WHAX was Slack-based, very minimalistic.

92
00:05:10.746 --> 00:05:15.403
Auditor Security Collection was
a live CD that was KOPPIX-based,

93
00:05:15.403 --> 00:05:21.950
had 300 tools pre-compiled in there, and
there was some overlap between those two.

94
00:05:21.950 --> 00:05:26.106
So what they did, that's really
where BackTracks got its inception,

95
00:05:26.106 --> 00:05:29.292
was from combining or
kind of taking the best of WHAX and

96
00:05:29.292 --> 00:05:32.907
Auditor Security Collection,
and putting those together.

97
00:05:32.907 --> 00:05:38.223
And so BackTracks, for a long time was
one of the security distros to get.

98
00:05:38.223 --> 00:05:41.965
I remember playing with that and
using it, wow,

99
00:05:41.965 --> 00:05:47.830
this comes with all these tools already
built in here, it was fantastic.

100
00:05:47.830 --> 00:05:52.210
Well, back in 2012 the developers at
Offensive Security, and the developers

101
00:05:52.210 --> 00:05:56.640
that were working on BackTracks really
decided they wanted to kinda redo things.

102
00:05:56.640 --> 00:06:01.270
They wanted to add a bunch of new
features and capabilities, but

103
00:06:01.270 --> 00:06:05.130
realized that it was gonna require
a lot of re-work under the hood.

104
00:06:05.130 --> 00:06:09.630
And they decided that this would be just
a good time to kinda start over, and

105
00:06:09.630 --> 00:06:10.850
they switched over to Debian.

106
00:06:10.850 --> 00:06:14.055
In fact I want to say the last guy
they brought in, Raphael Hertzog,

107
00:06:14.055 --> 00:06:16.934
I wanna say he was their Debian
guru guy that they brought in.

108
00:06:16.934 --> 00:06:22.590
But that what's happened there,
is they switched over to Debian.

109
00:06:22.590 --> 00:06:28.850
The first official release of Kali was
in 2013, is when we had our first one.

110
00:06:28.850 --> 00:06:32.480
So BackTracks evolved into Kali Linux.

111
00:06:33.480 --> 00:06:38.510
So that's a little bit about the history,
and then as we've been alluding to

112
00:06:38.510 --> 00:06:42.132
a few times, and Zack has talked about the
name, it's always something that comes up.

113
00:06:42.132 --> 00:06:43.834
>> [LAUGH]
>> It probably doesn't have a lot to

114
00:06:43.834 --> 00:06:47.245
functionality-wise but hey, you know you
want to be able to talk intelligently.

115
00:06:47.245 --> 00:06:51.060
And you get out there, and
people are like Kali, Kalima, right?

116
00:06:51.060 --> 00:06:54.750
Think of Indiana Jones and
things like that.

117
00:06:54.750 --> 00:06:56.930
But if we take a look,
in fact let's go out and

118
00:06:56.930 --> 00:07:01.440
look at Kali's website here,
this is Kali.org.

119
00:07:01.440 --> 00:07:03.585
This is where we're gonna
be able to get the ISOs or

120
00:07:03.585 --> 00:07:05.180
whatever else we need to install it.

121
00:07:05.180 --> 00:07:09.670
You get a lot of information here,
they've got their official documentation.

122
00:07:09.670 --> 00:07:14.940
They've got a great community
that you can be a part of.

123
00:07:14.940 --> 00:07:19.195
Offensive Security, again, was the ones
that helped maintain and fund all of this.

124
00:07:19.195 --> 00:07:25.900
And then as far as, I went back and
found one of their pages in their history.

125
00:07:25.900 --> 00:07:29.449
This is an old page, this is from 2012,
back when Kali was released,

126
00:07:29.449 --> 00:07:31.754
it actually came official I think in 2013.

127
00:07:31.754 --> 00:07:34.997
But it talks about what I
was just talking about,

128
00:07:34.997 --> 00:07:39.900
how they scrapped it all and
started fresh, Ubuntu versus Debian.

129
00:07:39.900 --> 00:07:41.660
But down here,
I thought I'd point this out,

130
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:44.800
since we love to talk about this,
what's in a name?

131
00:07:44.800 --> 00:07:46.040
Hindu goddess of time and

132
00:07:46.040 --> 00:07:49.305
change, Philippine martial art,
cool word in Swahili.

133
00:07:49.305 --> 00:07:51.105
>> [LAUGH]
>> None of the above,

134
00:07:51.105 --> 00:07:54.561
Kali is simply a name we came up with for
our new distribution.

135
00:07:54.561 --> 00:07:57.702
So there you go,
straight from the horses mouth.

136
00:07:57.702 --> 00:08:01.413
It really doesn't mean anything,
it's just a word that they [CROSSTALK].

137
00:08:01.413 --> 00:08:06.370
>> But I intend to think they so
that movie within [INAUDIBLE].

138
00:08:06.370 --> 00:08:10.692
>> [CROSSTALK] I mean maybe that works out
good for us because now I can, in my mind,

139
00:08:10.692 --> 00:08:12.722
I can think of it as coming from that,

140
00:08:12.722 --> 00:08:16.143
they can do goddess
>> Somebody else might have a different

141
00:08:16.143 --> 00:08:16.830
opinion.

142
00:08:16.830 --> 00:08:18.650
And hey, they don't disagree with us, so

143
00:08:18.650 --> 00:08:22.905
hey, we can kind of have our own
truth maybe there if that works.

144
00:08:22.905 --> 00:08:29.280
[LAUGH] All right, so a little bit about
the history of Kali, where it came from.

145
00:08:29.280 --> 00:08:31.610
Again, it's one of
the popular distributions,

146
00:08:31.610 --> 00:08:33.480
if you are going to be doing pen testing.

147
00:08:33.480 --> 00:08:35.890
Any type of security
work because of the fact,

148
00:08:35.890 --> 00:08:39.230
that it is, its got all of the tools,
free compiler that is installed in there,

149
00:08:39.230 --> 00:08:42.680
the repositories are available
with with additional tools.

150
00:08:42.680 --> 00:08:46.880
They keep tight control over what is
getting added to their repositories,

151
00:08:46.880 --> 00:08:50.330
in fact they will tell you if you
go to their documentation in here

152
00:08:50.330 --> 00:08:53.480
one of the things that people are tempted
to do is add additional repositories so

153
00:08:53.480 --> 00:08:55.240
they can go get these other tools.

154
00:08:55.240 --> 00:08:58.330
And there's nothing wrong with that, but
just understand that you are reducing

155
00:08:58.330 --> 00:09:01.340
the security that's built
in to Kali by doing that.

156
00:09:01.340 --> 00:09:02.130
>> You open the door.

157
00:09:02.130 --> 00:09:04.860
>> Yes, they keep a tight
control over their repository.

158
00:09:04.860 --> 00:09:08.170
As you start adding other repositories,
now it's beyond their control and

159
00:09:08.170 --> 00:09:11.080
you can introduce things and
introduce instability or

160
00:09:11.080 --> 00:09:14.800
insecurity, which maybe is what you
want and you're okay with that.

161
00:09:14.800 --> 00:09:18.060
Or if you're trying to
keep it buttoned down and

162
00:09:18.060 --> 00:09:21.060
secure, stick with your
official repositories for Kali.

163
00:09:21.060 --> 00:09:23.430
>> And the cost for it is zero?

164
00:09:23.430 --> 00:09:24.210
>> It is zero.

165
00:09:24.210 --> 00:09:27.830
It is one of our favorite
price points here at IRProTV.

166
00:09:27.830 --> 00:09:28.950
The cost is free and

167
00:09:28.950 --> 00:09:32.500
you read on their website that you
will never have to pay for Kali Linux.

168
00:09:32.500 --> 00:09:38.220
Their intention is to keep it free
forever, which is a good thing.

169
00:09:38.220 --> 00:09:40.060
We like free around here.

170
00:09:40.060 --> 00:09:41.570
All right, now requirement-wise.

171
00:09:41.570 --> 00:09:43.010
And you can kill the screen feed here.

172
00:09:43.010 --> 00:09:44.350
Well, actually, you know what?

173
00:09:44.350 --> 00:09:46.570
I can go over and well,
I'll show you this.

174
00:09:46.570 --> 00:09:48.100
Let's go over to the Kali documentation.

175
00:09:48.100 --> 00:09:49.090
Sorry, Megan.

176
00:09:49.090 --> 00:09:50.050
Goof on you up there.

177
00:09:51.070 --> 00:09:55.100
Let's take a look at some of
the installation requirements.

178
00:09:55.100 --> 00:09:56.840
So I know it's a little bit small.

179
00:09:56.840 --> 00:09:57.820
I can zoom in for you.

180
00:09:57.820 --> 00:10:02.560
Minimum of 20 gigs hard space,
disk space for the Kali Linux install.

181
00:10:02.560 --> 00:10:04.920
If you're gonna be installing it,
on a hard drive right.

182
00:10:04.920 --> 00:10:07.580
If you're running it from a thumb drive or
something like that.

183
00:10:07.580 --> 00:10:10.400
Obviously this requirement
doesn't apply to you.

184
00:10:10.400 --> 00:10:13.660
RAM for I3 to 6 and 64-bit architecture,

185
00:10:13.660 --> 00:10:17.480
minimum one gigabyte,
recommended 2 gigabytes or more.

186
00:10:17.480 --> 00:10:21.720
And just like any operating system they
will tell I can run with 1 gigabyte and

187
00:10:21.720 --> 00:10:27.290
that's all you got we'll make it work,
but it's not gonna be painless.

188
00:10:27.290 --> 00:10:29.420
It gonna have to be a little slow
especially depending on what

189
00:10:29.420 --> 00:10:32.540
you are running, so
as the application once you get booted up.

190
00:10:32.540 --> 00:10:37.080
2 gigs recommended but just like
any other OS the more we through at

191
00:10:37.080 --> 00:10:40.310
it up to a certain point anyway that
you get the diminishing returns but

192
00:10:40.310 --> 00:10:42.290
up to a certain point we wanna
input more memory in there.

193
00:10:42.290 --> 00:10:45.170
Cuz when we are loading things
like password crackers or

194
00:10:45.170 --> 00:10:48.790
other things that might be CPU intensive
that need to store a lot of info in RAM

195
00:10:50.200 --> 00:10:51.710
better have in more memory.

196
00:10:51.710 --> 00:10:52.770
So the more you can do it the better.

197
00:10:54.790 --> 00:11:01.290
Or CD drive, DVD drive, or USB boot
support to get it installed, all right.

198
00:11:01.290 --> 00:11:06.220
Other than that, pretty slight
really when it comes to language.

199
00:11:06.220 --> 00:11:07.650
It's like most Linux distros,

200
00:11:07.650 --> 00:11:10.940
I mean they're pretty light
on their system requirements.

201
00:11:10.940 --> 00:11:14.970
Just keep in mind, different tools that
you run also have requirements and

202
00:11:14.970 --> 00:11:16.380
you're gonna have to add those up, so

203
00:11:16.380 --> 00:11:19.820
if you're planning on doing a lot of
multitasking or running any of those

204
00:11:19.820 --> 00:11:24.290
disks or memory-intensive applications or
anything like that, you'll have to

205
00:11:24.290 --> 00:11:27.480
think about that when you're specing out
your system that you wanna run this on.

206
00:11:27.480 --> 00:11:30.600
>> Now are you gonna have to download
additional software to manage

207
00:11:30.600 --> 00:11:33.230
the Kali Linux or is it all unto itself?

208
00:11:33.230 --> 00:11:34.310
>> No, it's all unto itself.

209
00:11:34.310 --> 00:11:36.700
So let's take a look at
their download page.

210
00:11:36.700 --> 00:11:38.790
In fact, let me jump back here.

211
00:11:38.790 --> 00:11:40.480
And downloading Kali Linux.

212
00:11:40.480 --> 00:11:45.040
So, when you go out there and
you decide that you wanna run Kali,

213
00:11:45.040 --> 00:11:48.920
you've got your choices of how you're
gonna go about running it, and

214
00:11:48.920 --> 00:11:53.570
then that will determine really what it
is that you're going to be downloading.

When you went to boot Back Tracks

00:19:06.850 --> 00:19:09.960

00:19:09.960 --> 00:19:16.580

00:19:16.580 --> 00:19:18.730

00:19:18.730 --> 00:19:21.950

00:19:26.960 --> 00:19:31.590

00:19:46.735 --> 00:19:49.695

00:19:49.695 --> 00:19:53.955

00:19:53.955 --> 00:19:55.378

00:19:57.395 --> 00:20:01.120

I say Kali a live mode.

00:01:11.210 --> 00:01:16.690

00:01:29.390 --> 00:01:32.040

00:01:32.040 --> 00:01:33.020

00:01:33.020 --> 00:01:35.790
>> Yeah, the ability really to
save something, make it permanent.

37
00:01:35.790 --> 00:01:39.807
Because it's a live distro running off
that thumb drive, it's just like running

38
00:01:39.807 --> 00:01:42.785

00:01:42.785 --> 00:01:44.930
There's no write capabilities.

40
00:01:44.930 --> 00:01:49.020
So any of your configuration changes
would just be lost next time you boot.

41
00:01:49.020 --> 00:01:51.590
It's booting right back
to that read-only media.

42
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:53.050
And that was an issue.

00:01:53.050 --> 00:01:57.850
There were ways we'd go around,

00:02:02.320 --> 00:02:04.803

00:02:04.803 --> 00:02:06.420

again the next time.

47
00:02:06.420 --> 00:02:10.060
So there were ways to save information,
but it was a real pain.

00:02:10.060 --> 00:02:14.710

00:02:14.710 --> 00:02:17.730

00:02:17.730 --> 00:02:22.600

00:02:22.600 --> 00:02:23.850

00:02:23.850 --> 00:02:28.820
So when we boot that Kali Live back up,

53
00:02:28.820 --> 00:02:33.660

00:02:33.660 --> 00:02:35.800

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what 'Encryption' is, how to add Encryption to a Kali Linux Thumb Drive application with 'Persistence', how to modify our applications, and adding a 'Nuke' key for added security.

00:27:52.690 --> 00:27:55.840

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what a Kali Linux VM is, where & how to obtain a Kali VM, using 'Offensive Security,' other virtualization platforms, variations of the Kali VM, installation of Kali VM, discussion of built in persistence in the Kali VM, and launching & using the Kali VM.

403
00:20:26.935 --> 00:20:29.521
But it's easy enough to
just update it from here,

404
00:20:29.521 --> 00:20:32.060
which I'll show you in
a future episode as well.

405
00:20:32.060 --> 00:20:37.210
So hopefully that gives you an idea
of really how easy it is to

406
00:20:37.210 --> 00:20:42.110
get an instance of Kali Linux up and
running on your system.

407
00:20:42.110 --> 00:20:47.013
Pick your virtualization platform, go
with something free, go out to kali.org,

408
00:20:47.013 --> 00:20:52.780
download a pre-built virtual machine
from Offensive Security, fire it up.

409
00:20:52.780 --> 00:20:53.840
And you're good to go.

410
00:20:53.840 --> 00:20:55.180
>> Fantastic, great job, Mike.

411
00:20:55.180 --> 00:20:56.150
Thank you so very much.

412
00:20:56.150 --> 00:20:59.810
Kali virtual machine images,
as we continue on with Kali Linux and

413
00:20:59.810 --> 00:21:03.280
don't forget, there's a lot of
video content in this series.

414
00:21:03.280 --> 00:21:05.840
Check out all the videos,
you're gonna be very glad that you did.

415
00:21:06.920 --> 00:21:09.036
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

416
00:21:09.036 --> 00:21:12.340
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

417
00:21:12.340 --> 00:21:13.210
I'm Zach Memos.

418
00:21:13.210 --> 00:21:13.970
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

419
00:21:13.970 --> 00:21:16.500
>> And we will see you very soon.

420
00:21:16.500 --> 00:21:22.603
[MUSIC]

421
00:21:22.603 --> 00:21:29.729
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: Mike and Zach cover the use of Kali Linux now that install has been completed, virtual guest tools, how to update Kali, using 'Apt-Get' update, downloading newer versions of Kali, upgrading Kali, changing passwords, adding non-root users, sidebar options, and lock screen.
episodes.title: Post Installation Configuration

episodes.description: Mike and Zach cover the use of Kali Linux now that install has been completed, virtual guest tools, how to update Kali, using 'Apt-Get' update, downloading newer versions of Kali, upgrading Kali, changing passwords, adding non-root users, sidebar options, and lock screen.
episodes.title: Post Installation Configuration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.034 --> 00:00:06.737
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:06.737 --> 00:00:08.341
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.341 --> 00:00:11.961
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.961 --> 00:00:14.068
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.068 --> 00:00:15.963
where we help you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.963 --> 00:00:19.290
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with Kali Linux.

7
00:00:20.310 --> 00:00:25.990
In this episode we are going to be looking
at post installation configurations.

8
00:00:25.990 --> 00:00:27.640
Who's bringing us
the information that we need?

9
00:00:27.640 --> 00:00:29.419
Not me, no.

10
00:00:29.419 --> 00:00:31.918
Mike Rodrick, right over here,
he's got the answers.

11
00:00:31.918 --> 00:00:35.620
>> Don't let him fool you, he knows all
of this stuff too, he's just teasing.

12
00:00:35.620 --> 00:00:37.210
But yes, thanks Zach for having me here.

13
00:00:37.210 --> 00:00:38.709
Thanks for you guys being here.

14
00:00:40.400 --> 00:00:43.560
In our previous episode we looked
at different ways we could

15
00:00:44.670 --> 00:00:47.740
obtain Kali Linux and
install and run Kali Linux.

16
00:00:47.740 --> 00:00:51.279
Whether we're running it live off of
a thumb drive or with persistence,

17
00:00:51.279 --> 00:00:52.794
with encrypted persistence.

18
00:00:52.794 --> 00:00:54.013
And my favorite one,

19
00:00:54.013 --> 00:00:58.280
the virtual image, that we can
download from Offensive Security.

20
00:00:58.280 --> 00:01:01.283
So now that we've got Kali running and
we're gonna assume that,

21
00:01:01.283 --> 00:01:04.993
if you're running it off of a thumb drive,
well you're not gonna be doing a lot of

22
00:01:04.993 --> 00:01:07.356
configuration because
there's no persistence.

23
00:01:07.356 --> 00:01:10.417
You put it in, you boot up to it,
you use your tools and

24
00:01:10.417 --> 00:01:15.270
then you lose everything as soon as you
unplug your thumb drive or shut it down.

25
00:01:15.270 --> 00:01:17.615
We added some persistence
on that one episode,

26
00:01:17.615 --> 00:01:22.660
which now I could make some configuration
changes and they would be persistent.

27
00:01:22.660 --> 00:01:23.830
So that would be nice.

28
00:01:23.830 --> 00:01:26.180
And in that case,
these are some things you want to do.

29
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:30.620
But especially if you've installed it
locally, either as your daily drive or

30
00:01:30.620 --> 00:01:35.110
as a dual boot, or like me, if you're
running it in a virtual image with your

31
00:01:35.110 --> 00:01:38.300
virtualization software, then there are
some things that you're gonna wanna do.

32
00:01:38.300 --> 00:01:40.480
You want to make some
configuration changes, one,

33
00:01:40.480 --> 00:01:43.400
to help secure it, we gotta keep it up
to date, and make it usable and fun and

34
00:01:43.400 --> 00:01:47.080
make it something that
we enjoy using everyday.

35
00:01:47.080 --> 00:01:49.750
All right, so
that's what we're going to do.

36
00:01:49.750 --> 00:01:53.650
In the end of the previous episode,
if you're watching them in order,

37
00:01:53.650 --> 00:01:59.100
we had downloaded a virtual
image from Offensive Security.

38
00:01:59.100 --> 00:02:03.190
And we are running that now currently, so
I'm gonna just flip over to my screen and

39
00:02:03.190 --> 00:02:07.700
I'll show you what we typically
do to a system like this.

40
00:02:07.700 --> 00:02:10.240
So here it is, fresh install.

41
00:02:10.240 --> 00:02:14.960
I am going to log in with
that default password toor,

42
00:02:14.960 --> 00:02:18.333
T-O-O-R, and we're good to go.

43
00:02:18.333 --> 00:02:20.700
All right,
there's my beautiful desktop, again,

44
00:02:20.700 --> 00:02:23.790
love the virtual images that makes this so
much easier.

45
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:26.560
Now one of the first things
you'll really wanna do is

46
00:02:26.560 --> 00:02:29.410
depending on your virtualization
software that you're using,

47
00:02:29.410 --> 00:02:34.120
is install your virtualization tools,
in most cases.

48
00:02:34.120 --> 00:02:38.510
Like if you've installed this from
the disk, let's say you downloaded an ISO,

49
00:02:38.510 --> 00:02:42.840
build a blank virtual machine, and
installed Kali Linux from that ISO.

50
00:02:43.880 --> 00:02:47.360
Then you're gonna wanna to install
what's called your virtualization tools.

51
00:02:47.360 --> 00:02:51.682
These are tools that you're
virtualization platform uses to allow you

52
00:02:51.682 --> 00:02:54.140
to interact with that virtual machine.

53
00:02:54.140 --> 00:02:55.027
Yes, Mike?

54
00:02:55.027 --> 00:02:58.266
>> Well just real quick,
when you've done that download,

55
00:02:58.266 --> 00:03:01.848
does it not come with tools like
pre-installed, a few right.

56
00:03:01.848 --> 00:03:02.921
>> Some, yes.

57
00:03:02.921 --> 00:03:05.029
And let's make sure we understand
what we're talking about here.

58
00:03:05.029 --> 00:03:10.680
Now I'm not talking about tools like Nmap
or Metasploit, or anything like that.

59
00:03:10.680 --> 00:03:15.140
Those tools yes, are all in there, but
what you use to interact with that virtual

60
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:19.870
machine, those you'll have to add if
you're installing it from the ISO.

61
00:03:19.870 --> 00:03:24.085
Because the ISO is planning on you
installing it on actual hardware or

62
00:03:24.085 --> 00:03:28.590
in a virtual machine and then, again,
you install your Hyper-V tools,

63
00:03:28.590 --> 00:03:33.041
you install your VMware tools,
you install your VirtualBox add-ons.

64
00:03:33.041 --> 00:03:37.073
And what that allows it to do is to take
your mouse input and take your keyboard

65
00:03:37.073 --> 00:03:41.660
input away from your physical machine and
direct it into the virtual machine.

66
00:03:41.660 --> 00:03:45.640
And there's other things that these
tools will allow you to do as well like,

67
00:03:45.640 --> 00:03:47.150
share folders.

68
00:03:47.150 --> 00:03:50.807
I love being able to go to my
physical machine download things,

69
00:03:50.807 --> 00:03:53.504
scan them with my AV,
do whatever I need to do.

70
00:03:53.504 --> 00:03:56.918
And then put them in a location,
go to my virtual machine and

71
00:03:56.918 --> 00:04:01.358
I can access that location on my Windows
hard drive and copy those files over or

72
00:04:01.358 --> 00:04:03.590
whatever it is that I'm doing.

73
00:04:03.590 --> 00:04:06.949
So the ability to do that kind of thing
is a lot of times dependant on the tools.

74
00:04:06.949 --> 00:04:11.657
Now, that being said, when you
download the actual virtual image like

75
00:04:11.657 --> 00:04:14.561
I've done here, we don't have to do that,

76
00:04:14.561 --> 00:04:18.110
because Offensive Security
took care of that for us.

77
00:04:18.110 --> 00:04:23.430
They've actually got a custom set of
virtualization tools built into the image.

78
00:04:24.830 --> 00:04:28.940
That's why they have different ones,
format for one, but also for these tools.

79
00:04:28.940 --> 00:04:32.350
When you download
the VMWare virtual machine,

80
00:04:32.350 --> 00:04:34.650
it's got the VMWare tools in there.

81
00:04:34.650 --> 00:04:37.870
When you download the one for
VirtualBox, they've already added their

82
00:04:37.870 --> 00:04:41.156
own custom VirtualBox add-ins to allow
you to interact to that machine.

83
00:04:41.156 --> 00:04:44.470
So another advantage of downloading their
image is the fact that you don't have to

84
00:04:44.470 --> 00:04:45.439
do any of that, right?

85
00:04:45.439 --> 00:04:45.987
It's all there.

86
00:04:45.987 --> 00:04:50.748
In fact, if you try, it'll usually tell
you when you go to VM workstation, for

87
00:04:50.748 --> 00:04:54.516
example, if I go in and
try to install the normal VM workstation

88
00:04:54.516 --> 00:04:57.784
virtualization tools,
it's gonna tell me hey look,

89
00:04:57.784 --> 00:05:03.150
there's already some open source custom
virtualization tools installed there.

90
00:05:03.150 --> 00:05:04.262
Are you sure you wanna replace them?

91
00:05:04.262 --> 00:05:08.334
Usually you're better off going with those
tools that were prepared by the company

92
00:05:08.334 --> 00:05:09.799
that made the virtual image.

93
00:05:09.799 --> 00:05:10.627
>> Bingo!

94
00:05:10.627 --> 00:05:12.810
>> In that case,
I don't bother switching them out.

95
00:05:12.810 --> 00:05:14.170
But if I had installed this from an ISO,

96
00:05:14.170 --> 00:05:16.750
that would definitely be one of
the first things I would do.

97
00:05:18.780 --> 00:05:21.120
Cuz if you don't,
things that'll happen is,

98
00:05:21.120 --> 00:05:23.930
you click on the desktop
of your virtual machine.

99
00:05:23.930 --> 00:05:25.790
And now your mouse is captured, and

100
00:05:25.790 --> 00:05:27.610
you can't move it outside
your virtual machine.

101
00:05:27.610 --> 00:05:29.960
So if you wanted to go back
down to your Windows menu or

102
00:05:29.960 --> 00:05:33.770
to another virtual machine, you have
to do a keyboard combination to release

103
00:05:33.770 --> 00:05:38.100
the mouse from the virtual machine and
give it back to the physical machine.

104
00:05:38.100 --> 00:05:39.300
That's a pain in the butt.

105
00:05:39.300 --> 00:05:40.737
>> And
it sounds like the great title of a movie.

106
00:05:40.737 --> 00:05:41.800
Release the Mouse, I like it.

107
00:05:41.800 --> 00:05:46.470
>> [LAUGH] So with these tools, you don't
have to do any of that and so it's great.

108
00:05:46.470 --> 00:05:50.050
So anyway,
my point of this long ramble was,

109
00:05:50.050 --> 00:05:53.058
depending on how you install it that might
be one of the first things you do is,

110
00:05:53.058 --> 00:05:58.210
add those add-ins to make it easier just
to work with the virtual machine itself.

111
00:05:58.210 --> 00:05:59.670
It my case, they're already there.

112
00:05:59.670 --> 00:06:02.370
I will show you,
if we take a look at my screen here.

113
00:06:02.370 --> 00:06:07.021
If this was not a pre-built and
I had installed Kali from an ISO,

114
00:06:07.021 --> 00:06:11.241
the next thing I'd do is go up
to in VM Workstation anyway,

115
00:06:11.241 --> 00:06:16.100
you go up to your menu, and
you would choose install VMware tools.

116
00:06:16.100 --> 00:06:20.475
And that would add those tools specific to
this particular virtualization platform.

117
00:06:20.475 --> 00:06:23.510
Hyper-V is gonna be a little bit different
from how you install their add-ons,

118
00:06:23.510 --> 00:06:25.470
Virtual Box, a little bit different, but

119
00:06:25.470 --> 00:06:29.130
the same general concept, find it in
your menu and install those tools.

120
00:06:29.130 --> 00:06:30.880
Notice mine says update.

121
00:06:30.880 --> 00:06:34.125
It actually sees that my virtual
machine already has tools,

122
00:06:34.125 --> 00:06:35.850
thanks to Offensive Security.

123
00:06:35.850 --> 00:06:38.473
And it gives me the option to update,
but again if I go through

124
00:06:38.473 --> 00:06:41.612
the process it'll just tell me, hey,
you really don't wanna do this,

125
00:06:41.612 --> 00:06:43.941
you should stick with the ones
that they put in there.

126
00:06:43.941 --> 00:06:48.135
So I'm not gonna do that in this show
because, again, I don't have to.

127
00:06:48.135 --> 00:06:50.361
Now let's zoom back out
if I can see [CROSSTALK].

128
00:06:50.361 --> 00:06:51.276
>> [LAUGH] If it ain't broke don't fix it.

129
00:06:51.276 --> 00:06:53.720
>> That's right.

130
00:06:53.720 --> 00:06:55.720
So next thing we would do then,

131
00:06:55.720 --> 00:07:00.980
just like any other operating system that
you install, you want to get it updated.

132
00:07:00.980 --> 00:07:03.120
When was that image created?

133
00:07:03.120 --> 00:07:06.220
A week ago, a month ago, six months ago.

134
00:07:06.220 --> 00:07:07.750
There's been updates since then.

135
00:07:07.750 --> 00:07:09.750
Critical updates, security updates.

136
00:07:09.750 --> 00:07:12.411
Updates to programs and
packages that I need to get.

137
00:07:12.411 --> 00:07:18.310
And that's always going to be one of the
first things you do is get your updates.

138
00:07:18.310 --> 00:07:21.213
So in our Linux box here,
again, Kali comes,

139
00:07:21.213 --> 00:07:26.201
Offensive Security's got preconfigured
to reach out to their repositories,

140
00:07:26.201 --> 00:07:30.010
with their signed packages,
and I don't ever change that.

141
00:07:30.010 --> 00:07:33.910
You can, you can add additional
repositories and download and

142
00:07:33.910 --> 00:07:36.690
install programs that
they weren't planning or

143
00:07:36.690 --> 00:07:40.210
that you wanna add that aren't
part of this normal distribution.

144
00:07:40.210 --> 00:07:44.318
But they'll tell you that you can end up
reducing the security of your machine by

145
00:07:44.318 --> 00:07:45.003
doing that.

146
00:07:45.003 --> 00:07:48.577
That's your call, if you feel that
there is a program out there that

147
00:07:48.577 --> 00:07:52.153
is absolutely necessary that you
want to get and it's not available

148
00:07:52.153 --> 00:07:55.555
through the normal repositories for
Kali by all means add that.

149
00:07:55.555 --> 00:07:59.623
But we're gonna stick with what
offensive security recommends and

150
00:07:59.623 --> 00:08:03.772
that is just to Use their repositories
that are already configured.

151
00:08:03.772 --> 00:08:09.481
So, the command then, let me bump up
that command prompt a wee bit and

152
00:08:09.481 --> 00:08:11.530
see what we can do here.

153
00:08:11.530 --> 00:08:13.960
So, I'm gonna try to maximize.

154
00:08:13.960 --> 00:08:16.260
Let me see if I can get this guy
to stretch out, there it goes.

155
00:08:17.600 --> 00:08:20.210
Again, great thing about their image.

156
00:08:20.210 --> 00:08:22.130
All my video drivers, all of that.

157
00:08:22.130 --> 00:08:23.240
Normally this wouldn't stretch.

158
00:08:23.240 --> 00:08:27.360
If I had just installed it from the ISO,
I'd get the four by three and

159
00:08:27.360 --> 00:08:30.100
I'd have to go install drivers for
videos and things like that, so.

160
00:08:30.100 --> 00:08:32.350
>> Does Zoomid work on this?

161
00:08:32.350 --> 00:08:34.750
>> It does not.
Zoomid is a Windows thing, so.

162
00:08:34.750 --> 00:08:36.150
>> Right, right.
>> There are ways around that.

163
00:08:36.150 --> 00:08:40.020
There is a Zoom Accessibility
option in Linux,

164
00:08:40.020 --> 00:08:42.410
it wreaks havoc with my tools, though.

165
00:08:42.410 --> 00:08:45.950
As soon as I turn on the zoom feature, I
can't release the mouse automatically, and

166
00:08:45.950 --> 00:08:49.625
I start having to do that keyboard
shortcut again, which I absolutely hate.

167
00:08:49.625 --> 00:08:52.850
[LAUGH] But I will zoom in
when necessary if I need to.

168
00:08:52.850 --> 00:08:57.073
All right, so to do our updates,
we're gonna do apt-get, all right?

169
00:08:57.073 --> 00:09:01.100
Apt-get Update and I'll hit Enter, and

170
00:09:01.100 --> 00:09:04.230
I'll let it run and
we'll talk about it while it's going.

171
00:09:04.230 --> 00:09:07.730
Coming from a Windows world like me,
you might think, there he goes,

172
00:09:07.730 --> 00:09:08.610
he's doing his updates.

173
00:09:08.610 --> 00:09:12.030
Just like going out Windows Update and
getting updates.

174
00:09:12.030 --> 00:09:13.615
You would be incorrect.

175
00:09:13.615 --> 00:09:15.570
[LAUGH] If you think
that's what's happening.

176
00:09:15.570 --> 00:09:18.620
I know I was incorrect the first
time I played around with this.

177
00:09:18.620 --> 00:09:21.420
It's not updating the software or
anything like that.

178
00:09:21.420 --> 00:09:24.410
What it's actually doing
is updating your catalogs.

179
00:09:24.410 --> 00:09:27.010
It's reaching out to the repositories and

180
00:09:27.010 --> 00:09:31.050
it's checking to see what is the latest
version of all these packages.

181
00:09:31.050 --> 00:09:33.780
If there's new dependencies or
anything like that.

182
00:09:33.780 --> 00:09:37.810
So it's updating its catalog
of what's available.

183
00:09:37.810 --> 00:09:40.900
So before you actually go get the updates,

184
00:09:40.900 --> 00:09:43.220
you wanna make sure that
you update your catalog.

185
00:09:43.220 --> 00:09:46.030
Because if your catalog's out of date,
when it goes and reaches out for

186
00:09:46.030 --> 00:09:47.940
the update it's gonna
be betting older stuff.

187
00:09:47.940 --> 00:09:49.980
It doesn't know about the new stuff yet.

188
00:09:49.980 --> 00:09:54.130
So before you do an upgrade or
a just upgrade, which we're gonna do next.

189
00:09:54.130 --> 00:09:56.380
You wanna make sure you
update your catalog.

190
00:09:56.380 --> 00:09:59.640
Basically saying, hey,
go see what the latest and

191
00:09:59.640 --> 00:10:04.080
greatest stuff is that's available in
the repository and make a note of it.

192
00:10:04.080 --> 00:10:04.760
And that's what it is.

193
00:10:04.760 --> 00:10:07.805
You can see if we look here,
it's reaching out to

194
00:10:07.805 --> 00:10:13.400
archive.Linux.duke.edu/KaliLinux rolling
in release, yadda, yadda, yadda.

195
00:10:13.400 --> 00:10:18.744
And so then you can see like amd64
packages, and it's reaching out.

196
00:10:18.744 --> 00:10:21.793
It says okay, this is what I'm running,
what packages are available?

197
00:10:21.793 --> 00:10:24.324
Let me download that list and
update my catalog.

198
00:10:24.324 --> 00:10:28.211
And then the last line there,
reading package lists, done.

199
00:10:28.211 --> 00:10:30.713
So now we're good to go as
far as our catalog goes.

200
00:10:30.713 --> 00:10:35.181
It now is aware of all the latest versions
of all the different packages that we have

201
00:10:35.181 --> 00:10:36.610
installed.

202
00:10:36.610 --> 00:10:41.190
Now the next command you're gonna run,
you could actually do one or

203

looks at any changing dependencies,

00:11:31.092 --> 00:11:34.172

the of the packages as well as

00:11:47.982 --> 00:11:53.918
the updating of any dependencies
that those new packages might have.

00:00:39.780 --> 00:00:40.480
>> It is.

15
00:00:40.480 --> 00:00:41.470
>> I like that.

All right, so yeah,

we had an episode where we took a look at

00:00:46.870 --> 00:00:49.870
Kali Linux post-installation
things that we wanted to do.

Like changing the root default password

00:01:11.350 --> 00:01:13.280
>> Mm-hm, right.

with our app get update, and our app

it really depends on
the environment you're using it in.

The default host name or the name of your

32
00:01:34.792 --> 00:01:39.134
K-A-L-I, and we can see that if

33
00:01:39.134 --> 00:01:43.552
I'll open up my little bash shell and
type in host name,

00:01:43.552 --> 00:01:46.654
simple enough, easy to remember, and

35
00:01:46.654 --> 00:01:51.453
I can see that it is indeed Kali
which in a lot of cases is fine.

36
00:01:51.453 --> 00:01:56.455
If I'm doing this in a lab environment
like what I do here it's all virtualized,

37
00:01:56.455 --> 00:02:01.678
half the time it's host only networking so
they can't talk to the rest of the network

38
00:02:01.678 --> 00:02:06.535
or at least the other boxes, so there's
no conflict, there's no problem and

39
00:02:06.535 --> 00:02:10.909
typically I might not be trying to
access it remotely so Kali's okay.

40
00:02:10.909 --> 00:02:15.298
If though you're gonna use this as your

41
00:02:15.298 --> 00:02:18.988

doing your security work you might

other people that are running Kali.

43
00:02:22.828 --> 00:02:24.562
You might not be the only one and

00:02:24.562 --> 00:02:29.169
you can't have two machines with the same
name, that's gonna cause a conflict,

45
00:02:29.169 --> 00:02:33.108
right, especially if we're trying
to access the Kali box remotely,

46
00:02:33.108 --> 00:02:36.320
then I really need to make
sure that that name is unique.

47
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:40.610
So let's start there, let's take a look at
how we go about changing our host name.

48
00:02:40.610 --> 00:02:44.750
There really are two places that we're
gonna wanna change our host name in.

49
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:50.415
One deals with local apps, and the other
one is going to be our actual DNS name,

50
00:02:50.415 --> 00:02:53.570
right, our FQDN,
our fully qualified domain name, and

51
00:02:53.570 --> 00:02:58.260
that's the one that would apply for
remote clients trying to connect to it.

52
00:02:58.260 --> 00:03:02.680
We would wanna make sure there's a DNS
entry for our machine on the DNS server

53
00:03:02.680 --> 00:03:06.250
that we're using on our network, things
like that, so let's take a look at it.

54
00:03:06.250 --> 00:03:12.000
The two places here, I am going to,
how's the best way to do this?

55
00:03:12.000 --> 00:03:16.970
I'll use Leafpad again simply because it's
a little bit easier to show on screen,

56
00:03:16.970 --> 00:03:20.236
if you're using Vi, or
Nano is my personal favorite,

57
00:03:20.236 --> 00:03:24.866
but Leafpad shows up best on screen here,
makes it a little bit easier for us.

58
00:03:24.866 --> 00:03:29.268
I'm gonna do, it's Etsy/hostname,
all right, and

59
00:03:29.268 --> 00:03:34.513
there it is [LAUGH] it's a very
complex file as you can see, right?

60
00:03:34.513 --> 00:03:35.775
>> Yeah, yeah it's very complex.

61
00:03:35.775 --> 00:03:36.945
>> Hopefully you can see that here,

62
00:03:36.945 --> 00:03:40.265
I'll tell you what I'll even
bump up the font a wee bit.

63
00:03:40.265 --> 00:03:41.235
>> Too many words.

64
00:03:41.235 --> 00:03:43.620
>> I know, it is crazy complex so

65
00:03:43.620 --> 00:03:47.177
you really don't wanna make any changes in
here unless you know what you're doing.

66
00:03:47.177 --> 00:03:51.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm kidding, whatever you type here is

67
00:03:51.040 --> 00:03:56.810
gonna be the name of your machine
as far as local apps go, right,

68
00:03:56.810 --> 00:04:01.330
S and B actually uses this name if
you're doing or something like that.

69
00:04:01.330 --> 00:04:02.890
So I don't know,
what should we change it to,

70
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:04.690
what do you want the name
of the machine to be?

71
00:04:04.690 --> 00:04:05.640
>> Fuzzy ears.

72
00:04:05.640 --> 00:04:07.548
>> How did I know that was coming?

what I really mean is clear, fantastic.

00:30:14.977 --> 00:30:16.277
cd space dot dot,

535
00:30:16.277 --> 00:30:22.030
takes you back up one level when
you're browsing through the directory.

536
00:30:22.030 --> 00:30:23.785
Well, I always miss the space.

537
00:30:23.785 --> 00:30:26.398
cd.., I don't do, cd space dot dot.

538
00:30:26.398 --> 00:30:28.062
And then it says command not found.

539
00:30:28.062 --> 00:30:30.781
Then I have to go back and
type, cd space dot dot.

540
00:30:30.781 --> 00:30:31.970
So I just simply made an alias.

541
00:30:31.970 --> 00:30:35.059
[CROSSTALK] [LAUGH] I said
rather than change my habits,

542
00:30:35.059 --> 00:30:38.159
how about I just fix my system
to do it the way I want it.

543
00:30:38.159 --> 00:30:42.140
So cd dot dot, is indeed cd space dot dot.

544
00:30:42.140 --> 00:30:43.475
Same thing with my tilde.

545
00:30:43.475 --> 00:30:49.100
cd tilde is actually gonna execute,
cd space tilde.

546
00:30:49.100 --> 00:30:54.549
You could do something like alias

547
00:30:54.549 --> 00:31:00.900
ipconfig actually equals ifconfig.

548
00:31:00.900 --> 00:31:04.390
Cuz in Windows it's ipconfig,
and here it's ifconfig.

549
00:31:04.390 --> 00:31:08.580
Now I don't know,
I typically don't do that one.

550
00:31:08.580 --> 00:31:11.620
So most of you have probably
watched Don's shows.

551
00:31:11.620 --> 00:31:16.100
He's a Linux guru, and
I was actually hosting one of his shows.

552
00:31:16.100 --> 00:31:20.110
And when he was talking about
this I was like, I do that.

553
00:31:20.110 --> 00:31:21.010
>> Yeah.
>> He was like,

554
00:31:21.010 --> 00:31:23.860
don't use aliases to cheat yourself.

555
00:31:23.860 --> 00:31:25.923
Learn the right way to do it, rather than-
>> [LAUGH]

556
00:31:25.923 --> 00:31:26.791
>> Make an alias and

557
00:31:26.791 --> 00:31:28.470
continue to do it the wrong way.

558
00:31:28.470 --> 00:31:30.970
>> But you can make an alias,
which is cool.

559
00:31:30.970 --> 00:31:31.830
>> Okay, yeah, Don.

560
00:31:31.830 --> 00:31:33.250
I understand that, it's true.

561
00:31:33.250 --> 00:31:38.320
And so I don't do things like ifconfig for
ipconfig or for anything like that.

562
00:31:38.320 --> 00:31:40.304
But there are some,
like I said, that I just love.

563
00:31:40.304 --> 00:31:44.410
cls is so much easier to type,
and it just makes sense to me.

564
00:31:44.410 --> 00:31:46.140
So, do what you will with your aliases.

565
00:31:46.140 --> 00:31:49.840
You can create all you want,
save it out in a little file like this.

566
00:31:51.220 --> 00:31:53.930
And then when you're in your,
you would restart.

567
00:31:53.930 --> 00:31:56.130
I didn't make any changes,
but you would restart.

568
00:31:56.130 --> 00:32:00.450
And now if I do cls, which normally
would be a command not found,

569
00:32:00.450 --> 00:32:02.000
it actually clears my screen.

570
00:32:02.000 --> 00:32:08.768
If I do an la,
I get the same results as typing, ls -a.

571
00:32:08.768 --> 00:32:12.785
Actually it's an ls A,
I think is what the alias is.

572
00:32:12.785 --> 00:32:15.938
So we could do ls -A, that way.

573
00:32:15.938 --> 00:32:18.516
And there my results
look exactly the same.

574
00:32:18.516 --> 00:32:23.020
So that's how you can use aliases to make
your life a little bit easier when working

575
00:32:23.020 --> 00:32:23.862
in Bash.

576
00:32:23.862 --> 00:32:26.655
>> Fantastic, well,
we're gonna have to do a part three.

577
00:32:26.655 --> 00:32:30.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> A Post Installation Configuration part

578
00:32:30.350 --> 00:32:32.100
three, Kali Linux.

579
00:32:32.100 --> 00:32:35.102
And part two, of course,
that's what we were just doing here.

580
00:32:35.102 --> 00:32:36.550
And there's a part one.

581
00:32:36.550 --> 00:32:39.420
So you wanna make sure you watch
all the videos in this series.

582
00:32:39.420 --> 00:32:40.990
Mike, any last words before we go?

583
00:32:40.990 --> 00:32:44.009
>> When we come back, we'll take a look
at actually setting up a couple of

584
00:32:44.009 --> 00:32:46.550
services that we might want
to start automatically.

585
00:32:46.550 --> 00:32:49.291
>> Awesome, and thank you for
watching ITProTV.

586
00:32:49.291 --> 00:32:52.810
And remember,
a good IT pro is always learning.

587
00:32:52.810 --> 00:32:53.610
I'm Zach Memos.

588
00:32:53.610 --> 00:32:54.400
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

589
00:32:54.400 --> 00:32:56.899
>> And we'll see you soon.

590
00:32:56.899 --> 00:33:02.769
[MUSIC]

591
00:33:02.769 --> 00:33:10.154
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Mike and Zach define 'Metasploit' and how to access it, 'Postgesql,' using Apache with Kali Linux, and what 'SSH' is.
episodes.title: Post Installation Configuration Part 3

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss how to get the Kali Box connected to networks, how to configure network adapters, accessing the GUI, using Shell, adding multiple network adapters, and how we get Kali to communicate with Vulnerable Machines (VM).
episodes.title: Network Configuration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.153 --> 00:00:07.195
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.195 --> 00:00:08.298
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.298 --> 00:00:12.272
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.272 --> 00:00:13.919
>> Hello again, thank you for

5
00:00:13.919 --> 00:00:17.436
watching ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.436 --> 00:00:21.551
My name is Zach Memos and I am your host
as we continue on with Kali Linux and

7
00:00:21.551 --> 00:00:22.971
love me some Kali Linux.

8
00:00:22.971 --> 00:00:25.984
And today we're talking
about network configuration.

9
00:00:25.984 --> 00:00:29.858
Person bringing us all that information
is our IT Pro resident Kali expert,

10
00:00:29.858 --> 00:00:31.260
Mike Rodrick right there.

11
00:00:31.260 --> 00:00:32.507
Hey Mick good morning to you sir.

12
00:00:32.507 --> 00:00:34.701
>> Hey good morning Zach
good to be here and

13
00:00:34.701 --> 00:00:39.554
glad to have everybody out there watching,
and yes we've gone through in our previous

14
00:00:39.554 --> 00:00:43.411
episodes We've looked at different
ways to install Kali get it up and

15
00:00:43.411 --> 00:00:46.754
running, like off of a USB drive,
even with persistence.

16
00:00:46.754 --> 00:00:49.990
What we haven't talked about yet
is networking this guy.

17
00:00:49.990 --> 00:00:54.440
Obviously we're gonna use Kali to perform
penetration tests, to scan machines.

18
00:00:54.440 --> 00:00:58.370
Needs to be connected to our network,
and so we need to take a look at some of

19
00:00:58.370 --> 00:01:00.310
the options we can use
to configure networking.

20
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:03.480
Obviously we've been talking about
DHCP and doing it statically.

21
00:01:03.480 --> 00:01:07.260
And this is really pertinent if you're
running it either in persistent mode,

22
00:01:07.260 --> 00:01:09.393
where I can actually save configurations.

23
00:01:09.393 --> 00:01:13.987
Remember, if I'm running it off of a CD or
off of a USB just live, no persistence,

24
00:01:13.987 --> 00:01:17.000
none of my configuration
changes are gonna be there.

25
00:01:17.000 --> 00:01:18.590
Now that's not to say you can't do them.

26
00:01:18.590 --> 00:01:21.995
You might plug in your live thumb drive,
do some configuration so

27
00:01:21.995 --> 00:01:23.690
it can connect to the current network.

28
00:01:23.690 --> 00:01:27.060
But all those are gonna go away
when you shut it down right.

29
00:01:27.060 --> 00:01:30.850
The next time you plug that thumb dive
into a machine, you'll have to reset those

30
00:01:30.850 --> 00:01:34.070
or pick up the appropriate settings
from whatever network, and that's fine.

31
00:01:34.070 --> 00:01:37.736
But if you are doing a, so I'll show
you how to configure those IP settings.

32
00:01:37.736 --> 00:01:43.342
And I also wanna show you how to add
a second network adapter to Kali Linux.

33
00:01:43.342 --> 00:01:47.545
When you're using the offensive
security VMs, those pre-built VMs.

34
00:01:47.545 --> 00:01:51.240
Because I think a lot of you are gonna be
probably taking advantage of those as you

35
00:01:51.240 --> 00:01:52.200
learn Kali.

36
00:01:52.200 --> 00:01:54.814
As you practice with the different tools,

37
00:01:54.814 --> 00:01:59.618
you're gonna want to connect to vulnerable
machines, like what we use here.

38
00:01:59.618 --> 00:02:02.293
Either two,

39
00:02:02.293 --> 00:02:08.292
you might be looking at
the Darn Vulnerable Web Application DVWA.

40
00:02:08.292 --> 00:02:13.160
Things from the wonderful people out
there at that set-up vulnerable virtual

41
00:02:13.160 --> 00:02:17.359
machines and these are what we want to
practice these tools as we learn about

42
00:02:17.359 --> 00:02:20.642
these different security tools,
we need to try them out.

43
00:02:20.642 --> 00:02:24.706
We need to get good at them,
understand their different options,

44
00:02:24.706 --> 00:02:29.250
look at the output that we get from
those tools, understand that output.

45
00:02:29.250 --> 00:02:33.010
And if I am only scanning
machines that are not vulnerable,

46
00:02:33.010 --> 00:02:36.500
and hopefully that's what
the machines are on my network,

47
00:02:36.500 --> 00:02:38.810
then I'm not gonna see a lot
back from these tools.

48
00:02:38.810 --> 00:02:43.850
So I don't really get a good idea of what
I would see if there was a vulnerability.

49
00:02:43.850 --> 00:02:47.443
So that's why practicing with pre-built,
vulnerable machines is very important.

50
00:02:47.443 --> 00:02:50.928
It gives us the ability to see
what it would look like if we did

51
00:02:50.928 --> 00:02:52.980
discover vulnerabilities.

52
00:02:52.980 --> 00:02:55.100
And then even how to take advantage
of those vulnerabilities.

53
00:02:55.100 --> 00:02:58.150
And then, ultimately, how to patch
against those vulnerabilities and

54
00:02:58.150 --> 00:02:59.660
protect our network from them.

55
00:02:59.660 --> 00:03:03.170
So we are gonna be running some machines
that are intentionally vulnerable

56
00:03:03.170 --> 00:03:06.090
as we learn and play with Kali Linux.

57
00:03:06.090 --> 00:03:09.197
With that being said these machines
are intentionally vulnerable.

58
00:03:09.197 --> 00:03:12.229
>> [LAUGH]
>> It means they've got tons of weaknesses

59
00:03:12.229 --> 00:03:13.222
built into them.

60
00:03:13.222 --> 00:03:16.561
And if you attach them to a network
that’s exposed to the public network for

61
00:03:16.561 --> 00:03:19.741
example they're going to be found
they're going to be compromised and

62
00:03:19.741 --> 00:03:22.180
that’s now the doorway into
the rest of your network.

63
00:03:22.180 --> 00:03:24.720
You've just compromised your entire
network which is not what we

64
00:03:24.720 --> 00:03:25.420
want to do right.

65
00:03:25.420 --> 00:03:29.210
We don't want to be the one,
that brought the bad guys in.

66
00:03:29.210 --> 00:03:31.690
So we wanna be really careful
with exposing those guys,

67
00:03:31.690 --> 00:03:36.400
even exposing them to our internal
network can be a little risky.

68
00:03:36.400 --> 00:03:39.997
If you've got other people on your
network that are maybe experimenting and

69
00:03:39.997 --> 00:03:42.764
they find one of those and
they try to take advantage of it.

70
00:03:42.764 --> 00:03:45.326
There's just too many things
that can go wrong, so

71
00:03:45.326 --> 00:03:49.730
typically we isolate those virtual
machines from the rest of our network.

72
00:03:49.730 --> 00:03:51.610
To make sure that nothing bad happens.

73
00:03:51.610 --> 00:03:56.933
But now I've gotta get my kalibox to
be able to hit that isolated network.

74
00:03:56.933 --> 00:03:59.810
And hopefully at the same
time still hit the Internet.

75
00:03:59.810 --> 00:04:01.440
Because I need to go out and do research.

76
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:07.080
Or I need to take a look at a website
to get some instructions on a tool.

77
00:04:07.080 --> 00:04:11.600
Or go out to bug track, or find some
information on a vulnerability from one

78
00:04:11.600 --> 00:04:14.390
for those vulnerability databases, maybe
you need to go out to offensive security.

79
00:04:15.500 --> 00:04:18.113
And I can switch my
network settings back and

80
00:04:18.113 --> 00:04:22.574
forth in my Kali box okay I'm gonna
connect it to my internal only network.

81
00:04:22.574 --> 00:04:25.617
And now I need to go out and find some
information so I'm gonna you know,

82
00:04:25.617 --> 00:04:28.633
reconfigure it to connect to the normal
LAN and go out to the Internet.

83
00:04:28.633 --> 00:04:32.832
And then when I need to hit those machines
again, I gotta reconfigure it and

84
00:04:32.832 --> 00:04:33.910
that can be a pain.

85
00:04:33.910 --> 00:04:38.610
And one of the things I found with
the offensive security pre-bulit VMs

86
00:04:38.610 --> 00:04:40.680
is that I can only enable one
network adaptor at a time.

87
00:04:40.680 --> 00:04:44.030
You turn one on, the other one turns
off and it gets a little frustrating.

88
00:04:44.030 --> 00:04:48.670
So I'm gonna show you a way that
we can get our Kali machine

89
00:04:48.670 --> 00:04:52.410
to be able to talk to the Internet or at
least the LAN and then whatever else you

90
00:04:52.410 --> 00:04:57.410
want it to talk to as well as our
isolated network with our vulnerable VMs.

91
00:04:57.410 --> 00:04:59.302
So that's the goal for
this particular episode.

92
00:04:59.302 --> 00:05:03.737
>> So then, the next question would be,
we've got Kali loaded from offensive

93
00:05:03.737 --> 00:05:07.710
security, so how do we get the Kali
box connected to the network?

94
00:05:07.710 --> 00:05:09.180
>> That's a great place to start.

95
00:05:09.180 --> 00:05:10.402
So let's take a look at that.

96
00:05:10.402 --> 00:05:14.072
Out of the box Kali is going to
be set up to be a DHCP client,

97
00:05:14.072 --> 00:05:17.591
meaning I plug it in,
it's got a network adaptor, and

98
00:05:17.591 --> 00:05:21.512
as long as there's DHTP on my
network we should be good to go.

99
00:05:21.512 --> 00:05:25.953
I will say that a lot of this is going to
depend on your virtualization software,

100
00:05:25.953 --> 00:05:27.892
we've talked about that before.

101
00:05:27.892 --> 00:05:32.860
>> If you're using via Workstation or
Player or VirtualBox or Hyper-V or

102
00:05:32.860 --> 00:05:37.246
what have you, the actual steps
might be a little different but

103
00:05:37.246 --> 00:05:40.090
the concept is going to remain the same.

104
00:05:40.090 --> 00:05:43.660
So that's what we're here to learn and
then you'll have to kind of tweak it

105
00:05:43.660 --> 00:05:46.740
a little bit for
your particular virtualization.

106
00:05:46.740 --> 00:05:48.490
So the first thing I'm gonna
look at when you load up,

107
00:05:48.490 --> 00:05:52.270
again this is just a pre-built
Kali Linux box that I've downloaded from

108
00:05:52.270 --> 00:05:57.140
Offensive Security for our VM workstation,
which is the platform that I'm using.

109
00:05:57.140 --> 00:06:02.309
I have done all of my updates,
my apt-get update to update my catalog and

110
00:06:02.309 --> 00:06:05.883
my apt-get disk upgrade
to get all of my updates.

111
00:06:05.883 --> 00:06:09.060
And then I've saved my machines,
and I'm gone from there.

112
00:06:09.060 --> 00:06:10.650
So this is an updated,

113
00:06:10.650 --> 00:06:14.190
current, running version of
Kali Linux from Offensive Security.

114
00:06:15.310 --> 00:06:18.110
Now, if we take a look,
if I open up a terminal,

115
00:06:18.110 --> 00:06:22.033
we can from the terminal we can
determine what our IP settings are.

116
00:06:22.033 --> 00:06:26.090
We can do our IF Config Now hit enter.

117
00:06:26.090 --> 00:06:28.222
And it shows me that I've
got one network adapter.

118
00:06:28.222 --> 00:06:30.900
Eth0 is gonna be my code for that one.

119
00:06:30.900 --> 00:06:35.203
And I can see that I have picked
up an Internet address, or

120
00:06:35.203 --> 00:06:39.882
an IP address, 1010814,
with my subnet mask there.

121
00:06:39.882 --> 00:06:42.211
So it's showing me that
I have connectivity.

122
00:06:42.211 --> 00:06:47.333
In my virtualization software,
let me drop this down a little bit.

123
00:06:47.333 --> 00:06:48.760
Let me put it out of full screen there.

124
00:06:48.760 --> 00:06:53.094
If we take a look at the settings for
this particular vm.

125
00:06:53.094 --> 00:06:57.198
I look at my network adapter, and again,
this is where it'll differ at little bit

126
00:06:57.198 --> 00:06:59.996
depending on what your
virtualization technology is,

127
00:06:59.996 --> 00:07:03.820
I can see this guy is connected to nat,
used to share the host's IP address.

128
00:07:03.820 --> 00:07:07.980
We're doing network address translation
between this virtual machine and

129
00:07:07.980 --> 00:07:11.680
the physical network that my laptop
that the virtual machine is running on

130
00:07:11.680 --> 00:07:14.220
that we're doing NAT in between those.

131
00:07:14.220 --> 00:07:17.740
So my laptop is getting an IP address from
the local area network that it's connected

132
00:07:17.740 --> 00:07:22.970
to and my Kali Linux box is getting
an IP address from virtual machine or

133
00:07:22.970 --> 00:07:24.350
VM workstation.

134
00:07:24.350 --> 00:07:26.920
And then im NATing in between those two.

135
00:07:26.920 --> 00:07:32.780
So at this point I should have
Internet access for this machine,

136
00:07:32.780 --> 00:07:37.750
if we ping something like
google.com I get replies, right.

137
00:07:37.750 --> 00:07:42.550
It's able to reach out, talk to DNS,
resolve that name into an IP address,

138
00:07:42.550 --> 00:07:45.325
return that IP address
back to my command and

139
00:07:45.325 --> 00:07:49.921
then start doing our ICMP echo requests
and everything is working good.

140
00:07:49.921 --> 00:07:53.706
So, we do have Internet
access on this machine.

141
00:07:53.706 --> 00:07:58.268
Okay, so I've got my IP address,
get Internet access, everything is good.

142
00:07:58.268 --> 00:08:01.408
Now, I've got my vulnerable machines, and

143
00:08:01.408 --> 00:08:07.283
these again could be from somebody like or
capture to the flag type machine.

144
00:08:07.283 --> 00:08:13.001
This is the DVWA,
the Darn Vulnerable web application and I

145
00:08:13.001 --> 00:08:15.504
>> That darn vulnerable web application.

146
00:08:15.504 --> 00:08:16.480
Darn it.

147
00:08:16.480 --> 00:08:17.170
>> Darn thing.

148
00:08:17.170 --> 00:08:21.200
If we look at the settings for this, this
is one of those vulnerable machines, and

149
00:08:21.200 --> 00:08:24.060
so when I fire these up and
let me find my settings.

150
00:08:24.060 --> 00:08:24.640
Here we go.

151
00:08:24.640 --> 00:08:27.260
Talking and clicking at the same
time can be challenging.

152
00:08:27.260 --> 00:08:30.890
I see that this guy is connected
to a host only network.

153
00:08:30.890 --> 00:08:35.350
Almost every virtualization software
has this ability to say hey,

154
00:08:35.350 --> 00:08:37.650
I want to network that's private.

155
00:08:37.650 --> 00:08:42.592
Just to the VMs themselves, it can't reach
out and talk to the internal network or

156
00:08:42.592 --> 00:08:46.480
to the LAN or to the WAN or
anything like that.

157
00:08:46.480 --> 00:08:49.130
Again, because it's specifically
designed to be vulnerable and

158
00:08:49.130 --> 00:08:50.500
I don't want to expose it.

159
00:08:50.500 --> 00:08:55.290
So it's set to a host only, and if we were
to take a look at the settings from we'd

160
00:08:55.290 --> 00:08:59.320
see the same thing, I go into settings and
I've got it connected to host only.

161
00:09:00.870 --> 00:09:06.031
So if we look at the IP address,
if I can get this guy up,

162
00:09:06.031 --> 00:09:08.969
I get some focus going on here.

163
00:09:08.969 --> 00:09:12.894
Do a little ifconfig,
