00:22:03.100 --> 00:22:05.690
We've got access to the internet,
and I've got a nice,

391
00:22:05.690 --> 00:22:09.430
safe network that I can run my
vulnerable machines on, and

392
00:22:09.430 --> 00:22:13.870
we can start playing with things like the
DVWA, the Darn Vulnerable Web Application.

393
00:22:13.870 --> 00:22:14.810
>> That darn one.

394
00:22:14.810 --> 00:22:19.380
>> Yeah, we've got Metasploitable 2,
that's got dozens of exploits or

395
00:22:19.380 --> 00:22:21.210
vulnerability setup in there.

396
00:22:21.210 --> 00:22:23.920
We can start going out to
places like Vuln Hub and

397
00:22:23.920 --> 00:22:27.730
downloading some of these CTF,
capture the flag type vulnerable machines

398
00:22:27.730 --> 00:22:29.620
that we can use to
practice our techniques.

399
00:22:29.620 --> 00:22:33.290
And test out the different tools
all in a nice, safe network,

400
00:22:33.290 --> 00:22:37.949
keeping anything else that we're connected
to from picking up anything bad,

401
00:22:37.949 --> 00:22:40.491
and protecting the vulnerable machines,

402
00:22:40.491 --> 00:22:44.391
themselves from somebody else
finding them, exploiting them.

403
00:22:44.391 --> 00:22:47.850
And turning them into a stepping
stone into the rest of our networks.

404
00:22:47.850 --> 00:22:52.508
So that is how we're gonna setup Kali to
go through the rest of the episodes as we

405
00:22:52.508 --> 00:22:54.000
progress to the series.

406
00:22:54.000 --> 00:22:54.800
>> Awesome.

407
00:22:54.800 --> 00:22:57.380
I can't wait so episodes coming up.

408
00:22:57.380 --> 00:23:02.760
We're gonna actually put this in the we're
gonna do some Full forensics, right.

409
00:23:02.760 --> 00:23:03.300
>> Yeah, absolutely.

410
00:23:03.300 --> 00:23:08.040
Well, we're gonna do some recognizants,
we'll go through discovering the machines,

411
00:23:08.040 --> 00:23:11.760
doing our recognizants,
we'll look at exploiting those.

412
00:23:11.760 --> 00:23:14.220
But yeah, we'll walk through all
the different tools that we use in Kali.

413
00:23:14.220 --> 00:23:16.505
>> Fantastic,
can't wait network configuration.

414
00:23:16.505 --> 00:23:20.340
Kali Linux and there's a whole
bunch of video's in this series.

415
00:23:20.340 --> 00:23:22.130
Make sure you watch every
single one of them.

416
00:23:22.130 --> 00:23:24.840
You'll be very glad you did Mike,
excellent job as always.

417
00:23:24.840 --> 00:23:26.750
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

418
00:23:26.750 --> 00:23:29.760
Remember, a good IT pro's always learning.

419
00:23:29.760 --> 00:23:30.660
I'm Zach Memos.

420
00:23:30.660 --> 00:23:31.450
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

421
00:23:31.450 --> 00:23:33.621
>> And we will see you soon!

422
00:23:33.621 --> 00:23:39.636
[MUSIC]

423
00:23:39.636 --> 00:23:42.458
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Mike and Zach continue the discussion of using Kali Linux basic functionality, using the 'Menu,' locating files, using 'Which' & 'Find' functions, accessing 'History,' and how to clear history.
episodes.title: Navigating Kali Linux
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:06.540
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.540 --> 00:00:08.000
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.000 --> 00:00:11.907
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.907 --> 00:00:17.090
>> Hello, thank you for watching ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:17.090 --> 00:00:20.460
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with Kali Linux.

6
00:00:20.460 --> 00:00:24.268
And right now it's navigating
Kali Linux with our Linux

7
00:00:24.268 --> 00:00:29.960
professional expert wizard,
Mike Rodrick, right here.

8
00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:31.610
Hey, Mike.
>> Hey, how you doing, Zach?

9
00:00:31.610 --> 00:00:33.080
I don't know about all that, but

10
00:00:33.080 --> 00:00:36.238
yeah, let's take a look at what we can
do in Linux, or in Kali I should say.

11
00:00:36.238 --> 00:00:39.180
All right, so this episode is just kinda

12
00:00:39.180 --> 00:00:41.890
getting our feet wet as far as
just working our way around Kali.

13
00:00:41.890 --> 00:00:45.110
Just a couple of little things that I
wanted to point out to you that will

14
00:00:45.110 --> 00:00:49.130
make it easier as we go through
some of our future episodes and

15
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:51.710
start working with the tools, cuz that's
really what it's all about, right?

16
00:00:51.710 --> 00:00:53.340
We want to get in here and
play with the tools.

17
00:00:53.340 --> 00:00:54.650
That's why we run Kali, isn't it?

18
00:00:54.650 --> 00:00:56.660
>> Right
>> Because it has 600 plus tools built

19
00:00:56.660 --> 00:01:01.370
into it But if we can't find them,
if we can't get to them, it's no fun.

20
00:01:01.370 --> 00:01:05.620
So let's do a little bit of
kind of foundation work there.

21
00:01:05.620 --> 00:01:10.170
We've got some other great courses in
the library where we really go into

22
00:01:10.170 --> 00:01:14.600
basic Linux commands, and working from
the terminal and things like that.

23
00:01:14.600 --> 00:01:18.300
So make sure you check those out if
you're newer to Linux, in general.

24
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:23.280
As far as Kali goes,
it's, one of the things

25
00:01:23.280 --> 00:01:27.800
that's a good thing about Kali is the fact
that there's 600 plus tools built in.

26
00:01:27.800 --> 00:01:32.335
One of the downsides of that, though,
is where are they, how do I find them?

27
00:01:32.335 --> 00:01:35.885
What are all these crazy tools and
what the heck do they do?

28
00:01:35.885 --> 00:01:36.805
>> I do have a question for you.

29
00:01:36.805 --> 00:01:38.375
>> Yes.
>> What are all these crazy tools and

30
00:01:38.375 --> 00:01:39.335
what the heck do they do?

31
00:01:39.335 --> 00:01:41.585
>> That's a great question,
I'm glad you asked.

32
00:01:41.585 --> 00:01:43.045
Let's take a look at it, right?

33
00:01:43.045 --> 00:01:46.845
One of the things that I love that they've
done, if you go up here to the top and

34
00:01:46.845 --> 00:01:48.565
take a look at my screen, sorry, Megan.

35
00:01:48.565 --> 00:01:52.700
And we look at the very
top left-hand corner,

36
00:01:52.700 --> 00:01:54.475
I have to remember my right
from my left for a second.

37
00:01:54.475 --> 00:01:55.636
>> [LAUGH] Your other right.

38
00:01:55.636 --> 00:01:58.480
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,
my other right, military right.

39
00:01:58.480 --> 00:02:03.570
I've got my Applications menu, and
from here, I've got Categories, right?

40
00:02:03.570 --> 00:02:05.730
You've got Favorites,
which you can kind of pin and

41
00:02:05.730 --> 00:02:08.324
unpin things from, which is great.

42
00:02:08.324 --> 00:02:11.340
So things that you use
often you can put there.

43
00:02:11.340 --> 00:02:14.600
If you're still showing
your dash to dock or

44
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:18.920
dock to dash thing,
you can also pin applications down there.

45
00:02:18.920 --> 00:02:22.190
But below that,
we have these categories, right?

46
00:02:22.190 --> 00:02:25.070
Kind of Windows-esque, if you will.

47
00:02:25.070 --> 00:02:29.320
I know most of you Linux people are going,
did he just say that.

48
00:02:29.320 --> 00:02:31.178
>> Yeah, he did.
Windows-esque.

49
00:02:31.178 --> 00:02:33.800
>> But it does,
it reminds me a little bit of that.

50
00:02:33.800 --> 00:02:34.650
But it's categorized.

51
00:02:34.650 --> 00:02:38.380
So this first category is
information gathering.

52
00:02:38.380 --> 00:02:42.240
And when I hover over that,
I get a slide out menu over here.

53
00:02:42.240 --> 00:02:46.770
And these are the different tools that I
can use for information gathering, right?

54
00:02:46.770 --> 00:02:51.930
Now, any of these that have a little
triangle out to the side of them,

55
00:02:51.930 --> 00:02:56.270
I can actually click on and
it will expand it out even further.

56
00:02:56.270 --> 00:02:59.450
So these are just some of the most
common information gathering.

57
00:02:59.450 --> 00:03:02.710
But if I expand this out,
I want to do DNS analysis.

58
00:03:02.710 --> 00:03:05.310
There's a bunch of DNS
tools that I can work with.

59
00:03:05.310 --> 00:03:08.020
We want to do SMB analysis.

60
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:12.280
Well, here's some tools
that work with SBM or SMTP.

61
00:03:12.280 --> 00:03:15.510
And the idea is,
I don't know what Squawks is.

62
00:03:15.510 --> 00:03:20.640
If they give me a list of tools that I
could use, and I wanted to do some SMTP

63
00:03:20.640 --> 00:03:26.155
analysis, I might not know that Squawks
is a tool that will work with SMTP.

64
00:03:26.155 --> 00:03:32.875
But I do now because
it's under SMTP Analysis.

65
00:03:32.875 --> 00:03:37.295
So great way to organize these tools
in the menu that they developed here

66
00:03:37.295 --> 00:03:38.795
by these categories.

67
00:03:38.795 --> 00:03:40.505
And they did it for that very reason.

68
00:03:40.505 --> 00:03:41.235
Because there's so

69
00:03:41.235 --> 00:03:45.660
many tools, this is a really good way to
show them in a small amount of space.

70
00:03:45.660 --> 00:03:48.660
And many of these tools you
might not be familiar with.

71
00:03:48.660 --> 00:03:52.610
And so you'll know that if I go
under wireless attacks in Bluetooth,

72
00:03:52.610 --> 00:03:56.480
that Red Fang is a Bluetooth
wireless tool that I can use.

73
00:03:56.480 --> 00:03:59.814
Just simply from where
it's located on the menu.

74
00:03:59.814 --> 00:04:04.303
So love that feature, it's very,
very handy when we're first getting

75
00:04:04.303 --> 00:04:07.690
our feet wet with all of
these tools in Kali Linux.

76
00:04:07.690 --> 00:04:09.800
So that's the way the menu is laid out.

77
00:04:09.800 --> 00:04:14.280
You simply click on one obviously, and
it would launch that tool, all right?

78
00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:18.400
And then you've got your systems
services and your usual applications,

79
00:04:18.400 --> 00:04:20.300
accessories, Internet.

80
00:04:20.300 --> 00:04:22.930
Some of your standard applications
that you get with most

81
00:04:22.930 --> 00:04:26.210
operating systems are included as well.

82
00:04:26.210 --> 00:04:28.390
So lots and lots and lots of tools there.

83
00:04:28.390 --> 00:04:31.245
It always makes me laugh cuz
people go there's not that many.

84
00:04:31.245 --> 00:04:33.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> Until you realize that each one of

85
00:04:33.480 --> 00:04:36.330
those expandable and has subcategories.

86
00:04:36.330 --> 00:04:39.340
And some of those have
scroll bars on them.

87
00:04:39.340 --> 00:04:41.320
There are a lot of tools.

88
00:04:41.320 --> 00:04:43.760
>> Are the dependencies here too, or no?

89
00:04:43.760 --> 00:04:44.520
>> Not so much.

90
00:04:44.520 --> 00:04:46.670
You just find the tool,
click on it, launch it.

91
00:04:46.670 --> 00:04:48.540
Some of them are going
to have a GUI interface.

92
00:04:48.540 --> 00:04:52.590
Some of them will just open up a terminal
with that command started there.

93
00:04:52.590 --> 00:04:54.020
Which brings us to another point.

94
00:04:54.020 --> 00:04:58.220
You can always, like I can go, let's
say I want to do some scanning, right?

95
00:04:58.220 --> 00:04:59.660
I wanna run Nmap.

96
00:04:59.660 --> 00:05:01.910
I don't know where it is on here.

97
00:05:01.910 --> 00:05:05.970
So we could do sniffing and
spoofing, probably, or

98
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:07.890
information gathering, would be one.

99
00:05:07.890 --> 00:05:09.191
Yeah, and there's Nmap.

100
00:05:09.191 --> 00:05:12.800
So I can click it, and
I can launch Nmap, right?

101
00:05:12.800 --> 00:05:13.875
It gives me the help.

102
00:05:13.875 --> 00:05:18.690
Cuz it's basically like typing
Nmap with no parameters in there.

103
00:05:18.690 --> 00:05:23.030
Or if I know the name of the tool I want,
then I can simply come in here and

104
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:24.270
type in Nmap.

105
00:05:24.270 --> 00:05:26.290
And we could launch it that way as well.

106
00:05:26.290 --> 00:05:29.534
So either way, you wanna go to the menu,
you want us to open up the terminal,

107
00:05:29.534 --> 00:05:32.010
type in if you already
know the name of the tool.

108
00:05:32.010 --> 00:05:36.420
Usually the menu's a great place to start,
and then once you're familiar with

109
00:05:36.420 --> 00:05:40.780
the tools that you like, you can just
launch them up there from the terminal.

110
00:05:40.780 --> 00:05:44.940
You can also go into
your show applications.

111
00:05:44.940 --> 00:05:47.510
If you have this little
dock still on your screen,

112
00:05:47.510 --> 00:05:50.230
I know some people might have hidden
it permanently, taken it off.

113
00:05:50.230 --> 00:05:51.436
I think we talked about
that in another episode-

114
00:05:51.436 --> 00:05:52.522
>> Right, right customizable.

115
00:05:52.522 --> 00:05:57.810
>> Yeah, so
you can click show applications Maybe.

116
00:05:57.810 --> 00:05:58.650
There we go.

117
00:05:58.650 --> 00:06:00.930
And it takes me to this screen here.

118
00:06:00.930 --> 00:06:06.660
And it starts on frequent, and these are
the things that I've used recently, right?

119
00:06:06.660 --> 00:06:11.330
Or I can switch to All, and
it shows me those same categories, and

120
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:12.420
I can navigate through there.

121
00:06:12.420 --> 00:06:15.310
But I can also just type Nmap, right?

122
00:06:15.310 --> 00:06:20.810
And it shows me, look I've got Nmap, I've
got Zenmap, and I've got Zenmap as root.

123
00:06:20.810 --> 00:06:24.045
So a few different ways you can go
about launching the applications.

124
00:06:24.045 --> 00:06:25.850
You'll see there's several screens here,

125
00:06:25.850 --> 00:06:30.160
you can see this little dots as
I scroll and go through those.

126
00:06:30.160 --> 00:06:34.790
All right, so that is how we can
go about finding our applications,

127
00:06:34.790 --> 00:06:39.080
either through the menu or
through your show applications, or

128
00:06:39.080 --> 00:06:41.795
simply typing the name
in the terminal there.

129
00:06:41.795 --> 00:06:43.490
All right,

130
00:06:43.490 --> 00:06:47.260
now the next thing I wanna talk about is
how we can find things in the file system.

131
00:06:47.260 --> 00:06:49.160
>> Yeah, I was gonna say,
how do we locate them?

132
00:06:49.160 --> 00:06:50.690
I mean, if we wanna do it quickly.

133
00:06:50.690 --> 00:06:53.396
>> Yeah, and there's a few
different commands that Kali has or

134
00:06:53.396 --> 00:06:56.780
Linux in general has, actually,
it's not just a Kali thing.

135
00:06:56.780 --> 00:07:00.650
The three big commands that we'll use,
locate, which, and find.

136
00:07:00.650 --> 00:07:06.320
Each one has a specific use and purpose,
does things a little bit differently.

137
00:07:07.530 --> 00:07:13.660
Locate is a command I can use to search
through all of the files on my system.

138
00:07:13.660 --> 00:07:16.702
Remember, in Linux,
everything is really a file.

139
00:07:16.702 --> 00:07:19.511
And Locate is how I can
find where is a file is.

140
00:07:19.511 --> 00:07:24.690
If I need the path to that file,
I can use the Locate command.

141
00:07:24.690 --> 00:07:26.930
But locate relies on a database.

142
00:07:26.930 --> 00:07:29.870
It's a locally stored
database of all your files.

143
00:07:29.870 --> 00:07:33.580
And so you need to update that
database periodically, typically,

144
00:07:33.580 --> 00:07:37.650
every time you use,
they say run it every time you use Locate.

145
00:07:37.650 --> 00:07:40.930
If you haven't added a lot of files,
there's really no point in updating it.

146
00:07:40.930 --> 00:07:42.600
But it doesn't take that long.

147
00:07:42.600 --> 00:07:44.509
Let me just show you what I mean here.

148
00:07:44.509 --> 00:07:47.212
Let me open up a show.

149
00:07:47.212 --> 00:07:52.740
And let's update the database first.

150
00:07:52.740 --> 00:07:55.466
So we'll do update DB.

151
00:07:55.466 --> 00:07:56.093
And that's it.

152
00:07:56.093 --> 00:07:57.446
It's just update DB.

153
00:07:57.446 --> 00:07:58.084
You run it.

154
00:07:58.084 --> 00:07:58.952
It takes a minute.

155
00:07:58.952 --> 00:08:02.734
And it's indexing the system It's
adding entries into the database and

156
00:08:02.734 --> 00:08:04.970
it's gonna make everything searchable.

157
00:08:04.970 --> 00:08:10.135
So now if I wanna find something,
like let's locate fasttrack.

158
00:08:11.970 --> 00:08:13.380
>> That's fast crack?

159
00:08:13.380 --> 00:08:14.454
>> That's fasttrack.

160
00:08:14.454 --> 00:08:14.973
>> Fasttrack [LAUGH].

161
00:08:14.973 --> 00:08:16.676
>> [LAUGH] That's just, right?

162
00:08:16.676 --> 00:08:19.578
And there it is, so
you type and locate fasttrack.

163
00:08:19.578 --> 00:08:23.158
The text which is actually a wordlist,
that I use with some of the password

164
00:08:23.158 --> 00:08:26.010
crackers and things like that,
and there is my path to it.

165
00:08:26.010 --> 00:08:29.860
So now I know where on
the system that file is.

166
00:08:29.860 --> 00:08:30.794
>> Very good.

167
00:08:30.794 --> 00:08:34.836
>> So if I needed to type it in,
in a command when I'm running, John or

168
00:08:34.836 --> 00:08:39.088
something like that, And
then the command is I've got my input for

169
00:08:39.088 --> 00:08:42.130
my parameter for
wordlist that wanna load up.

170
00:08:42.130 --> 00:08:44.773
Well, I need to type in the path
to that wordlist, down my note.

171
00:08:44.773 --> 00:08:47.770
In fact, I can just copy it from there and
I don't even have to type it, right?

172
00:08:47.770 --> 00:08:49.400
Well, that's one thing we could do.

173
00:08:49.400 --> 00:08:52.120
But like I said,
you do need to update that database.

174
00:08:52.120 --> 00:08:54.240
Let's see if we can test that theory out.

175
00:08:54.240 --> 00:09:00.730
Let me make a file and I'm gonna call it,
just for zachfuzzyears.txt.

176
00:09:00.730 --> 00:09:02.772
>> Awesome.

177
00:09:02.772 --> 00:09:03.720
>> All right?

178
00:09:03.720 --> 00:09:06.485
And then we'll see,
we'll see where to locate this.

179
00:09:06.485 --> 00:09:12.477
Fuzzyears.txt.

180
00:09:12.477 --> 00:09:14.730
And notice I got no results.

181
00:09:14.730 --> 00:09:17.000
Wait a second, I just created that file.

182
00:09:17.000 --> 00:09:21.580
If I do an LS,
there is the file right there in the same

183
00:09:21.580 --> 00:09:26.140
directory that I'm currently at, and
you're telling me Locate can't find it?

184
00:09:26.140 --> 00:09:28.650
Because remember,
Locate is not searching the file system,

185
00:09:28.650 --> 00:09:30.330
it's looking in the database.

186
00:09:30.330 --> 00:09:34.790
And I created this file after
I've updated the database.

187
00:09:34.790 --> 00:09:38.560
So that's what I was trying to say
earlier, is when you run this command,

188
00:09:38.560 --> 00:09:41.840
it's a good idea to update
the database first.

189
00:09:41.840 --> 00:09:46.780
Let's try it, update Db and now,

190
00:09:46.780 --> 00:09:52.080
Locate fuzzyears.txt.

191
00:09:52.080 --> 00:09:54.924
And notice it finds it,
just fine, all right?

192
00:09:54.924 --> 00:09:59.279
So Locate, great command to use to find
the location of a file but it is dependent

193
00:09:59.279 --> 00:10:03.740
on the database and if you haven't
updated database, you won't find it.

194

00:22:41.580 --> 00:22:45.930
There's all kinds of parameters
that you can do with history.

431
00:22:45.930 --> 00:22:50.550
I'm just showing you a couple
of the most commonly used ones.

432
00:22:50.550 --> 00:22:54.336
So now that I have cleared my history,
but then I did type man history,

433
00:22:54.336 --> 00:22:56.466
let's see what my history looks like.

434
00:22:58.481 --> 00:23:02.039
It looks likes I've only got two
entries in there, man-history and

435
00:23:02.039 --> 00:23:04.386
the command I just typed, history, right?

436
00:23:04.386 --> 00:23:07.070
So history -c to clear your history.

437
00:23:07.070 --> 00:23:09.020
>> Like it never even happened.

438
00:23:10.040 --> 00:23:12.970
So Kali Linux, and
this is navigating Kali.

439
00:23:12.970 --> 00:23:15.400
And wonderful information.

440
00:23:15.400 --> 00:23:18.735
Anything else you want to leave
us with before we say goodbye?

441
00:23:18.735 --> 00:23:22.653
>> As we progress I'm sure we'll throw
some more things in there about navigating

442
00:23:22.653 --> 00:23:23.774
and things like that.

443
00:23:23.774 --> 00:23:26.630
But it's about time to start
playing with some tools

444
00:23:26.630 --> 00:23:27.860
>> Yeah, that'd be a lot of fun.

445
00:23:27.860 --> 00:23:29.150
So, Kali Linux.

446
00:23:29.150 --> 00:23:30.800
Lot of video in this series.

447
00:23:30.800 --> 00:23:33.710
Make sure you see all the videos,
you'll be very glad you did.

448

Mike, excellent job.

449
00:23:35.166 --> 00:23:37.133
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

450
00:23:37.133 --> 00:23:40.116
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

451
00:23:40.116 --> 00:23:41.382
I am Zach Memos.

452
00:23:41.382 --> 00:23:42.165
>> And I am Mike Rodrick.

454

00:23:50.834 --> 00:23:55.259

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss and use netcat, one of the fundamental tools in Kali Linux.   Mike describes briefly it’s history and versatility as a tool.   He demonstrates the power of netcat to run a banner grab and tcp connections. He begins to describe the bind shell and reverse shell exploit.
episodes.title: Netcat Basics
episodes.transcript:

a guy named only known or

>> Not the hobbit but just Hobbit.

A brilliant gentleman, or

But the developer's name was Hobbit.

He said I don't want to mess with GNU,

I don't want to mess with any

Use it as it's free.

Do whatever you want with it

I don't care.

Here it is for the world to enjoy.

So kudos to Hobbit for

Some of the things we might use it for,

UDP connection, or
UDP connection between two machines.

I think, well, why?

So we can do all kinds of things.

Could be just a simple chat between two

the machine you're trying to pen

Port forwarding, you can do port
forwarding It can work as a proxy,

it´s just very very flexible.

80

It can be a simple web server and

81
00:03:55.190 --> 00:03:57.900
Fantastic, use this all

You just browse to this website,

And it makes a great back door.

85

It´s a very common utility

So it's a very very powerful tool.

89

because we're gonna take a look

00:04:28.581 --> 00:04:33.001
Not so much the background, but kind of

pick a tool to use, when would I go, all

00:04:37.421 --> 00:04:41.587
that I go, all right, I need to jump

94
00:04:41.587 --> 00:04:42.840
>> That's a great question.

95
00:04:42.840 --> 00:04:45.780
During the initial phases,
if we talk about penetration testing,

we talk about the phases,
in that early phase, the very first one,

00:04:48.620 --> 00:04:54.130
reconnaissance Netcat is gonna be a go-to

98
00:04:54.130 --> 00:04:58.270
And again, there are other tools that
we can do this with, but sometimes you

99

wanna have more than one choice, and
this one's a very very simple one to do.

100
00:05:02.220 --> 00:05:04.690
We'll take a look at banner

101
00:05:04.690 --> 00:05:07.870
So banner grabbing would be one of
the big reasons that it's a go-to guy for

00:05:07.870 --> 00:05:10.880
me, and then just getting a reverse shell.

00:05:10.880 --> 00:05:15.230
After, when we started getting into

If I need a reverse shell,

Because it's small, it's easy to

And for transferring files,

Let's say I'm attacking a Windows machine,

Netcat's a very easy way

You'll find that once you get familiar

00:05:42.360 --> 00:05:43.470
It really is.

112
00:05:43.470 --> 00:05:45.210
>> All right, so Mike, let's go ahead and

00:05:46.980 --> 00:05:49.240
We wanna start off with that

00:05:49.240 --> 00:05:49.750
>> I think so.

00:05:49.750 --> 00:05:52.530
So let's take a look at my screen here,
and

00:05:52.530 --> 00:05:55.470
I've just got my Kali Linux box opened up.

00:05:55.470 --> 00:05:58.870
I've also got meta exploitable running,

00:05:58.870 --> 00:06:03.800
at so if I If I wanna do, well first

Alright?

00:06:14.390 --> 00:06:18.326
But here the -h gives me some simple help.

00:06:18.326 --> 00:06:20.851
And I can see, connect to somewhere.

00:06:20.851 --> 00:06:25.046
NC for Netcat,
you can actually type netcat or NC.

00:06:25.046 --> 00:06:28.733
Usually most Linux just distros there is
actually a couple different versions of

00:06:28.733 --> 00:06:31.890
Netcat, there is the original

00:06:31.890 --> 00:06:36.690
there is a GNU license netcat There's

A lot of it depends on

And in the end, It doesn't matter so

00:06:56.482 --> 00:07:00.310
The NCAT, the one from Nmap is

the way the switches work, but
the N Cat and C pretty much are the same.

00:07:05.170 --> 00:07:08.405
Like in Kali, it's just alias to
whether you type N cat or not,

00:07:08.405 --> 00:07:14.150
here' I can show you if I type man NC,

141
00:07:14.150 --> 00:07:16.600
The TCPIP Swiss army knife.

00:07:16.600 --> 00:07:23.820
If I quit out of that, and I do man

00:07:23.820 --> 00:07:25.720
So it's not two different

144
00:07:25.720 --> 00:07:29.230

00:07:29.230 --> 00:07:30.870

00:07:30.870 --> 00:07:34.390
There are a lot of them, but

00:07:34.390 --> 00:07:39.010

148
00:07:39.010 --> 00:07:42.325
It removes any issues I might

149

I love the v switch, the verbose,

150
00:07:47.495 --> 00:07:50.211
Don't hide anything,
show me what's going on.

151
00:07:50.211 --> 00:07:53.665
The l switch is for listen mode.

152
00:07:53.665 --> 00:07:57.507
Netcat works as both the client And
the sever, all right?

153
00:07:57.507 --> 00:07:59.291
You're going to establish a connection,

154
00:07:59.291 --> 00:08:02.520

155
00:08:02.520 --> 00:08:06.810
It opens up a port, it's actively

156
00:08:06.810 --> 00:08:10.080
The client side of things would
be what connects to the server.

157
00:08:10.080 --> 00:08:11.820
Now it could be on either end, right?

158
00:08:11.820 --> 00:08:14.860
I might be connecting,
I might be running the client locally,

159
00:08:14.860 --> 00:08:17.350

a compromised machine.

160
00:08:17.350 --> 00:08:21.710
Or it could be the other way around,
where I'm running a server.

161
00:08:21.710 --> 00:08:24.660
I've compromised a machine and
I connected back to my server.

162
00:08:24.660 --> 00:08:27.850
So, there's no the server's always on this
end, the client's always on that end, or

163
00:08:27.850 --> 00:08:29.840
anything like that, but
it can flip back and forth.

164
00:08:29.840 --> 00:08:32.560
And the L is what puts me
in that server mode, right?

165
00:08:32.560 --> 00:08:35.600
This is, listen,
I'm gonna establish a port number and

166
00:08:35.600 --> 00:08:38.050
I'm gonna listen for
inbound connections on that.

167
00:08:38.050 --> 00:08:40.240
So N, V, L, and

168
00:08:40.240 --> 00:08:45.630
then P to specify the actual port number
that you're gonna listen on, all right?

169
00:08:45.630 --> 00:08:49.565
So, those are the biggest ones,
E is another one we'll end up using today.

170
00:08:49.565 --> 00:08:55.730
A program to execute after connect,
you notice it says dangerous, and it is.

171
00:08:55.730 --> 00:08:58.349
That's how we do our shells,
our BI shells and our reverse shells.

172
00:08:59.510 --> 00:09:01.500
All right, so a few of the basic switches.

173
00:09:01.500 --> 00:09:05.380
Now, Ronnie, I think we can get into
actually doing some banner grabbing.

174
00:09:05.380 --> 00:09:09.122
So NC, Netcat or NC,
either one would work,

175
00:09:09.122 --> 00:09:12.473
NC a little bit shorter, and then -NV.

176
00:09:12.473 --> 00:09:15.393
We just talked about that,
N being my No DNS, or

177
00:09:15.393 --> 00:09:20.299
numbers only, whichever way you wanna
remember it, and then V being verbose.

178
00:09:20.299 --> 00:09:22.000
All right, so -NV.

179
00:09:22.000 --> 00:09:25.918
You can do these separately
like I can do it nc -n -v.

180
00:09:25.918 --> 00:09:30.920
But you could also combine them
just a -nv makes it a lot easier

181
00:09:30.920 --> 00:09:34.400
to type the IP address that
you're trying to connect to.

182
00:09:34.400 --> 00:09:35.420
And this is gonna be 1.136.

183
00:09:35.420 --> 00:09:39.830
And then the port number that I
wanna do the banner grabbing on.

184
00:09:41.080 --> 00:09:42.890
All right, and there we go.

185
00:09:42.890 --> 00:09:46.860
And if you can that,
I can see that I've connected,

186
00:09:46.860 --> 00:09:51.200
that's gonna fail the connections
actually not going to be established.

187
00:09:51.200 --> 00:09:55.420
But that's not what I'm trying to do,
I am successfully connecting to that port.

188
00:09:55.420 --> 00:09:57.090
That tells me that port is open.

189
00:09:57.090 --> 00:10:01.020
Probably already knew this because we
ran in map of some of the port scanning

190
00:10:01.020 --> 00:10:02.970
to determine that port was open,
but maybe I didn't.

191
00:10:02.970 --> 00:10:06.160
Maybe I was just doing a shot
in the dark with netcap.

192
00:10:06.160 --> 00:10:08.080
So it does tell me hey, the port is open.

193
00:10:08.080 --> 00:10:11.350
It tells me that it thinks it's
running that SSH service and

194
00:10:11.350 --> 00:10:14.030
it shows me The banner,
I should say thing.

195
00:10:14.030 --> 00:10:14.590
So it knows,

196
00:10:14.590 --> 00:10:20.950
it sees the information that that SSH
server on that machine is spitting out.

197
00:10:20.950 --> 00:10:22.190
So we get a couple things out of this.

198
00:10:22.190 --> 00:10:26.140
So even though it doesn't actually

00:22:07.790 --> 00:22:12.830

our bash shell in the case of Linux,

407
00:22:12.830 --> 00:22:17.440
typically your bash shell,
to a port to a listener.

408
00:22:17.440 --> 00:22:22.380
And then, whoever connects to
that port will be presented

409
00:22:22.380 --> 00:22:27.030
with that bind shell and they can

00:22:27.030 --> 00:22:31.468
If it's from a Windows machine

411
00:22:31.468 --> 00:22:35.200
Our shell on Windows,
we'd be binding that to a listening port.

00:22:35.200 --> 00:22:39.629
And then anybody that connects to that
port would then be able to run commands

413
00:22:39.629 --> 00:22:43.310

or that DOS prompt, all right?

414
00:22:43.310 --> 00:22:46.430
That's really what we
mean by a bind shell.

00:22:46.430 --> 00:22:49.460
Bind shells work great internally.

00:22:49.460 --> 00:22:53.145
The things is, you've got to be

00:23:12.801 --> 00:23:15.354

let's say I need Ronnie's help.

00:23:34.020 --> 00:23:38.670
But I can't bind my shell to
my private IP address and

429
00:23:38.670 --> 00:23:40.130
expect Ronnie to connect to it.

430
00:23:40.130 --> 00:23:42.592
What I can do is have Ronnie
set up a listener and

431
00:23:42.592 --> 00:23:46.696
I can send my shell to Ronnie, to his
listener, and then the return traffic of

432
00:23:46.696 --> 00:23:50.768
course it's gonna be net to net,
everything is going to work out just fine.

433
00:23:50.768 --> 00:23:54.498
That's what's called a reverse shell,
and I know that's a tricky concept to

434
00:23:54.498 --> 00:23:56.659
understand, so
I did make up some drawings.

435
00:23:56.659 --> 00:24:01.395
That we'll take a look at before we
actually get into trying to set this

436
00:24:01.395 --> 00:24:02.127
thing up.

437
00:24:02.127 --> 00:24:06.730
So here's an example of a buying
shell between a couple of machines.

438
00:24:07.860 --> 00:24:10.310
I've got Alice and Bob,
good old A and B, right?

439
00:24:10.310 --> 00:24:13.090
Alice and Bob,
I made Alice a Linux machine.

440
00:24:13.090 --> 00:24:17.580
I've got Bob on a Windows machine
[COUGH] and let's say that Bob you know,

441
00:24:17.580 --> 00:24:21.900
wants Alice to connect to
his machine to help him out.

442
00:24:21.900 --> 00:24:24.590
Well we'll use good, or white hat,

443
00:24:24.590 --> 00:24:27.660
scenarios as we talk about this,
all right.

444
00:24:27.660 --> 00:24:30.680
So what Bob is gonna do is say hey Alice,

445
00:24:30.680 --> 00:24:33.690
I need your help,
can you connect to my machine?

446
00:24:33.690 --> 00:24:37.544
I'm gonna set up listener, he'll write
Mcat NVLP, right there's my listener,

447
00:24:37.544 --> 00:24:38.767
my port number 9999.

448
00:24:38.767 --> 00:24:43.689
And he's gonna use that dash e,
remember when we looked at

449
00:24:43.689 --> 00:24:48.562
that help file the dash e was
executed program CMD.exc.

450
00:24:48.562 --> 00:24:50.100
So basically what he's doing is saying,

451
00:24:50.100 --> 00:24:54.065
hey machine I want you to
listen on port 9999, and

452
00:24:54.065 --> 00:24:57.419
when somebody connects I want you to
present them with a command problem.

453
00:24:58.520 --> 00:25:03.640
Alice then, from her machine,
is able to type in NC -nv,

454
00:25:03.640 --> 00:25:06.740
Bob's IP address, and the port number.

455
00:25:06.740 --> 00:25:09.580
And it should send her
over a command prompt.

456
00:25:09.580 --> 00:25:11.530
She'll be sitting there staring at C:.

457
00:25:11.530 --> 00:25:14.132
On her Linux machine,
she will have a C:, right?

458
00:25:14.132 --> 00:25:15.180
And I'll show you.

459
00:25:15.180 --> 00:25:17.050
We'll do this here in a minute.

460
00:25:17.050 --> 00:25:20.850
The opposite would just be
instead of binding cmd.exe,

461
00:25:20.850 --> 00:25:23.990
you'd be binding your shell,
in this case, bin bash.

462
00:25:23.990 --> 00:25:25.020
So she runs the same command.

463
00:25:25.020 --> 00:25:28.020
And let's say again, reverse the scenario.

464
00:25:28.020 --> 00:25:32.540
Alice wants Bob to connect remotely
to her machine to help her out.

465
00:25:32.540 --> 00:25:37.210
So she's gonna run net cat NVLP
999 dash e slash bin slash bash.

466
00:25:38.670 --> 00:25:43.050
I hope then Bob runs his net cat, the
client end connects to her IP address port

467
00:25:43.050 --> 00:25:49.200
number and it's gonna present her with
a shell, with a bash shell, right?

468
00:25:49.200 --> 00:25:52.410
So in this case these
are both what's called

469
00:25:52.410 --> 00:25:56.560
binding a shell cuz you're
binding a shell to.

470
00:25:56.560 --> 00:25:57.400
And let me see if Ronnie.

471
00:25:57.400 --> 00:26:01.632
I'm gonna try the handy
dandy presentation mode.

472
00:26:01.632 --> 00:26:03.970
And I didn't get my pencil.

473
00:26:03.970 --> 00:26:06.810
Still new at the presentation
mode on our drawing tools.

474
00:26:06.810 --> 00:26:10.150
So let's kill that.

475
00:26:10.150 --> 00:26:11.580
So where was I going with that.

476
00:26:11.580 --> 00:26:16.560
So in this case,
Bob is binding cmd.exe to a port number.

477
00:26:17.660 --> 00:26:20.990
But that address has to be reachable,
right?

478
00:26:20.990 --> 00:26:22.820
Alice has to connect to that IP address.

479
00:26:22.820 --> 00:26:25.190
In this case they're on the same network.

480
00:26:25.190 --> 00:26:26.880
Same thing with Alice the other way.

481
00:26:26.880 --> 00:26:29.650
Bob's connecting to an internal private
address everything works just fine.

482
00:26:30.670 --> 00:26:34.540
If Bob was denied,
let's pretend Bob had a public IP address.

483
00:26:34.540 --> 00:26:38.550
So I couldn't just have Bob
connect to my machine, actually,

484
00:26:38.550 --> 00:26:40.200
it's this one over here.

485
00:26:40.200 --> 00:26:43.420
I can't just have Bob bind a shell.

486
00:26:43.420 --> 00:26:50.225
So, what I'm going to do,
is have Alice set up the listener, right?

487
00:26:50.225 --> 00:26:55.200
Cuz if Bob needs help, I want Alice to
have a command prompt on Bob's machine,

488
00:26:55.200 --> 00:26:56.890
Instead of starting with Bob and

489
00:26:56.890 --> 00:26:59.150
setting up a server,
cuz Bob´s the one that needs help, right?

490
00:26:59.150 --> 00:27:03.398
In this scenario, Bob needed help,
Bob ran the server.

491
00:27:03.398 --> 00:27:08.998
For the reverse shell Bob needs help,
Alice is, I´m sorry, did I do that right?

492
00:27:08.998 --> 00:27:10.310
I hit the wrong tab..

493
00:27:10.310 --> 00:27:13.390
Alice is gonna set up the server,
NC NvLP 999.

494
00:27:13.390 --> 00:27:19.610
And then Bob is going to forward his
command prompt to that listener.

495
00:27:20.700 --> 00:27:24.340
So in the end, kind of the same thing, but

496
00:27:24.340 --> 00:27:29.690
we're going about it in a different
direction, hence the name reverse shell.

497
00:27:29.690 --> 00:27:33.560
Rather than have Bob bind a shell to
a port number that we connect to,

498
00:27:33.560 --> 00:27:37.470
we're gonna have Bob send the shell
to a port number we're listening on.

499
00:27:37.470 --> 00:27:41.140
All right and
this is the most common attack scenario.

500
00:27:41.140 --> 00:27:42.550
This is what the bad guys are doing.

501
00:27:42.550 --> 00:27:47.000
This is what we're doing as pin testers,
is we're doing something like this.

502
00:27:47.000 --> 00:27:51.930
The machine I wanna compromise is
Bob's Window's Machine, all right.

503
00:27:51.930 --> 00:27:56.310
So what I'm gonna do is, I'm gonna set
up a listener on my attack machine.

504
00:27:56.310 --> 00:27:59.080
And then I'm gonna package up some code,

505
00:27:59.080 --> 00:28:03.140
take advantage of some exploit on his
system that I found he's running an old

506
00:28:03.140 --> 00:28:08.110
version of some application as a buffer
overflow issue or something like that and

507
00:28:08.110 --> 00:28:14.210
I'm gonna package all the net cat
reverse shell code in that exploit.

508
00:28:14.210 --> 00:28:18.980
And so when I exploit Bob's
machine It executes this command

509
00:28:18.980 --> 00:28:23.070
which connects back to my attack
machine and presents me with a shell.

510
00:28:23.070 --> 00:28:27.310
Typically running at system
with system level access.

511
00:28:27.310 --> 00:28:29.660
That's the whole idea
behind a reverse shell.

512
00:28:29.660 --> 00:28:32.560
I can't get them to set
up a bind to bind their

513
00:28:32.560 --> 00:28:34.500
shell to a port that I can connect to.

514
00:28:34.500 --> 00:28:37.130
But I can take advantage of an exploit,

515
00:28:37.130 --> 00:28:40.590
have it send a shell back
to my listening port.

516
00:28:40.590 --> 00:28:42.590
And the reverse would be
true if we wanted to do it.

517
00:28:42.590 --> 00:28:48.160
If we were either Bob,
Alice needed help, right?

518
00:28:48.160 --> 00:28:51.544
We could say, all right,
Bob set up a listener on port 9999.

519
00:28:51.544 --> 00:28:53.190
All right, Alice.

520
00:28:53.190 --> 00:28:58.270
I've got a listener set up on port 9999,
send me your shell She can run

521
00:28:58.270 --> 00:29:04.540
N get NV port number E bin bash, which
will then push that shell out to Bob.

522
00:29:04.540 --> 00:29:07.860
In the attack scenario, now we're
attacking from the windows box, and

523
00:29:07.860 --> 00:29:10.200
we're trying to compromise the Calley box.

524
00:29:10.200 --> 00:29:13.260
So we set up a listener on port 9999.

525
00:29:13.260 --> 00:29:17.480
I package up some code that's gonna
take advantage of an exploit.

526
00:29:17.480 --> 00:29:20.340
I run that on Alice's
machine In that exploit,

527
00:29:20.340 --> 00:29:25.260
it executes this reverse shell, and
sends a shell back to me, the attacker.

528
00:29:25.260 --> 00:29:27.760
And i now have system
access to that machine.

529
00:29:27.760 --> 00:29:32.740
So there's the concept behind both
a bind shell and a reverse shell.

530
00:29:32.740 --> 00:29:33.780
>> All right, Mike.

531
00:29:33.780 --> 00:29:37.800
This actually is very exciting because
it actually does show the power of what

532
00:29:37.800 --> 00:29:40.130
Mcat or Netcat can do for us.

533
00:29:40.130 --> 00:29:43.850
But we do also want to see it in action
but we're going to save that for

534
00:29:43.850 --> 00:29:46.270
a part 2 one he netcap basics.

535
00:29:46.270 --> 00:29:49.520
So remember what you actually saw here
of course are some of the basic tools

536
00:29:49.520 --> 00:29:50.770
that we can also or

537
00:29:50.770 --> 00:29:54.510
some of the basic exploits that we
can actually carry out with netcap.

538
00:29:54.510 --> 00:29:57.370
But there is more to come,

Let's go ahead and sign off then.

For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue demonstrating the “swiss army knife of hacking tools.”  Mike demonstrates it’s ability to set up a connection with ease that allows the user to send commands across this connection.  He also shows how files can be transferred, regardless of whether they’re executable files or just a simple text file.  Lastly, he show the simple nature of using nCAT ( Nmap’s version of netcat) to create an encrypted connection.
episodes.title: Netcat Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike dive into another tool in Kali: Wireshark.  Mike describes the purpose and the basic filtering methodology of wireshark.  He distinguishes using capture and display filter.
episodes.title: Wireshark Basics

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.825
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.825 --> 00:00:02.544
I'm your host [INAUDIBLE].

3

[MUSIC]

>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5

>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.690 --> 00:00:17.720
You're watching the Kali Linux Show.

7
00:00:17.720 --> 00:00:19.330
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

8
00:00:19.330 --> 00:00:23.340
today we're actually taking
a look at some Wireshark basics.

9
00:00:23.340 --> 00:00:25.924
And here to help guide us through
this is going to be well Mr.

00:00:25.924 --> 00:00:28.330
Security himself, Mr. Mike Roderick.

11

12
00:00:29.350 --> 00:00:32.840
>> Hey Ronnie thanks I don't know about
all that but I am glad to be here.

13
00:00:32.840 --> 00:00:35.310
Today we are continuing on.

14

We've been looking at some of
the fundamental, or basic,

15
00:00:38.460 --> 00:00:42.080
tools that we need to be familiar with
as we get our feet wet with Kali Linux.

16
00:00:42.080 --> 00:00:44.590
And we prepare our selves
to do security work,

17
00:00:44.590 --> 00:00:47.520
penetration testing,
whatever the case may be.

18
00:00:47.520 --> 00:00:49.960
So far, I think we've looked at Netcat,

19
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:53.450
which is a tool we used
to create those TCP and

20
00:00:53.450 --> 00:00:57.255
UDP connections fundamental foundational
knowledge that we have to have.

21
00:00:57.255 --> 00:01:01.480
Cuz as we get more advanced and
as we progress into these other tools, and

22
00:01:01.480 --> 00:01:07.320
we start to actually perform a task or
exploits against machines.

23
00:01:07.320 --> 00:01:10.860
These basic tools are what we
need to make all that work.

24
00:01:10.860 --> 00:01:14.370
I need to establish a connection and
try to get a file over there,

25
00:01:14.370 --> 00:01:16.400
I found a port that's open and writable.

26
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:17.840
How do you find that port?

27
00:01:17.840 --> 00:01:20.900
You're using NMAP and,
you're using things like packet capture.

28
00:01:20.900 --> 00:01:24.330
So again,
hitting these foundational tools first.

29
00:01:24.330 --> 00:01:27.230
And, the one we're gonna
look at today is Wireshark.

30
00:01:27.230 --> 00:01:31.720
Wireshark is what we call
a packet capture utility.

31
00:01:31.720 --> 00:01:33.360
It captures packets, right?

32
00:01:33.360 --> 00:01:38.140
Little packets that are travelling across
the wire but it captures the raw package.

33
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:43.090
It allows me to monitor the traffic
that's going across the wire.

34
00:01:43.090 --> 00:01:48.040
And you might hear it like a packet
capture utility, a network sniffer.

35
00:01:48.040 --> 00:01:49.980
Ronnie, I think you had said,
what'd you say they were?

36
00:01:49.980 --> 00:01:53.880
>> Sometimes you'll also hear
the term protocol analyzer as well.

37
00:01:53.880 --> 00:01:56.750
All these tools really do
help us essentially to, well,

38
00:01:56.750 --> 00:02:00.070
get the packets that we really
want to be able to see it do.

39
00:02:00.070 --> 00:02:02.800
Now Mike when we talk about
especially like Wireshark.

40
00:02:02.800 --> 00:02:07.430
Wireshark's versatility is kind of a big
one, and its popularity as well, right?

41
00:02:07.430 --> 00:02:11.630
>> It is, Wireshark has been around for
a while it used to be known as Ethereal or

Ethereal depending on how
people wanted to say that.

43
00:02:14.430 --> 00:02:17.060
They had a split in the company and
this that and the other.

44
00:02:17.060 --> 00:02:20.700
But we are left with Wireshark,
same program, different name.

45
00:02:20.700 --> 00:02:24.225
So it's been around for a long time and
that means the kinks have been worked out,

46
00:02:24.225 --> 00:02:29.760
it's a very polished,
powerful program to do packet capture.

47
00:02:29.760 --> 00:02:31.280
Now there's others out there, but

48
00:02:31.280 --> 00:02:34.110
we are focusing here on
what we have here in Kali.

49
00:02:34.110 --> 00:02:38.020
Wireshark is probably the premier
packet capture utility.

50
00:02:38.020 --> 00:02:39.070
And with this we can again,

51
00:02:39.070 --> 00:02:43.050
we can look at traffic we can see what's
happening as we do our ping sweeps.

52
00:02:43.050 --> 00:02:46.670
Or as we try to brute force a port or
whatever the case may be.

53
00:02:46.670 --> 00:02:49.850
Or like Ronnie said you're also
known as protocol analyzers.

54
00:02:49.850 --> 00:02:52.450
Wanna see what protocols
are traveling across my network,

55
00:02:52.450 --> 00:02:54.800
see what kind of information
I can get out of there.

56
00:02:54.800 --> 00:02:58.150
Remember, if they're using
plain text protocols,

57
00:02:58.150 --> 00:03:01.110
everything that's in that packet,
payload wise, header wis.

58
00:03:01.110 --> 00:03:05.500
All of that is gonna be visible within
Wireshark, cuz it's not encrypted right?

59
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:08.550
>> Now Mike as you say that and
we get started here.

60
00:03:08.550 --> 00:03:12.880
One of the things if you're really new
at working with something like Wireshark

61

is this thinking that you're just gonna
turn it on and it's just going to work.

62
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:20.840
Right out of the box, it's gonna capture
every bit of graphic on your network.

63
00:03:20.840 --> 00:03:22.490
But because we're on a switch network,

64
00:03:22.490 --> 00:03:26.450
Mike, is there some setting I need
to actually think about having on?

65
00:03:26.450 --> 00:03:31.420
>> There is but it's not so much, I mean
Wireshark will turn your network adapter

66
00:03:31.420 --> 00:03:34.220
into what's known as promiscuous
mode if it's available.

67
00:03:34.220 --> 00:03:37.580
If your network adapter supports that,
most modern network adapters

68
00:03:37.580 --> 00:03:40.430
depending on the chips that
are gonna support promiscuous mode.

69
00:03:40.430 --> 00:03:45.560
Because we know normally the way your PC
works is that it has an IP address and

70
00:03:45.560 --> 00:03:47.460
a MAC address associated with it.

71
00:03:47.460 --> 00:03:51.050
And as it sees traffic going across the
network, if that's not it's MAC address.

72
00:03:51.050 --> 00:03:52.260
If it's not my own MAC address,

73
00:03:52.260 --> 00:03:55.530
if I was the network adapter,
I would ignore those, right?

74
00:03:55.530 --> 00:03:58.310
Well we want to see more than just
the traffic that's just in our computer.

75
00:03:58.310 --> 00:04:00.790
I want to see that server
talking to Ronnie's client.

76
00:04:00.790 --> 00:04:02.990
But that traffic's not destined for me, so

77
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:05.800
my network therefore would
normally drop that stuff.

78
00:04:05.800 --> 00:04:09.444
Wireshark will kick you over into
promiscuous mode which just capture all

79

the traffic that's travelling
across the network.

80
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:15.893
Now that doesn't solve the problem with
switched Ethernet which most modern

81
00:04:15.893 --> 00:04:18.124
networks are going to
be switched Ethernet.

82
00:04:18.124 --> 00:04:21.920
Where you have a point to point
connection between you and the switch.

83
00:04:21.920 --> 00:04:27.040
The switch is only allowing traffic out
that port that's destined for your node.

84
00:04:27.040 --> 00:04:29.030
That's out there on the end of that port,
right?

85
00:04:29.030 --> 00:04:32.240
So even if I'm in promiscuous mode,
I'm saying capture everything.

86
00:04:32.240 --> 00:04:35.560
I'm still only seeing because what
the switch is doing in front of me,

87
00:04:35.560 --> 00:04:37.340
I'm still not seeing all that traffic.

88
00:04:37.340 --> 00:04:39.430
So if you want to monitor
traffic on the network,

89
00:04:39.430 --> 00:04:43.870
you need to get into a place where you
can actually see that traffic going by.

90
00:04:43.870 --> 00:04:47.530
And our little test environments,
we're on a small virtual network and

91
00:04:47.530 --> 00:04:51.830
we can practice and
play with these tools and it works great.

92
00:04:51.830 --> 00:04:56.300
In the real world,
your switch might have a monitor port, or

93
00:04:56.300 --> 00:04:58.370
what do they call it a mirror port or
something like that.

94
00:04:58.370 --> 00:04:59.800
Ronnie's my switch guy.

95
00:04:59.800 --> 00:05:01.360
>> Yeah,
it's either gonna be port mirroring,

96
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:03.860
span is sometimes how you hear this idea.

97
00:05:03.860 --> 00:05:04.960
Port mirroring of some sort or

98
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:08.110
if you have a network tap a little
bit more expensive of a device.

99
00:05:08.110 --> 00:05:11.130
But those are devices that really do
allow you to capture everything that's

100
00:05:11.130 --> 00:05:12.080
going across it.

101
00:05:12.080 --> 00:05:15.060
Whereas the port marin just says take
all of the traffic from the ports

102
00:05:15.060 --> 00:05:15.930
you want to see.

103
00:05:15.930 --> 00:05:18.230
Send me this one port,
the one that I'm running Wireshark on,

104
00:05:18.230 --> 00:05:20.820
and that's normally how we also
can get the other traffic.

105
00:05:20.820 --> 00:05:23.180
>> Yeah so, that's something
that if it's your network and

106
00:05:23.180 --> 00:05:25.770
you're part of the security
team you can find out.

107
00:05:25.770 --> 00:05:28.750
Is there a port that we can
monitor all traffic on,

108
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:31.790
is there a way I can get all that
traffic routed out to my port?

109
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:36.660
If you're doing a pen test then that
becomes part of the challenge, right?

110
00:05:36.660 --> 00:05:37.780
I've gotta be able to get in there.

111
00:05:37.780 --> 00:05:40.660
And this is why we
compromise a machine and

112
00:05:40.660 --> 00:05:44.010
then we load tools on that machine to
then further investigate the network.

113
00:05:44.010 --> 00:05:46.880
To see what nodes that it's talking to,
things like that.

114
00:05:46.880 --> 00:05:49.530
So keep that in mind as you're
working with Wireshark.

115
00:05:49.530 --> 00:05:51.630
You're like,
why am I not seeing all the traffic?

116
00:05:51.630 --> 00:05:55.050
It very well could be that you're
in a switched Ethernet environment.

117
00:05:55.050 --> 00:05:57.120
All right, so
let's take a look at Wireshark.

118
00:05:57.120 --> 00:06:02.310
Couple of things, Wireshark runs on
Windows, Linux, Mac, it runs on anything.

119
00:06:02.310 --> 00:06:04.510
You will need certain libraries.

120
00:06:04.510 --> 00:06:06.820
There's a WinPcap for Windows.

121
00:06:06.820 --> 00:06:09.089
For Kali, for Linux, it's Libpcap.

122
00:06:10.190 --> 00:06:13.550
Typically when you install WirsShark,
it's going to prompt you to download that.

123
00:06:13.550 --> 00:06:17.860
And that's what lets your operating
system work with the raw packets.

124
00:06:17.860 --> 00:06:19.620
Because remember, these packets,
what we're seeing,

125
00:06:19.620 --> 00:06:22.320
they're going down the good OSI model.

126
00:06:22.320 --> 00:06:27.190
And they're getting packaged up and
formatted to be transmitted on the wire or

127
00:06:27.190 --> 00:06:28.140
wireless.

128
00:06:28.140 --> 00:06:30.920
And now they're being transmitted,
and you're capturing them.

129
00:06:30.920 --> 00:06:35.680
They're not going back up the OSI model
to be interpreted, pulled back apart, and

130
00:06:35.680 --> 00:06:37.050
broken into.

131
00:06:37.050 --> 00:06:39.723
Human readable, or application readable,
anything like that,

132
00:06:39.723 --> 00:06:41.167
you're looking at the wrong data.

133
00:06:41.167 --> 00:06:43.750
So, there's libpcap, and for Windows,

134
00:06:43.750 --> 00:06:47.210
WinPcap is what allows me to
work with those raw packets.

135
00:06:48.880 --> 00:06:52.450
So let's fire up Wireshark and Kali
you can go either go to a terminal and

136
00:06:52.450 --> 00:06:56.140
type Wireshark or you could go down
to like stiffing and spoofing.

137
00:06:56.140 --> 00:06:58.938
You guys know you can go many different
ways to get to the application.

138
00:06:58.938 --> 00:07:01.800
But here's Wireshark,
now the first time you fire it up,

139
00:07:01.800 --> 00:07:04.560
if you're logged on as root,
you'll probably get this error.

140
00:07:04.560 --> 00:07:06.525
In fact, every time you fire it up.

141
00:07:06.525 --> 00:07:08.180
>> [LAUGH]
>> You'll get this error, and

142
00:07:08.180 --> 00:07:11.910
this is because Lua is
Wireshark's scripting language.

143
00:07:11.910 --> 00:07:15.090
And with that language you
can really do some damage.

144
00:07:15.090 --> 00:07:19.890
And if you're running as root the damage
could be to your system, could be bad.

145
00:07:19.890 --> 00:07:24.360
So they're saying, hey, we're gonna block
this since we see you're logged on as

146
00:07:24.360 --> 00:07:27.040
the root or as you're super user.

147
00:07:27.040 --> 00:07:31.110
Just click OK, unless you need scripts,
you have created a separate account

148
00:07:31.110 --> 00:07:34.440
that's not root and then you can
work with the scripting language.

149
00:07:34.440 --> 00:07:37.680
There are ways you can disable that and
allow those scripts to work

150
00:07:37.680 --> 00:07:41.060
even when you're logged in as root,
that's a risk you take, right?

151
00:07:41.060 --> 00:07:42.640
As long as you know what you
are doing you should be good,

152
00:07:42.640 --> 00:07:45.460
it's just kind of trying to
protect us from ourselves.

153
00:07:45.460 --> 00:07:48.474
You can also comment out that
message in the config file.

154
00:07:48.474 --> 00:07:51.840
So you log on as root but you don't
care because you never run scripts.

155
00:07:51.840 --> 00:07:53.630
You just get tired of seeing that message.

156
00:07:53.630 --> 00:07:56.376
Go comment that out in the config file.

157
00:07:56.376 --> 00:07:58.044
Here's Wireshark, and

158
00:07:58.044 --> 00:08:03.216
the first thing we have to do is to tell
it what interface we want to capture on.

159
00:08:03.216 --> 00:08:05.412
I've got several network, I have two.

160
00:08:05.412 --> 00:08:07.125
Network adapters in here.

161
00:08:07.125 --> 00:08:11.804
It also sees things like my loop back,
if I had a USB network adapters they

162
00:08:11.804 --> 00:08:16.880
would show up in here, Bluetooth
network adapters would show up in here.

163
00:08:16.880 --> 00:08:19.890
So this will show you the different
adapters you have available.

164
00:08:19.890 --> 00:08:24.620
And this little bar,
this little kind of spark line or

165
00:08:24.620 --> 00:08:27.610
mini line graph here,
is showing me the activity.

166
00:08:27.610 --> 00:08:30.100
So it's saying, hey,
there is activity on this.

167
00:08:30.100 --> 00:08:31.014
This one, there is no activity.

168
00:08:31.014 --> 00:08:36.330
Probably not a good one to choose, if I am
trying to figure out what network adapter.

169
00:08:36.330 --> 00:08:37.140
I am going to go ahead.

170
00:08:37.140 --> 00:08:39.155
First, I am gonna grab my eth0, and

171
00:08:39.155 --> 00:08:43.511
I'm just gonna click this blue shark-fin
up here to start capturing packets.

172
00:08:43.511 --> 00:08:47.108
So we will just let it go for
a second and see what happens.

173
00:08:47.108 --> 00:08:48.350
It is very exciting.

174
00:08:48.350 --> 00:08:50.208
It's funny how Dropbox
is almost always first.

175
00:08:50.208 --> 00:08:53.564
That thing is going all the time.

176
00:08:53.564 --> 00:08:54.456
Give it a minute.

177
00:08:54.456 --> 00:08:59.113
I'll try to generate it some
additional traffic here.

178
00:08:59.113 --> 00:09:02.850
I'm kind of surprised that more
hasn't popped up just yet.

179
00:09:04.642 --> 00:09:06.457
So I don't know.

180
00:09:06.457 --> 00:09:08.417
We'll go to a couple
different webpages here.

181
00:09:08.417 --> 00:09:10.442
We'll close that browser down.

182
00:09:10.442 --> 00:09:12.596
Then we'll come back over here, and

183
00:09:12.596 --> 00:09:16.425
we'll see that I have indeed
captured some traffic, all right?

184
00:09:16.425 --> 00:09:21.690
Now I'm gonna go ahead and
stop the capture and we look at the scroll

185
00:09:21.690 --> 00:09:26.700
bar over here and look how many
packets I captured, all right?

186
00:09:26.700 --> 00:09:28.429
That is a lot of data, all right?

187
00:09:28.429 --> 00:09:33.260
It was going for what, 30 seconds at
the most, so one of the things you're

188
00:09:33.260 --> 00:09:38.170
gonna find when you start working with
any packet capture utility is there's

189
00:09:38.170 --> 00:09:42.549
a lot of information, and
being able to find what you're looking for

190
00:09:42.549 --> 00:09:45.522
becomes the real art of
using a tool like this.

191
00:09:45.522 --> 00:09:49.010
And Wireshark has built
in abilities to do that,

192
00:09:49.010 --> 00:09:53.480
to help us get down to what
we're really looking for.

193
00:09:53.480 --> 00:09:55.749
And those are known as filters, all right?

194
00:09:55.749 --> 00:09:59.720
Because we end up with a lot of,
what I like to call, background noise.

195
00:09:59.720 --> 00:10:01.190
There's always ARP requests.

196
00:10:01.190 --> 00:10:04.140
Like here, I can see a couple
ARP requests right there.

197
00:10:04.140 --> 00:10:08.750
ARP is constantly broadcasting in
the background as nodes are talking to

198
00:10:08.750 --> 00:10:09.400
each other.

199
00:10:09.400 --> 00:10:13.827
DNS queries going on and
maybe I don't want to see those, right?

200
00:10:13.827 --> 00:10:19.103
I'm looking for SMTP traffic or
HTTP traffic or something like that.

201
00:10:19.103 --> 00:10:23.035
So, being able to get rid of that
background noise is where our filters

202
00:10:23.035 --> 00:10:23.577
come in.

203
00:10:23.577 --> 00:10:27.598
Now, we have two different set of
filters we can use within Wireshark.

204
00:10:27.598 --> 00:10:32.250
We have what's know as capture filters,
and then we have display filters.

205
00:10:32.250 --> 00:10:36.320
And let's just talk about how these
fit into the overall picture.

206
00:10:36.320 --> 00:10:39.840
If we think about the data being
out there on the wire, right, and

207
00:10:39.840 --> 00:10:44.040
we're firing up Wireshark, and
Wireshark's listening to that network.

208
00:10:44.040 --> 00:10:47.220
Well, that traffic,
as it comes in to our network adapter,

209
00:10:47.220 --> 00:10:52.420
it's first gonna be processed by any
capture filters that we have in place.

210
00:10:52.420 --> 00:10:58.130
Capture filters define what data I want or
don't want to capture.

211
00:10:58.130 --> 00:11:01.510
So it's saying, here's a packet
that's coming in, it's TCP.

212
00:11:01.510 --> 00:11:04.470
The filter says grab all TCP,
I'm going to let that in.

213
00:11:04.470 --> 00:11:08.030
If it is DNS,
that is not on my capture filter.

214
00:11:08.030 --> 00:11:08.987
I am gonna block that.

215
00:11:08.987 --> 00:11:10.635
I'm gonna not allow that in.

216
00:11:10.635 --> 00:11:16.070
All the filters, the capture filters,
get applied first before the data gets

217
00:11:16.070 --> 00:11:20.160
passed into the capture engine,
Wireshark itself.

218
00:11:20.160 --> 00:11:24.130
It's ability to grab those packets and
put them in a list, break them down,

219
00:11:24.130 --> 00:11:25.380
and color code them.

220
00:11:25.380 --> 00:11:28.584
So, data comes in,
it goes through the capture filters and

221
00:11:28.584 --> 00:11:31.403
then it goes into the capture
engine in Wireshark and

222
00:11:31.403 --> 00:11:34.561
then it passes through whats
called the display filters.

223
00:11:34.561 --> 00:11:38.452
This is between the capture engine,
Wireshark in the background,

224
00:11:38.452 --> 00:11:42.500
the underlying code, and
the GUI that I see here on my desktop.

225
00:11:42.500 --> 00:11:45.074
The display filters kind of
sit in between those two.

226
00:11:45.074 --> 00:11:49.490
So the capture has all this data based
on what our capture filters were set to.

227
00:11:49.490 --> 00:11:52.970
And then it's pushing it out to the GUI
but as it goes to the GUI the display

228
00:11:52.970 --> 00:11:57.410
filter says you know what he only wants
to see traffic that was source port 80,

229
00:11:57.410 --> 00:11:58.000
right?

230
00:11:58.000 --> 00:12:02.954
Or source IP address 1011215, right?

231
00:12:02.954 --> 00:12:09.652
And so the slate filter filters what data
is actually gonna be shown in my GUI.

232
00:12:09.652 --> 00:12:14.344
The key to remember here is the capture
filters are applied before the capture, or

233
00:12:14.344 --> 00:12:16.310
during the capture, right?

234
00:12:16.310 --> 00:12:19.200
So they will limit
the size of the capture.

235
00:12:19.200 --> 00:12:22.630
They can reduce the overall size
cuz you're saying hey just ignore

236
00:12:22.630 --> 00:12:26.760
all this ARP stuff and all this SMTP
stuff or whatever the case may be.

237
00:12:26.760 --> 00:12:28.432
Everything else make it
part of the capture.

238
00:12:28.432 --> 00:12:31.483
The display filters do not
modify the capture file,

239
00:12:31.483 --> 00:12:36.570
they are just filtering what you're seeing
and you can change those on the fly.

240
00:12:36.570 --> 00:12:37.400
If I decide, you know what?

241
00:12:37.400 --> 00:12:41.600
I want to look at TCP I can create
a display filter that just shows TCP.

242
00:12:41.600 --> 00:12:44.002
If I say, you know what,
I need to see the UDP.

243
00:12:44.002 --> 00:12:48.273
I can change my filter to UDP and I says
alright now I'm going to hide the TCP and

244
00:12:48.273 --> 00:12:49.940
I'll show you UDP.

245
00:12:49.940 --> 00:12:53.440
But all the packets remain as part of
the capture because the display filters

246
00:12:53.440 --> 00:12:54.890
are after the capture.

247
00:12:54.890 --> 00:12:58.840
They do affect your capture size,
you can change them on the fly.

248
00:12:58.840 --> 00:13:01.167
Capture filters can't change on the fly.

249
00:13:01.167 --> 00:13:03.410
Once I set them and
start the capture, well,

250
00:13:03.410 --> 00:13:06.494
that's what's going to be used
to create that capture file.

251
00:13:06.494 --> 00:13:10.524
If I want to change that I have to stop
my capture, create a new filter, and

252
00:13:10.524 --> 00:13:12.089
start the capture all over.

253
00:13:12.089 --> 00:13:13.149
All right?

254
00:13:13.149 --> 00:13:16.683
>> So Mike, let's make sure, because
you just said a lot of stuff there, so

255
00:13:16.683 --> 00:13:18.800
let's make sure that we understand.

256
00:13:18.800 --> 00:13:23.010
With the capture filters,
I hope I'm explaining this right Mike.

257
00:13:23.010 --> 00:13:25.400
What Mike is saying is if you choose to,

258
00:13:25.400 --> 00:13:29.020
just like what he said,
I don't want to see DNS, right?

259
00:13:29.020 --> 00:13:33.260
And you do that with a capture filter, and
then you decide later on to go back and

260
00:13:33.260 --> 00:13:34.290
look for DNS.

261
00:13:34.290 --> 00:13:36.270
Mike, is it right what you're saying?

262
00:13:36.270 --> 00:13:40.136
Capture filter's saying I don't see
DNS cuz you already filtered it out.

263
00:13:40.136 --> 00:13:41.289
>> Exactly.
>> Okay.

264
00:13:41.289 --> 00:13:44.268
But with the display filter though,
you're saying it captures it and

265
00:13:44.268 --> 00:13:48.090
then you can say I didn't wanna see
DNS but it's actually still there.

266
00:13:48.090 --> 00:13:50.300
But then you're just filtering it out but

267
00:13:50.300 --> 00:13:52.567
So if you choose to change your mind-
>> Yep.

268
00:13:52.567 --> 00:13:53.840
>> Then you can actually display it.

269
00:13:53.840 --> 00:13:54.914
>> You're free to change your mind.

270
00:13:54.914 --> 00:13:55.741
>> That's right.
>> Exactly right.

271
00:13:55.741 --> 00:13:56.804
Cuz it's all still there.

272
00:13:56.804 --> 00:13:59.669
>> Yeah and so
the neat part about this, right?

273
00:13:59.669 --> 00:14:02.876
Is that you have that power and
that ability to do so.

274
00:14:02.876 --> 00:14:05.788
Wireshark makes it easier for
you to do this.

275
00:14:05.788 --> 00:14:09.989
And the reason why I say it's easier is
because there's other tools out there,

276
00:14:09.989 --> 00:14:13.062
that Mike as mentioning,
that don't make it that easy for

277
00:14:13.062 --> 00:14:16.658
you to be able to do this and
to kinda know exactly what you have to do.

278
00:14:16.658 --> 00:14:20.876
But because of the way that Wireshark
has been developed over time and

279
00:14:20.876 --> 00:14:23.940
within the community,
it really is a nifty tool.

280
00:14:23.940 --> 00:14:26.913
It's probably one of the neatest
tools that you'll have access to,

281
00:14:26.913 --> 00:14:29.900
to be able to do things, like what
Mike is talking about, on the fly.

282
00:14:29.900 --> 00:14:32.652
It's really worth your time and
effort and to take a look at.

283
00:14:32.652 --> 00:14:33.250
>> Absolutely.

284
00:14:33.250 --> 00:14:34.504
Like I said at the beginning,

285
00:14:34.504 --> 00:14:37.170
this is one of the fundamental
tools that you just must master.

286
00:14:37.170 --> 00:14:39.360
You can pick another one,
it doesn't have to be Wireshark,

287
00:14:39.360 --> 00:14:41.820
but packet capture in general
you need to understand.

288
00:14:43.790 --> 00:14:48.587
So we've talked about the display filters,
the capture filters.

289
00:14:48.587 --> 00:14:50.869
One other thing, and
I'll go out to Wireshark here and

290
00:14:50.869 --> 00:14:52.563
we'll take a look at some of the syntax.

291
00:14:52.563 --> 00:14:57.199
Capture filters,
they're not quite as robust.

292
00:14:57.199 --> 00:15:03.585
There's not as many of them,
they're not used as much, right?

293
00:15:03.585 --> 00:15:08.400
And when I say that, I wanna say that
they are not use, that's not probably

294
00:15:08.400 --> 00:15:13.470
a good way to put it but again we
typically wanna capture as much as we can.

295
00:15:13.470 --> 00:15:17.310
And then be able to filtered it using
display filters change our view, but

296
00:15:17.310 --> 00:15:18.790
we still have the data.

297
00:15:18.790 --> 00:15:23.130
Remember capture filter like Ronnie just
said, you can't go back and get more info.

298
00:15:23.130 --> 00:15:26.080
When you've put a capture filter on there,
if you blocked it during the capture

299
00:15:26.080 --> 00:15:29.240
it will never be there because
you did not capture it.

300
00:15:29.240 --> 00:15:32.560
So use your capture
filters in a limited way.

301
00:15:32.560 --> 00:15:36.870
Really capture filters, you are not
trying to decide what I want to look for,

302
00:15:36.870 --> 00:15:39.470
I'm looking for
a particular, not normally.

303
00:15:39.470 --> 00:15:42.725
Normally we use capture filters to
get rid of the background noise.

304
00:15:42.725 --> 00:15:44.851
Like, I know there's ARP request going and

305
00:15:44.851 --> 00:15:48.542
if I'm not dealing with ARP attacks
right now, maybe I wanna get rid of ARP.

306
00:15:48.542 --> 00:15:53.847
There's a lot of active directory traffic,
Windows network that we can filter out,

307
00:15:53.847 --> 00:15:56.881
and just keep it out of
the capture all together.

308
00:15:56.881 --> 00:15:59.670
Just to keep the file size
a little bore manageable.

309
00:15:59.670 --> 00:16:03.230
But really be careful because like I said,
you use, you can't go back.

310
00:16:03.230 --> 00:16:06.011
So, I would much really use
a display filter after the fact and

311
00:16:06.011 --> 00:16:07.254
just capture everything.

312
00:16:07.254 --> 00:16:11.507
I rarely use capture filters, I'll be
honest with you, because of that fact.

313
00:16:11.507 --> 00:16:15.930
Because I want all the data And I'm not
really worried about the file size that

314
00:16:15.930 --> 00:16:19.756
much and so I'll capture everything and
then filter it out later.

315
00:16:19.756 --> 00:16:23.119
All right, this is Wireshark's page
here and I'll zoom in a little bit so

316
00:16:23.119 --> 00:16:24.486
we can see it a little better.

317
00:16:24.486 --> 00:16:28.742
This is their capture filters and I just
wanted to show you a few of the different

318
00:16:28.742 --> 00:16:31.339
examples that they give
on their website here.

319
00:16:31.339 --> 00:16:34.910
If I was wanting to see traffic
just from a particular host.

320
00:16:34.910 --> 00:16:37.729
And I'll show you where to do this
in Wireshark in just a second.

321
00:16:37.729 --> 00:16:40.870
The keyword host and then the IP address.

322
00:16:40.870 --> 00:16:45.460
Or I could do an entire network
if we've got multiple subnets and

323
00:16:45.460 --> 00:16:48.030
I'm on a mirrored port that's

324
00:16:48.030 --> 00:16:50.410
I just wanna see a particular network.
