00:16:51.420 --> 00:16:53.464
Or I've got a class, think about this.

326
00:16:53.464 --> 00:16:57.116
I could take that class B,
which has a lot of hosts and

327
00:16:57.116 --> 00:17:02.096
even though it's not the subnet address
I could use this to effectively

328
00:17:02.096 --> 00:17:07.020
only capture a part or a sub-portion
of that class B network, right?

329
00:17:07.020 --> 00:17:10.110
You can type it out in the site or
notation.

330
00:17:10.110 --> 00:17:14.756
You can type it out with a actual
mask if you use the keyword net and

331
00:17:14.756 --> 00:17:16.146
the keyword mask.

332
00:17:16.146 --> 00:17:23.040
The host will get inbound and outbound
traffic from that particular IP address.

333
00:17:23.040 --> 00:17:26.050
Net will get inbound and
outbound traffic from that range.

334
00:17:27.450 --> 00:17:30.740
Or we can prepend with the word source.

335
00:17:30.740 --> 00:17:35.607
If I say source net,
now it's only traffic from, not to, right?

336
00:17:35.607 --> 00:17:40.670
Only from, and you can still use the net
mask, or you can use destination or

337
00:17:40.670 --> 00:17:45.580
DST for only traffic inbound
to that particular network.

338
00:17:45.580 --> 00:17:51.899
So those are good ones to know, host,
net, source net, destination net.

339
00:17:51.899 --> 00:17:53.510
You can do a particular port number.

340
00:17:53.510 --> 00:17:58.110
Only looking for DNS traffic,
I can put a capture filter on there 453.

341
00:17:58.110 --> 00:18:01.570
And then I should only have
DNS traffic in my results.

342
00:18:03.190 --> 00:18:07.310
Here they're starting to use the word and
to combine multiple filters.

343
00:18:07.310 --> 00:18:09.869
You can use and, you can use ors.

344
00:18:11.660 --> 00:18:13.680
Do think about your order of operation,
right?

345
00:18:13.680 --> 00:18:18.310
This goes back to the old PEMDAS,
parentheses are going to be first.

346
00:18:18.310 --> 00:18:21.407
And so they're do a not port 80 or
port 25.

347
00:18:21.407 --> 00:18:24.900
They're negating both of
those either 80 or 25, but

348
00:18:24.900 --> 00:18:29.569
they're saying it has to be from here but
it can't be port 80 or port 25.

349
00:18:31.290 --> 00:18:33.900
Here they're just doing
it in a more complex way.

350
00:18:33.900 --> 00:18:35.910
And I'm not gonna go
through each one of these.

351
00:18:35.910 --> 00:18:38.080
You guys can take your time and
go through these filters.

352
00:18:38.080 --> 00:18:39.820
I wanted to show you some basic ones.

353
00:18:39.820 --> 00:18:41.330
You can see they can get rather complex.

354
00:18:41.330 --> 00:18:44.080
Here, what they're actually
doing with that syntax

355
00:18:44.080 --> 00:18:46.360
is they're breaking
down the header itself.

356
00:18:46.360 --> 00:18:50.483
They're saying skip the first two bytes of
the header and read the second two where

357
00:18:50.483 --> 00:18:54.739
the port number is and see if it's less
than or in this case greater than 1,500.

358
00:18:54.739 --> 00:18:59.980
All right, what else did I wanna show you?

359
00:18:59.980 --> 00:19:00.860
Here's one that's simple and

360
00:19:00.860 --> 00:19:04.114
not broadcast,
not multicast that can eliminate.

361
00:19:04.114 --> 00:19:08.610
So a lot of you are not looking for that
type of traffic, eliminate a lot of that.

362
00:19:08.610 --> 00:19:11.599
Here's one that they've written
that actually looks for

363
00:19:11.599 --> 00:19:13.008
the Welchia worm, right?

364
00:19:13.008 --> 00:19:16.763
Because they know the signature because
we can find the signature of the worm.

365
00:19:16.763 --> 00:19:21.228
And they know that if you skip the header,
the next four bytes or

366
00:19:21.228 --> 00:19:23.010
is it bytes or bits?

367
00:19:23.010 --> 00:19:29.140
Next four bytes start with eight a's or
four bytes of a's I should say.

368
00:19:29.140 --> 00:19:30.398
That was a signature of Welchia.

369
00:19:30.398 --> 00:19:36.190
So you can actually use Wireshark to
detect if this worm is on your network.

370
00:19:36.190 --> 00:19:37.257
Pretty crazy, right?

371
00:19:37.257 --> 00:19:40.720
Here is a pretty complex
one to find heart bleed.

372
00:19:40.720 --> 00:19:42.525
Also has some default capture filters.

373
00:19:42.525 --> 00:19:47.420
Wireshark is smart enough to know when it
is running on a virtualized host, and so

374
00:19:47.420 --> 00:19:51.230
it will not capture a lot of
the virtual or remote desktop.

375
00:19:51.230 --> 00:19:57.270
If it's running remotely, it won't
capture the remote desktop information.

376
00:19:57.270 --> 00:19:59.040
So good stuff there.

377
00:19:59.040 --> 00:20:00.488
What else do I wanna show you?

378
00:20:00.488 --> 00:20:04.030
So while we're here, let's go ahead and
look at the display filters.

379
00:20:04.030 --> 00:20:05.920
Again, much more powerful, many,

380
00:20:05.920 --> 00:20:09.410
many, many more options
that I can do with display.

381
00:20:09.410 --> 00:20:13.297
Things like tcp.port = 25 or ICMP.

382
00:20:13.297 --> 00:20:19.530
So it's looking for my SMTP traffic or my
internet control message protocol traffic.

383
00:20:20.620 --> 00:20:23.070
There's the equal, equal.

384
00:20:23.070 --> 00:20:28.250
Notice you can use English or
the C like code within your filters.

385
00:20:28.250 --> 00:20:30.070
You can do either one.

386
00:20:30.070 --> 00:20:34.750
And I'll show you,
rather than go through each one of these,

387
00:20:34.750 --> 00:20:37.100
you can go out and Google this.

388
00:20:37.100 --> 00:20:38.930
This one happens to come
from packetlife.net.

389
00:20:38.930 --> 00:20:43.697
There are several people out there that
have Wireshark display filter cheat

390
00:20:43.697 --> 00:20:44.640
sheets.

391
00:20:44.640 --> 00:20:49.841
And you can see it's a pretty impressive
list of things that we can filter for.

392
00:20:49.841 --> 00:20:54.090
All right, and
this comes from packetlife.net.

393
00:20:54.090 --> 00:20:56.980
Jeremy Stretch wrote this up,
great job there.

394
00:20:56.980 --> 00:20:58.620
Use your favorite search engine, and

395
00:20:58.620 --> 00:21:02.220
you will find several options for
cheat sheets.

396
00:21:03.260 --> 00:21:06.820
All right, let's get back over here and
see why my virtualization is freaking out.

397
00:21:06.820 --> 00:21:08.882
I think my Windows machine just shut down.

398
00:21:08.882 --> 00:21:11.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> But, where do we wanna go next?

399
00:21:11.430 --> 00:21:16.440
We've talked about our capture filters,
our display filters.

400
00:21:16.440 --> 00:21:18.985
Should we actually look at capturing
some more traffic, Ronnie?

401
00:21:18.985 --> 00:21:20.012
>> Sounds like a good idea.

402
00:21:20.012 --> 00:21:27.170
>> All right, so when we go to start a new
capture, I have a capture currently.

403
00:21:27.170 --> 00:21:31.730
If I click start, for a start a new
capture, it's gonna ask me do I wanna

404
00:21:31.730 --> 00:21:35.228
save this data or
do I want to continue without saving.

405
00:21:35.228 --> 00:21:38.340
In the real world,
most likely you'd wanna save it.

406
00:21:39.510 --> 00:21:44.280
A lot of time we wanna save these dumps or
captures for later analysis or for

407
00:21:44.280 --> 00:21:46.442
comparison to what we've done currently.

408
00:21:46.442 --> 00:21:51.349
I'm gonna go ahead and
say continue without saving.

409
00:21:51.349 --> 00:21:53.490
And actually I'm gonna stop that one.

410
00:21:53.490 --> 00:21:54.440
No packets captured.

411
00:21:54.440 --> 00:21:56.817
We're gonna change ethernet adapters.

412
00:21:56.817 --> 00:21:58.734
All right, so I'm gonna flip over to eth1,

413
00:21:58.734 --> 00:22:01.150
which is connected to my
little test lab here.

414
00:22:01.150 --> 00:22:05.550
And we'll try a couple of different
things and then we'll apply some filters.

415
00:22:05.550 --> 00:22:06.678
Now speaking of filters,

416
00:22:06.678 --> 00:22:09.609
capture filters are applied before
you start the capture, right?

417
00:22:09.609 --> 00:22:12.130
Once you start it, you can't change it.

418
00:22:12.130 --> 00:22:15.310
This is where you put your capture filter,
right here.

419
00:22:15.310 --> 00:22:19.210
There's a little green flag that you
can click on to manage your saved

420
00:22:19.210 --> 00:22:20.390
capture filters.

421
00:22:20.390 --> 00:22:25.081
And there's a bunch of prebuilt filters
in here that came with Wireshark,

422
00:22:25.081 --> 00:22:26.550
which is great.

423
00:22:26.550 --> 00:22:31.390
You wanna create your own you can
go to manage capture filters, and

424
00:22:31.390 --> 00:22:35.760
this will bring you to this dialogue
box where I can indeed create my own

425
00:22:35.760 --> 00:22:39.350
capture filters and
then save them for future use.

426
00:22:39.350 --> 00:22:41.830
So let's take a look at
how we would do that.

427
00:22:41.830 --> 00:22:44.510
Little plus sign here down in
the bottom plus and minus.

428
00:22:44.510 --> 00:22:48.240
You can also take an existing one and
click the copy option and

429
00:22:48.240 --> 00:22:52.950
it will start a new one then you can
kinda tweak it to fit your needs.

430
00:22:52.950 --> 00:22:59.247
If click the plus sign, that will
let me create a new capture filter,

431
00:22:59.247 --> 00:23:06.852
and I could do something like source,
host and I don't know, 10.10.1.

432
00:23:06.852 --> 00:23:12.293
Gosh, if I can remember his IP
address now 101, I believe.

433
00:23:12.293 --> 00:23:14.358
And I can click okay, right?

434
00:23:14.358 --> 00:23:15.440
So now, oops,

435
00:23:15.440 --> 00:23:20.720
I created a new filter, now I need to make
sure that set grabs it, cuz it did not.

436
00:23:20.720 --> 00:23:22.224
And there is my filter.

437
00:23:22.224 --> 00:23:22.925
It turns green.

438
00:23:22.925 --> 00:23:26.830
That lets me know my syntax is correct and
it can apply that filter.

439
00:23:26.830 --> 00:23:27.350
I checked this.

440
00:23:27.350 --> 00:23:29.510
Now, I will give you a word of warning.

441
00:23:29.510 --> 00:23:32.520
I have seen where people are trying
to figure out why I can't enter

442
00:23:32.520 --> 00:23:34.040
a capture filter.

443
00:23:34.040 --> 00:23:39.160
And when you first launch this,
let me close it and launch it again.

444
00:23:39.160 --> 00:23:41.840
Sometimes there is no
network adapter selected.

445
00:23:43.370 --> 00:23:45.177
And you go to add.

446
00:23:45.177 --> 00:23:47.070
Right now,
there is no network adapter selected.

447
00:23:47.070 --> 00:23:50.730
So I'm gonna go up here, and
I'm gonna choose, I don't know, not ARP.

448
00:23:50.730 --> 00:23:51.550
Notice it turns red.

449
00:23:52.670 --> 00:23:54.590
Wait a second.
That's a pre-built filter.

450
00:23:54.590 --> 00:23:55.840
It really should be working.

451
00:23:55.840 --> 00:23:57.120
It should be the right syntax.

452
00:23:57.120 --> 00:23:59.780
And that's because it doesn't know what
network adapter you're gonna use, so

453
00:23:59.780 --> 00:24:02.950
it can't test it or
figure out if that filter is gonna work.

454
00:24:02.950 --> 00:24:05.070
As soon as I select something, and

455
00:24:05.070 --> 00:24:08.080
then I choose one of my filters,
we should be good to go.

456
00:24:08.080 --> 00:24:12.670
Or if I choose that same filter, not ARP
just to show you, now it turns green.

457
00:24:12.670 --> 00:24:16.235
All right, so there's your capture
filters, how you create them.

458
00:24:16.235 --> 00:24:20.030
Again, I'm actually not
gonna use one right now.

459
00:24:20.030 --> 00:24:23.480
Well, just because we wanna
get into our display filters,

460
00:24:23.480 --> 00:24:25.540
pretty straightforward there again.

461
00:24:25.540 --> 00:24:31.160
If this is gonna affect the size and what
packets are part of the overall capture.

462
00:24:31.160 --> 00:24:35.190
All right, so as you can see, there's
a lot we can do with Wireshark in our

463
00:24:35.190 --> 00:24:38.377
filters, both before the capture and
after the capture.

464
00:24:38.377 --> 00:24:41.770
And we wanna take a look at how we can
actually do these rather than just talk

465
00:24:41.770 --> 00:24:44.920
about them, but Ronnie's over there
kinda giving me the evil eye.

466
00:24:44.920 --> 00:24:47.280
I think we might be a little low on time.

467
00:24:47.280 --> 00:24:51.470
Yes, Mike, we definitely are a little
bit low on time and we want to see how,

468
00:24:51.470 --> 00:24:55.860
of course, Wireshark can be used and
generate some traffic and

469
00:24:55.860 --> 00:24:59.460
get the capture going, cuz that's probably
what we all want to be able to do and

470
00:24:59.460 --> 00:25:02.900
that way Mike can also show us well,
what it actually is doing.

471
00:25:02.900 --> 00:25:05.640
So it's a great place for us to just
sign off and we'll come back for

472
00:25:05.640 --> 00:25:08.120
a part two when Mike
shows us how to do this.

473
00:25:08.120 --> 00:25:11.890
So, signing off for ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

474
00:25:11.890 --> 00:25:12.810
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

475
00:25:12.810 --> 00:25:15.240
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Kali Linux shows!

476
00:25:15.240 --> 00:25:22.133
[MUSIC]

477
00:25:22.133 --> 00:25:24.893
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continues with Wireshark. Mike shows how to setup and use a capture filter and the results.  He also then differentiates the results by doing a display filter too.  Mike ends the episode with a tcp stream follow to show how wireshark can reassemble the packets into a logical data stream.
episodes.title: Wireshark Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at another Kali Linux tool tcpdump.  Mike explains that tcpdump can provide another way of seeing the traffic that is not as sophisticated as Wireshark but just as complex.  With tcpdump, we can do some of the same things as wireshark and even filter specific information within a packet to display packet level details.
episodes.title: Tcpdump Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:01.200
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.200 --> 00:00:03.151
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.151 --> 00:00:05.074
[CROSSTALK].

4
00:00:05.074 --> 00:00:08.194
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.194 --> 00:00:11.330
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.330 --> 00:00:14.978
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.978 --> 00:00:18.020
You're watching the Kali Linux show.

8
00:00:18.020 --> 00:00:19.640
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

9
00:00:19.640 --> 00:00:24.010
today we're gonna be taking a look at
another type of packet-capturing utility.

10
00:00:24.010 --> 00:00:27.210
One called tcpdump and
we're learning about the basics.

11
00:00:27.210 --> 00:00:30.590
And who better to help us out than Mr.
Security himself, Mike Rodrick?

12
00:00:30.590 --> 00:00:32.428
Mike, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:32.428 --> 00:00:33.916
>> Well,
I can think of a few better people but no.

14
00:00:33.916 --> 00:00:35.440
[LAUGH]
>> I don't think so.

15
00:00:35.440 --> 00:00:37.390
All right now, Mike.

16
00:00:37.390 --> 00:00:40.114
>> When we start to talk about this idea.

17
00:00:40.114 --> 00:00:45.590
We've already went through Wireshark,
so Mike why tcpdump?

18
00:00:45.590 --> 00:00:51.780
>> Really it's just when you need a small
command line driven type of capture.

19
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:52.585
>> Okay.

20
00:00:52.585 --> 00:00:56.975
>> You know, actually Wireshark
can be run from the command line.

21
00:00:56.975 --> 00:00:59.921
But tcpdump is command line only,
there's no GUI interface for it.

22
00:00:59.921 --> 00:01:05.585
It's an easy one, typically,
to get installed and run.

23
00:01:05.585 --> 00:01:08.525
And then we can do most of the same things
that we do with Wireshark we've got our

24
00:01:08.525 --> 00:01:13.375
filtering capabilities, we can write out
to a file, we can read existing files.

25
00:01:13.375 --> 00:01:19.940
And it puts it out in a format that other,
like Wireshark for example, can also read.

26
00:01:19.940 --> 00:01:22.930
Which is typically what I end
up doing because as you'll see,

27
00:01:22.930 --> 00:01:26.100
working with tcpdump
is a little different.

28
00:01:26.100 --> 00:01:30.190
It's not as user friendly I think
is probably a politically correct

29
00:01:30.190 --> 00:01:31.480
way to say it.

30
00:01:31.480 --> 00:01:32.680
Lets look at it.

31
00:01:32.680 --> 00:01:35.740
We'll kind of go through the different
options, we'll fire it up.

32
00:01:35.740 --> 00:01:39.490
We'll generate some traffic, we'll capture
some traffic we'll save the capture file

33
00:01:39.490 --> 00:01:43.620
we'll open it up, we'll filter it we'll
open it up with Wireshark as well.

34
00:01:43.620 --> 00:01:45.180
What the heck, let's do it all.

35
00:01:45.180 --> 00:01:47.590
All right, so let start off by
taking a look like my screen here.

36
00:01:47.590 --> 00:01:49.710
I'm on my Kali Linux box of course.

37
00:01:49.710 --> 00:01:54.095
And the first thing we're gonna do
is just a little man tcpdump if I

38
00:01:54.095 --> 00:01:56.740
can spell that
>> That's quite the name of a file

39
00:01:56.740 --> 00:01:57.387
isn't it?

40
00:01:57.387 --> 00:01:58.318
>> It is right?

41
00:01:58.318 --> 00:01:59.403
>> Executable.

42
00:01:59.403 --> 00:02:00.987
>> Creative.

43
00:02:00.987 --> 00:02:05.268
Great man page, but there are some of the
switches that we should be familiar with,

44
00:02:05.268 --> 00:02:06.790
some of the options.

45
00:02:06.790 --> 00:02:12.460
You basically got your options and
your expressions, there are several that,

46
00:02:12.460 --> 00:02:15.005
let's see, the best way to
show you some of these are.

47
00:02:15.005 --> 00:02:17.410
[COUGH] excuse me.

48
00:02:17.410 --> 00:02:22.160
As I go down here, this is one of the
first ones you might wanna use as the -d.

49
00:02:22.160 --> 00:02:24.440
This gives you a list of interfaces.

50
00:02:24.440 --> 00:02:26.620
Just like we did with our
other packet caps utilities,

51
00:02:26.620 --> 00:02:29.610
we have to tell it what
interface we want to listen on.

52
00:02:29.610 --> 00:02:34.650
Now if you just run TCP dump and you
don't tell it It'll typically pick your

53
00:02:34.650 --> 00:02:39.140
first network adaptor and
the list of adaptors that you have.

54
00:02:39.140 --> 00:02:42.730
Which might or might not be the one you're
expecting, so usually easier to, hey,

55
00:02:42.730 --> 00:02:45.440
let me take a look at the list and
then specify.

56
00:02:45.440 --> 00:02:51.825
So in the -i is what we're going to
use [COUGH] to specify the interface.

57
00:02:51.825 --> 00:02:53.374
So -i eth0, eth1.

58
00:02:53.374 --> 00:02:57.780
You can also do a -any, or
-i any, and it'll listen on all.

59
00:02:57.780 --> 00:03:03.320
And you can list more than
one interfaces as well.

60
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:04.930
Let's see what else I wanted
to point out for sure.

61
00:03:04.930 --> 00:03:08.236
So we talked about the dash d,
the -l, dash lower case n,

62
00:03:08.236 --> 00:03:11.222
don't resolve your host names,
always a good one.

63
00:03:11.222 --> 00:03:16.430
I could scroll through here and
find it but it's kind of a pain,

64
00:03:16.430 --> 00:03:21.358
at least on screen here, but
your dash lower case n is your.

65
00:03:21.358 --> 00:03:27.770
Skipping the DNS name resolution, which
sometimes may slow it down a little bit.

66
00:03:27.770 --> 00:03:29.621
Also typically, makes for
a cleaner output.

67
00:03:29.621 --> 00:03:32.130
We're usually worried about
the IP address not the DNS name.

68
00:03:32.130 --> 00:03:36.008
Another one I wanna make sure we
talk about is the -v that is for

69
00:03:36.008 --> 00:03:41.150
verbose that is typically a good one
to use just get you more information.

70
00:03:41.150 --> 00:03:47.110
A -X, this one will show you the hex
output and the ASCII output.

71
00:03:47.110 --> 00:03:49.610
If you do dash capital X, capital X.

72
00:03:49.610 --> 00:03:53.558
So double X,
you can actually get the link header and

73
00:03:53.558 --> 00:03:56.172
the frame header for that as well.

74
00:03:56.172 --> 00:04:01.408
Looks very similar to the output you
would see in the bottom of Wireshark

75
00:04:01.408 --> 00:04:06.830
where you saw the hexdump as well as
the ASCII conversion right next to it.

76
00:04:06.830 --> 00:04:08.360
So we'll see that.

77
00:04:08.360 --> 00:04:09.485
The other thing,

78
00:04:09.485 --> 00:04:14.140
it only captures they've just recently
changed the defaults, I think.

79
00:04:14.140 --> 00:04:20.600
I wanna say it's 90
bytes out of the packet.

80
00:04:20.600 --> 00:04:22.466
It didn't capture the entire packet, so

81
00:04:22.466 --> 00:04:25.280
if you want the entire packet
you can specify the size.

82
00:04:25.280 --> 00:04:30.468
Or you can do an as 0,
what they call a snap length as a -S.

83
00:04:30.468 --> 00:04:34.530
You can do -S 0, and
it actually captures the entire packet.

84
00:04:34.530 --> 00:04:39.485
Which is usually what I try to do,
-e will add your Ethernet header,

85
00:04:39.485 --> 00:04:43.600
-W gives you the ability to write
to a file, to take the output,

86
00:04:43.600 --> 00:04:48.800
instead of going to your standard
out in your terminal, out to a file.

87
00:04:48.800 --> 00:04:53.230
And then -r will allow you
to open up an existing file.

88
00:04:53.230 --> 00:04:58.740
So a few of the options we wanna be
familiar with when we're running tcpdump,

89
00:04:58.740 --> 00:05:02.960
some of the expressions we would use
similar to other packet capture utilities,

90
00:05:02.960 --> 00:05:05.720
we've got things like host, net, port.

91
00:05:05.720 --> 00:05:10.554
So we could do tcpdump host 10.10.1

92
00:05:10.554 --> 00:05:15.132
what is my IP 101 something like that and

93
00:05:15.132 --> 00:05:19.965
that's gonna tell it
hey I'm gonna listen or

94
00:05:19.965 --> 00:05:24.819
look for traffic to or
from host is to or from.

95
00:05:24.819 --> 00:05:29.373
I'm just gonna kill that cuz I didn't
tell it an Ethernet adapter is listening

96
00:05:29.373 --> 00:05:33.090
on my first one which doesn't
have any traffic on it right now.

97
00:05:33.090 --> 00:05:36.330
You can specify a network,
we can use citer notation.

98
00:05:36.330 --> 00:05:37.978
You can also specify a port number.

99
00:05:37.978 --> 00:05:41.309
We could do tcpdump port and
a particular port number, only looking for

100
00:05:41.309 --> 00:05:42.762
traffic on a particular port.

101
00:05:42.762 --> 00:05:46.926
You've got your destination switches so
instead of host,

102
00:05:46.926 --> 00:05:50.780
I could say tcpdump source 10,10,1,101.

103
00:05:50.780 --> 00:05:53.740
Maybe traffic leaving, originating from.

104
00:05:53.740 --> 00:05:57.920
I could do destination,
DST be traffic coming back.

105
00:05:57.920 --> 00:05:59.560
And we can also do protocols.

106
00:05:59.560 --> 00:06:03.650
We can just type in, TCP for

107
00:06:03.650 --> 00:06:08.240
example or ICMP to filter for
a particular protocol.

108
00:06:08.240 --> 00:06:10.930
So let's kick this thing in the tires,
light the fires and

109
00:06:10.930 --> 00:06:13.240
see what the heck tcpdump is all about.

110
00:06:13.240 --> 00:06:17.160
So let's start off with actually
clearing the screen up a little bit,

00:06:17.160 --> 00:06:19.290

00:06:19.290 --> 00:06:24.460
So what I wanna do is let's start with

00:06:26.360 --> 00:06:28.780
There we can see the different
Ethernet adapters or

00:06:33.180 --> 00:06:36.765
Give me a list of those so

eth1 being the ones I wanna use.

00:06:38.786 --> 00:06:43.270
But a quick easy way to see what it

that we've learned about.

00:06:59.790 --> 00:07:04.610
You can string these switches together, as
with most programs, so a single hyphen and

00:07:04.610 --> 00:07:06.210
then all of my different options.

00:07:06.210 --> 00:07:09.730
I'm gonna do a -N, for no name resolution.

125
00:07:09.730 --> 00:07:11.460
Also gonna throw a V for verbose.

00:07:11.460 --> 00:07:15.330
We can do a couple of these, to get some
extra verbosity, but it'll go ahead and

00:07:15.330 --> 00:07:16.870
leave it on that single one there.

00:07:16.870 --> 00:07:21.170
Another one that I didn't mention that

00:07:21.170 --> 00:07:26.180
correlating logs, dumps across different,

The timestamp info, there's a -t where

00:07:35.980 --> 00:07:41.920
I'm gonna do the XX,

And we can see a little

And lets take a look let

here we can see the output

what you're seeing is each

10.10.1.101 heading to 10.10.1.103 and

Next packet down looks

So it's coming from 103 heading

00:09:00.039 --> 00:09:02.710

00:09:02.710 --> 00:09:07.769
So, pretty straight forward there

00:09:07.769 --> 00:09:11.969

155
00:09:13.840 --> 00:09:17.700
All right, now let's take a look, let me

00:09:17.700 --> 00:09:22.119
It does tell you when you do stop

00:09:22.119 --> 00:09:24.430

00:09:24.430 --> 00:09:30.050
31 packets received by filter
zero packets dropped by kernel.

00:09:30.050 --> 00:09:35.815
And what that's saying is hey 31 packets
came by all of which matched your filters,

160
00:09:35.815 --> 00:09:40.716
cuz I have no filters so it actually

161
00:09:40.716 --> 00:09:42.923
Now if we want to start filtering traffic,

162
00:09:42.923 --> 00:09:45.820
let's take a look at doing

00:09:45.820 --> 00:09:52.700
We'll bring that last command back and

00:09:52.700 --> 00:09:53.660
So it says it's listening.

165
00:09:55.320 --> 00:09:56.540
And let's fire up our ping again.

00:09:59.222 --> 00:10:04.070
And you'll notice is there's no packets

There are a few packets now and

But none of these ping packets

So when we use a filter like

These are controlling what packets

right, as I scroll down

00:10:50.720 --> 00:10:55.340
Again, it's a little bit

It's easy to get tcpdump started and

00:11:03.220 --> 00:11:08.513

but we could also use things like

All right, so

And let's try another one,

What should we do now, Ronnie?

Let's, so we did not ICMP,

Let's do something like this, let's

So same filter that I'm using and we

I'm gonna write this out

That's how we dump the file,

And I'm just gonna call it tcpump test,

00:11:52.510 --> 00:11:55.940
something like that, and

00:11:57.150 --> 00:11:58.200
And again, it is listening.

So we'll go generate a little

Heck, what else should we do?

Let's do a little telnet.

00:12:13.179 --> 00:12:18.746
What was that guy, 10.10.1.103?

00:12:20.992 --> 00:12:24.750
Just generating some traffic so

You give me second to prompt me for

Well, take a look at how

00:12:37.860 --> 00:12:41.868
All right, now I'm gonna jump

I will stop my capture, right?

But notice I had no output

00:12:46.772 --> 00:12:48.706

00:12:48.706 --> 00:12:54.650
And I can see I got 80 packets captured

00:12:54.650 --> 00:12:57.930
But it's all being stored in a file.

00:12:57.930 --> 00:13:03.100
And here is my file tcpdump test,

00:13:03.100 --> 00:13:08.625
So if we wanna view that file that's where
the -R switch comes into play tcpdump

00:13:12.159 --> 00:13:13.550
-R and then the name of my file.

00:13:13.550 --> 00:13:19.804
And it's going to spit it out

00:13:21.976 --> 00:13:25.963
Now the cool thing about this so

00:13:25.963 --> 00:13:28.840

00:13:28.840 --> 00:13:30.550
We said not ICMP.

00:13:30.550 --> 00:13:31.540
That was a capture filter.

This time I didn't put any there,

What if I wanna filter this traffic now?

Can we do that, like we saw with some

And the answer is yes,

00:13:46.380 --> 00:13:49.980
So let's take a look,

00:13:49.980 --> 00:13:55.282
Clear my screen get back up to the top so

we'll do the tcpdump -R,

somebody sent to us for analysis and

00:14:05.710 --> 00:14:08.836
Alright, and
if we look not the easiest to see but

00:14:08.836 --> 00:14:12.571
if you had a bunch of telnet's,

00:14:12.571 --> 00:14:17.300

this is the beginning this is

00:14:20.910 --> 00:14:24.850
So what we're seeing

00:14:24.850 --> 00:14:29.426
when we ran a read command

00:14:29.426 --> 00:14:34.130

00:14:34.130 --> 00:14:36.140
All right, so we're so

00:14:36.140 --> 00:14:40.640

00:14:40.640 --> 00:14:45.444
We just have to, we can set our source,

00:14:45.444 --> 00:14:48.908

00:14:48.908 --> 00:14:51.550

00:14:51.550 --> 00:14:55.790
And I can definitely use tcpdump

You can write complex filters in here.

So we can get as complex as

00:15:17.210 --> 00:15:18.280
So go back out here.

00:15:22.156 --> 00:15:23.644
And ignore our Lua Error.

00:15:27.710 --> 00:15:33.270

And notice that Wireshark is

00:15:40.120 --> 00:15:42.430

Everything is still working just fine.

00:15:50.080 --> 00:15:51.452

Right-click, follow stream,

00:15:57.560 --> 00:16:02.760
So even if we capture

So in the end another packet capture

00:16:28.712 --> 00:16:30.960
>> All right,
Mike well thank you again for

00:16:30.960 --> 00:16:35.550

271
00:16:35.550 --> 00:16:39.130
It is a powerful utility,

00:16:39.130 --> 00:16:43.590
And usually, a Linux distribution a lot

But it does help to at least see the raw

00:16:47.540 --> 00:16:48.920

275
00:16:48.920 --> 00:16:53.360
And Mike was right about the idea of the

00:16:53.360 --> 00:16:55.750
which is gonna be the 96 bytes here.

277
00:16:55.750 --> 00:16:58.690
But with him using that -S0?

278
00:16:58.690 --> 00:16:59.470
>> S0.

279
00:16:59.470 --> 00:17:01.760
>> That actually gives
the whole packet itself.

00:17:01.760 --> 00:17:04.100
>> And you can cuz like if
you wanted more than 96, but

00:17:04.100 --> 00:17:09.290
not the whole thing, you can say -S 1,000,
right, or something like that.

00:17:09.290 --> 00:17:11.630
But the S0 just says all right,
grab everything.

283
00:17:11.630 --> 00:17:14.600
>> And that's actually very important,
especially if you're looking for specific

284
00:17:14.600 --> 00:17:18.860
types of information that you're trying
to find within a packet, it's gonna help.

285
00:17:18.860 --> 00:17:21.660
Tcp does give you a lot
of other filters that

00:17:21.660 --> 00:17:24.640
we don't have to go through right now,
because that's actually more advanced, but

287

00:17:26.470 --> 00:17:29.260
Well, this is a great place for

>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike introduce nmap.  Mike describes it’s particular usage and then the syntax options when choosing to run nmap.  He begins describing the syntax used with some of the different scan types, options, target specifications and port specifications too.
episodes.title: Nmap Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.144
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm you host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.144 --> 00:00:08.130
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.130 --> 00:00:12.090
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.090 --> 00:00:15.130
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.130 --> 00:00:17.731
You're watching the Kali Linux show.

6
00:00:17.731 --> 00:00:22.800
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
today we're diving into Nmap Basics.

7
00:00:22.800 --> 00:00:25.440
And who better to help us to
understand Nmap better, well than Mr.

8
00:00:25.440 --> 00:00:27.250
Security himself, Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:27.250 --> 00:00:28.069
Mike, welcome back to the show.

10
00:00:28.069 --> 00:00:30.020
>> Hey, thanks, Ronnie,
thanks for having me back.

11
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:30.780
And yeah, excited,

12
00:00:30.780 --> 00:00:35.680
cuz today we are playing with another
one of my favorite tools, good old Nmap.

13
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:38.580
Now as we go through some
our foundational tools or

14
00:00:38.580 --> 00:00:43.410
our tools we just really have to have in
our toolkit, Nmap has to be one of them.

15
00:00:43.410 --> 00:00:47.460
We were talking about some
of the de facto tools.

16
00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:52.770
We talked about how Netcat, or NC, or Ncat
now, for the new version from the same

17
00:00:52.770 --> 00:00:58.410
people that made Nmap, are your go to
tool for creating connection, CCP UDP.

18
00:00:58.410 --> 00:01:03.245
We show how Wireshark is kind of like
the de facto standard for packet captures.

19
00:01:03.245 --> 00:01:08.130
Nmap is probably the de facto standard for
doing port scans, right.

20
00:01:08.130 --> 00:01:11.880
It is a fantastic tool,
an extremely powerful tool,

21
00:01:11.880 --> 00:01:15.210
it does a lot more than
just doing port scans.

22
00:01:15.210 --> 00:01:18.800
But that's where we'll start, right,
we wanna kinda learn our basics,

23
00:01:18.800 --> 00:01:21.248
get our feet wet, and
playing with a tool like this.

24
00:01:21.248 --> 00:01:26.760
So, Nmap, again,
is a port scanner and when we

25
00:01:26.760 --> 00:01:31.370
talk about a port scanner we have to think
back to our TCP/IP and the way that works.

26
00:01:31.370 --> 00:01:33.220
And when we look at a system,

27
00:01:33.220 --> 00:01:37.170
we've got network adapters that
get assigned an IP address.

28
00:01:37.170 --> 00:01:39.570
And, [COUGH] that's how we connect to it,
right?

29
00:01:39.570 --> 00:01:40.620
That's it's address.

30
00:01:40.620 --> 00:01:42.400
That's how it sends and receives data.

31
00:01:42.400 --> 00:01:44.400
That's how it's unique on the network.

32
00:01:44.400 --> 00:01:46.380
But computers can multitask.

33
00:01:46.380 --> 00:01:48.710
We can have more than one thing
going on at the same time.

34
00:01:48.710 --> 00:01:52.250
So when that traffic is coming in you
might have your browser opened up.

35
00:01:52.250 --> 00:01:56.040
You might have your
email client opened up.

36
00:01:56.040 --> 00:01:57.190
What else might you be doing?

37
00:01:57.190 --> 00:01:59.310
You're doing a terminal session somewhere.

38
00:01:59.310 --> 00:02:02.240
All these different applications
are sending data across the network.

39
00:02:02.240 --> 00:02:05.716
How does it know when those packets
are coming in, that it should go to your

40
00:02:05.716 --> 00:02:08.648
browser or this packet should
go to your email client, okay?

41
00:02:08.648 --> 00:02:13.512
And that port number, that's gonna
tell us that we have 65,000 run,

42
00:02:13.512 --> 00:02:14.762
535-
>> Six.

43
00:02:14.762 --> 00:02:15.424
>> 36.

44
00:02:15.424 --> 00:02:21.930
65,536 port numbers which you can
think of as sub-addresses, right?

45
00:02:21.930 --> 00:02:27.300
Take your IP address [COUGH] just for
example, 10.10.1.2,

46
00:02:27.300 --> 00:02:31.928
that's your IP address colon and
then say 80, right, or

47
00:02:31.928 --> 00:02:36.393
21, or 22, or 3396,
whatever the case may be.

48
00:02:36.393 --> 00:02:41.193
Each one of those is an attachment point
or a way that I can generate a socket,

49
00:02:41.193 --> 00:02:43.450
I guess would be a good way to say it.

50
00:02:43.450 --> 00:02:45.290
Cuz when we talk about a socket,

51
00:02:45.290 --> 00:02:48.560
a connection between two computers,
it's three things we need.

52
00:02:48.560 --> 00:02:50.380
We need the protocol that we're gonna use.

53
00:02:50.380 --> 00:02:51.640
The IP address.

54
00:02:51.640 --> 00:02:54.670
And the port number,
that we're gonna connect to, all right?

55
00:02:54.670 --> 00:02:57.677
So when we talk about computer security,

56
00:02:57.677 --> 00:03:01.260
we've got 65,500 [INAUDIBLE]
yada yada ports.

57
00:03:01.260 --> 00:03:02.990
We wanna close all those down.

58
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:05.770
We use firewalls to close those up and

59
00:03:05.770 --> 00:03:09.140
then as we run more services,
we need to open some of those up.

60
00:03:09.140 --> 00:03:10.810
Like when you run DNS.

61
00:03:10.810 --> 00:03:12.430
Port 53 gets opened up.

62
00:03:12.430 --> 00:03:15.770
When you run a web server,
we typically open up, say, port 80 or

63
00:03:15.770 --> 00:03:18.740
if it's secure it's 443, right?

64
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:22.540
So we have to make those
holes in those firewalls.

65
00:03:22.540 --> 00:03:25.210
Well, if we can look at a machine and

66
00:03:25.210 --> 00:03:28.920
see what ports are open,
we get a few things out of that.

67
00:03:28.920 --> 00:03:30.340
We can, one,

68
00:03:30.340 --> 00:03:34.910
probably determine what services
are running on that machine, right?

69
00:03:34.910 --> 00:03:38.870
If I see port 53 open, there's a good
chance that that machine is running

70
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:43.070
the DNS Server service and
we can interrogate that port and

71
00:03:43.070 --> 00:03:45.540
get a little more information
about that service.

72
00:03:45.540 --> 00:03:49.560
We can use that information as
well the way it responds when we

73
00:03:49.560 --> 00:03:51.420
do try to communicate with a port.

74
00:03:51.420 --> 00:03:55.330
If the port's closed it responds one way,
if the port's open it responds another

75
00:03:55.330 --> 00:04:01.110
way, and different operating systems
respond differently to open versus closed.

76
00:04:01.110 --> 00:04:04.390
And so we can even use this information
to start trying to figure out maybe

77
00:04:04.390 --> 00:04:06.610
what operating system is running.

78
00:04:06.610 --> 00:04:10.500
So a lot of information can be
gleaned by doing port scans.

79
00:04:10.500 --> 00:04:13.720
And the bad guys, they're looking for
doorways in, right?

80
00:04:13.720 --> 00:04:15.580
And so they're looking for open ports.

81
00:04:15.580 --> 00:04:17.670
They're looking to see what
services you're running.

82
00:04:17.670 --> 00:04:20.520
And they're hoping they can
compromise some of those services.

83
00:04:20.520 --> 00:04:24.780
>> Now Mike, I really don't know if
I've actually addressed this before but

84
00:04:24.780 --> 00:04:26.820
let's talk about this just for
a moment before running in Nmap,

85
00:04:26.820 --> 00:04:29.570
let's just say that somebody has
just tuned into this show and

86
00:04:29.570 --> 00:04:31.720
even though they might
not have a lot knowledge,

87
00:04:31.720 --> 00:04:34.460
they're probably saying all
right I wanna start using Nmap.

88
00:04:34.460 --> 00:04:38.440
Do they need to be on the same physical
network as the machine that they're

89
00:04:38.440 --> 00:04:41.650
taking look at, or it this certain
that they can do just from their home?

90
00:04:41.650 --> 00:04:43.920
>> Well,
you do have to be able to make in a,

91
00:04:43.920 --> 00:04:47.030
you gonna be sending packets
to each one of those ports,

92
00:04:47.030 --> 00:04:50.830
which ever port we choose to scan, so you
do have that connectivity, and have you

93
00:04:50.830 --> 00:04:54.905
got routing between there if it's a public
IP address which you're trying to scan,

94
00:04:54.905 --> 00:05:00.155
I can sit at home and I can scan,
say Microsoft servers or ITProTV servers.

95
00:05:00.155 --> 00:05:02.495
Because they have a public IP address and
they have to, right?

96
00:05:02.495 --> 00:05:05.155
They want the public to
come to their website.

97
00:05:05.155 --> 00:05:08.815
So from my home inside,
I can scan those machines.

98
00:05:08.815 --> 00:05:13.425
Now, my ISP might have a problem with that
because they can see that kind of traffic

99
00:05:13.425 --> 00:05:17.310
and they see packets coming out port,
port, port, port, port.

100
00:05:17.310 --> 00:05:18.810
They know what's going on.

101
00:05:18.810 --> 00:05:20.791
They can see that traffic and
then like,hey guys,

102
00:05:20.791 --> 00:05:22.060
the guy is doing port scanning.

103
00:05:22.060 --> 00:05:25.370
And if you keep doing enough of them to
especially the people that you shouldn't

104
00:05:25.370 --> 00:05:25.950
be scanning.

105
00:05:25.950 --> 00:05:28.130
Cuz you don't own them or have permission.

106
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:30.097
Your ISP could send you a nastygram.

107
00:05:30.097 --> 00:05:30.990
Microsoft's gonna talk to them,

108
00:05:30.990 --> 00:05:34.940
they're gonna talk to you and
you might get the nastygram in the mail.

109
00:05:36.600 --> 00:05:39.120
All right.
So yes, you can scan across the internet.

110
00:05:39.120 --> 00:05:41.610
Assuming the other end again is reachable.

111
00:05:41.610 --> 00:05:44.490
If I'm internal,
I can scan Ronnie's machine.

112
00:05:44.490 --> 00:05:48.140
He's got a private IP address but
I'm on the same network as him, right?

113
00:05:48.140 --> 00:05:49.500
Or if he's on a different subnet,

114
00:05:49.500 --> 00:05:52.920
I probably have routing going
on in my internal network.

115
00:05:52.920 --> 00:05:56.180
So as long as we can route the packets
there, sure we can do those scans.

116
00:05:56.180 --> 00:05:58.120
But that traffic can be blocked, too.

117
00:05:58.120 --> 00:05:59.780
>> And Mike,
I just wanted to make that point.

118
00:05:59.780 --> 00:06:02.340
Sometimes people do tune
into these shows and

119
00:06:02.340 --> 00:06:04.860
even though they might not
be the hacker in order.

120
00:06:04.860 --> 00:06:07.380
Mike that sounds like a great tool,
I'm gonna use this.

121
00:06:07.380 --> 00:06:10.690
Let me just start scanning
right out from my home and,

122
00:06:10.690 --> 00:06:13.110
the ISP is not gonna mind
if I start doing this.

123
00:06:13.110 --> 00:06:15.750
So you've gotta be a little
bit careful sometimes.

124
00:06:15.750 --> 00:06:18.803
So don't do this unless you have
permission, is what I would say at least,

125
00:06:18.803 --> 00:06:19.977
from your home, practice.

126
00:06:19.977 --> 00:06:23.101
[LAUGH]
>> Absolutely, this is one of those areas,

127
00:06:23.101 --> 00:06:26.861
and I don't wanna get too far off
track with laws and things like that,

128
00:06:26.861 --> 00:06:30.492
because it varies from state to state,
from country to country, so

129
00:06:30.492 --> 00:06:33.510
your laws where you live
are gonna be different from me.

130
00:06:33.510 --> 00:06:39.800
And it's all very new, so sometimes
the laws take a little while to catch up.

131
00:06:39.800 --> 00:06:41.880
So this is little bit of a gray area.

132
00:06:41.880 --> 00:06:44.190
I used to use an analogy where,

133
00:06:44.190 --> 00:06:47.090
lets say your walking down
a strip mall that was closed.

134
00:06:47.090 --> 00:06:48.725
You know, strip malls here in the US,

135
00:06:48.725 --> 00:06:53.390
where all the stores have their
own store front on the outside.

136
00:06:53.390 --> 00:06:56.040
Let's say your just walking down, or
an apartment complex or something, and

137
00:06:56.040 --> 00:06:59.140
your just walking along and
tugging on each one of the doors.

138
00:06:59.140 --> 00:07:02.083
And they're all locked and
a police officer comes up and says, hey,

139
00:07:02.083 --> 00:07:02.957
what are you doing?

140
00:07:02.957 --> 00:07:05.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> Can you get in trouble for doing that?

141
00:07:05.960 --> 00:07:10.360
Not taking into consideration trespassing
or anything like that, right, but as far

142
00:07:10.360 --> 00:07:15.270
as the pulling on the doors well, you
didn't get in, right, the door was locked.

143
00:07:16.660 --> 00:07:21.470
So you really didn't break any laws
at this point and even if the door

144
00:07:21.470 --> 00:07:26.800
was open and you open it and
then closed it, did you really break in.

145
00:07:26.800 --> 00:07:34.395
And that is where that gray area comes
in because we can't prosecute on intent.

146
00:07:34.395 --> 00:07:37.125
We all know that if you find that door
open, you're probably gonna go in and

147
00:07:37.125 --> 00:07:37.965
take something.

148
00:07:37.965 --> 00:07:41.812
But, since you haven't done that yet,
I can't really charge you.

149
00:07:41.812 --> 00:07:45.400
It's the same way with port scanning, when
you're doing port scanning against public

150
00:07:45.400 --> 00:07:48.516
entities or stuff that you don't own,
there's a reason you're doing it.

151
00:07:48.516 --> 00:07:52.180
You're not doing it for just fun,
you're trying to find an open port and

152
00:07:52.180 --> 00:07:56.025
maybe you can take advantage of that but
the problem is the port scan itself,

153
00:07:56.025 --> 00:07:58.276
you haven't really crossed that line yet.

154
00:07:58.276 --> 00:08:02.822
So legally maybe maybe not can
you get in trouble for it.

155
00:08:02.822 --> 00:08:04.790
But can your ISP get you in trouble?

156
00:08:04.790 --> 00:08:05.860
Absolutely.

157
00:08:05.860 --> 00:08:07.376
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's their network and

158
00:08:07.376 --> 00:08:10.430
if they don't want you doing port scans
across their network they can tell you no.

159
00:08:10.430 --> 00:08:14.110
So listen to what Ronnie is saying.

160
00:08:14.110 --> 00:08:15.080
>> Ask for permissions.

161
00:08:15.080 --> 00:08:18.666
>> Yes you do this in places that
you have written permission or

162
00:08:18.666 --> 00:08:22.481
you own the systems and
you can give yourself that permission.

163
00:08:22.481 --> 00:08:26.723
But then you've gotta think about the
networks that you're crossing too because

164
00:08:26.723 --> 00:08:31.330
we can end up generating a lot of traffic,
and even though I might own that system.

165
00:08:31.330 --> 00:08:34.463
I could be bogging down the network
that's effecting other people, right.

166
00:08:34.463 --> 00:08:38.470
If we're talking about cloud based
systems and things like that.

167
00:08:38.470 --> 00:08:41.279
I start doing heavy port scans
across lots of machines and

168
00:08:41.279 --> 00:08:45.316
all of the sudden other customers that
are paying this company for their service,

169
00:08:45.316 --> 00:08:48.608
they can't meet their SLA because
I'm taking all the bandwidth.

170
00:08:48.608 --> 00:08:50.631
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now they're gonna be upset with me,

171
00:08:50.631 --> 00:08:53.229
they're gonna say what the heck are you
doing you can't be doing these port scan.

172
00:08:53.229 --> 00:08:58.082
So legally I don't know but
you really wanna be careful with it.

173
00:08:58.082 --> 00:09:01.845
All right so now let's talk about N Map
and let's see what we've got here.

174
00:09:01.845 --> 00:09:06.596
N Map will run on just about anything,
they've got a port for

175
00:09:06.596 --> 00:09:10.425
it for Kali, for Linux,
for Windows, for Mac.

176
00:09:10.425 --> 00:09:12.740
And there's two versions.

177
00:09:12.740 --> 00:09:15.380
There's the shell version,
the command line version.

178
00:09:15.380 --> 00:09:18.543
And there's also a GUI
version known as Zenmap.

179
00:09:18.543 --> 00:09:22.986
You can go out to nmap.org and you can
download the Linux binary and in Kali,

180
00:09:22.986 --> 00:09:24.941
of course, it comes installed.

181
00:09:24.941 --> 00:09:28.959
Both of them, the command line and
the GUI version.

182
00:09:28.959 --> 00:09:31.210
Well we'll play with
the command line version.

183
00:09:31.210 --> 00:09:32.190
I do wanna show you the GUI.

184
00:09:32.190 --> 00:09:36.030
Because it's a great way
to learn how to use nmap.

185
00:09:36.030 --> 00:09:39.670
So let's take a look at my screen and
let's talk about some of the options.

186
00:09:39.670 --> 00:09:43.020
What I'm gonna do is just type in nmap and

187
00:09:43.020 --> 00:09:45.740
I'll do a -h and
we'll get their basic help.

188
00:09:45.740 --> 00:09:50.180
You could also do a man nmap and
get the manual pages and get

189
00:09:50.180 --> 00:09:54.740
a lot more examples and a lot more help
with this, but this'll get us started.

190
00:09:54.740 --> 00:09:58.040
When we look at this there's a few things
were going to want to pay attention to.

191
00:09:58.040 --> 00:09:59.675
First of all is the usage.

192
00:09:59.675 --> 00:10:03.040
nmap your scan type or types,

193
00:10:03.040 --> 00:10:07.700
any options that you want to include and
then your target specifications.

194
00:10:07.700 --> 00:10:11.020
So when we run nmap, there's really
three things we gotta think about.

195
00:10:11.020 --> 00:10:14.980
What type of scan do I wanna do and we'll
talk about the different ones here in

196
00:10:14.980 --> 00:10:18.840
a minute, what options do I want to go
along with that scan, like speed and

197
00:10:18.840 --> 00:10:20.480
some other things and we'll show you.

198
00:10:20.480 --> 00:10:22.090
And then who am I scanning?

199
00:10:22.090 --> 00:10:26.810
What is my target or targets,
cuz we can scan multiple machines.

200
00:10:26.810 --> 00:10:30.700
When it comes to target specification,
you can do it in any number of ways.

201
00:10:30.700 --> 00:10:31.933
I can use host names.

202
00:10:31.933 --> 00:10:35.700
This is gonna rely on DNS to resolve so
that's something you got to think about,

203
00:10:35.700 --> 00:10:39.020
if you don't have name resolution for
the network you're scanning,

204
00:10:39.020 --> 00:10:41.060
better off going with maybe IP addresses.

205
00:10:41.060 --> 00:10:46.370
Which you can also use networks if you
wanna scan entire ranges of IP addresses.

206
00:10:46.370 --> 00:10:50.236
So you could see different examples
here whether you using DNS names,

207
00:10:50.236 --> 00:10:52.804
here they're doing Microsoft.com/24.

208
00:10:52.804 --> 00:10:57.650
That's something you don't see that often
a DNS name with a cite or notation on it.

209
00:10:57.650 --> 00:11:01.690
Or you can do single IP addresses, or
notice here they're actually doing a range

210
00:11:01.690 --> 00:11:04.760
of IP addresses and
this is actually an interesting one.

211
00:11:04.760 --> 00:11:11.428
Look closely at that,
first octet is 10, second octet is 0,

212
00:11:11.428 --> 00:11:16.996
third octet 0-255 fourth octet, 1-254.

213
00:11:16.996 --> 00:11:21.609
What this is gonna do is it's
gonna scan all addresses in this

214
00:11:21.609 --> 00:11:23.604
range within this octet.

215
00:11:23.604 --> 00:11:25.690
It'll go from 0 to 255.

216
00:11:25.690 --> 00:11:26.930
This one only 1 to 254.

217
00:11:26.930 --> 00:11:30.936
Which means I won't be scanning
anything that ends in a 0, or

218
00:11:30.936 --> 00:11:33.411
anything that ends in a 255 right?

219
00:11:33.411 --> 00:11:36.967
That's pretty cool the way you can use
a range within an octet like that,

220
00:11:36.967 --> 00:11:39.122
cuz we know that 0 is
our network address and

221
00:11:39.122 --> 00:11:43.560
255 is gonna be our broadcast address,
typically don't wanna scan those.

222
00:11:43.560 --> 00:11:44.517
We can also use a list.

223

00:12:59.850 --> 00:13:06.939

00:13:06.939 --> 00:13:11.247

it tries to talk to each one of those IP

247
00:13:11.247 --> 00:13:14.396
address, sends out a ping,
and see which ones are live.

248
00:13:14.396 --> 00:13:18.668
And then once it has determined
which IP addresses out of that

249
00:13:18.668 --> 00:13:23.545
entire subnet are live or responding,
it's only gonna scan those.

250
00:13:23.545 --> 00:13:27.436
Why waste your time scanning IP
addresses that are not turned on or

251
00:13:27.436 --> 00:13:29.570
not assigned to anything, right.

252
00:13:29.570 --> 00:13:35.060
So that's the way Mmap works by default,
is it does a discovery phase.

253
00:13:35.060 --> 00:13:39.210
And then it goes through the scan phase.

00:13:39.210 --> 00:13:44.819
You can do a, [COUGH] The one I wanna

282
00:15:24.160 --> 00:15:27.010
And if we think back to
the way TCPIP works.

283
00:15:27.010 --> 00:15:31.202
When you make a connection there's
something known as a TCP 3 way hand shake

284
00:15:31.202 --> 00:15:35.198
where you send out a send packet to
whoever you're trying to connect to,

285
00:15:35.198 --> 00:15:38.819
they respond to your send with an ACK
as well as a send of their end.

286
00:15:38.819 --> 00:15:42.275
So they send back what's called
a SYN-ACK packet and then you respond

287
00:15:42.275 --> 00:15:46.330
with a final ack to their synchronization
request, their send packet.

288
00:15:46.330 --> 00:15:49.690
And that's the three packets
that form the handshake and

289
00:15:49.690 --> 00:15:52.288
now you have established a TCP connection.

290
00:15:52.288 --> 00:15:57.342
A sS scan or a syn scan sends the syn,
waits to see if you get the SYN-ACK

291
00:15:57.342 --> 00:16:01.727
back But then never responds
with its own acknowledgement.

292
00:16:01.727 --> 00:16:05.377
Never fully establishes
the three way handshake and so

293
00:16:05.377 --> 00:16:08.400
hopefully it's not
logged on the other end.

294
00:16:08.400 --> 00:16:11.870
That was the theory or
the working, I mean it did,

295
00:16:11.870 --> 00:16:14.680
it would not usually it's
a good way to say it.

00:16:14.680 --> 00:16:18.940
Back in the day we might of been
able to get away with that right?

297
00:16:18.940 --> 00:16:23.410
But now everything's logged and
it's not nearly as stealthy.

00:16:23.410 --> 00:16:26.570

00:25:21.980 --> 00:25:27.810
But the idea is hopefully, we might
be able to not trigger that IDS IPS.

444
00:25:27.810 --> 00:25:33.615
It doesn't see it as a barrage of
connect request to every single port.

445
00:25:33.615 --> 00:25:39.501
[SOUND] It's a request here,
a request there, could be normal traffic.

446
00:25:39.501 --> 00:25:40.769
That's the idea, anyway.

447
00:25:43.340 --> 00:25:47.050
There are ways to spoof source
addresses and things like that.

448
00:25:47.050 --> 00:25:50.260
Cuz in the end, I'll tell you,
they're gonna figure it out.

449
00:25:50.260 --> 00:25:53.610
They're gonna see where,
hey, this IP address has

450
00:25:53.610 --> 00:25:58.800
sent 65,535 requests to this
server over the last two hours.

451
00:25:58.800 --> 00:26:01.398
And interestingly enough,
each one is to a different port.

452
00:26:01.398 --> 00:26:04.794
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hm, I wonder what's going on there.

453
00:26:04.794 --> 00:26:09.870
So [LAUGH] again, don't think you're
gonna avoid detection altogether.

454
00:26:09.870 --> 00:26:11.370
That's where that decoy comes in.

455
00:26:11.370 --> 00:26:14.070
Maybe we'll do that in one
of our more advanced shows.

456
00:26:14.070 --> 00:26:17.090
What else do we need to talk about here,
Ronnie?

457
00:26:17.090 --> 00:26:20.519
The last little section,
I believe, is our output.

458
00:26:20.519 --> 00:26:26.920
And the output is another
great little option here.

459
00:26:26.920 --> 00:26:29.460
With the output,
normally when you run Nmap,

460
00:26:29.460 --> 00:26:32.870
it's gonna output to standard outcome and
right there to your terminal.

461
00:26:32.870 --> 00:26:36.336
A lot of times, I wanna save
that either for documentation.

462
00:26:36.336 --> 00:26:39.533
Because I'm doing a penetration test and
I need this for

463
00:26:39.533 --> 00:26:43.150
my report at the end of this test or
for me for future reference.

464
00:26:43.150 --> 00:26:46.086
I don't want to scan that machine
every time I come back to it,

465
00:26:46.086 --> 00:26:48.467
I'm trying to work on
getting into that machine.

466
00:26:48.467 --> 00:26:52.410
So we can output the scan
results into a file.

467
00:26:52.410 --> 00:26:55.980
Also some tools,
Nmap is again a very popular tool.

468
00:26:55.980 --> 00:26:57.865
And there's several other tools.

469
00:26:57.865 --> 00:27:02.070
Nikto being one,
a web application vulnerability scanner.

470
00:27:02.070 --> 00:27:04.804
I can actually take the Nmap output and

471
00:27:04.804 --> 00:27:08.236
I can feed it right into
Nikto with one command.

472
00:27:08.236 --> 00:27:12.905
I can do a scan of an entire network
searching for port 80 and 443.

473
00:27:12.905 --> 00:27:16.638
Any IP addresses that have those ports
open, you dump right into Nikto.

474
00:27:16.638 --> 00:27:22.373
And it immediately begins doing
a vulnerability scan on those web servers.

475
00:27:22.373 --> 00:27:24.911
So being able to output this is fantastic.

476
00:27:24.911 --> 00:27:26.539
And again, outputting it to files.

477
00:27:26.539 --> 00:27:30.360
There's normal, there's XML.

478
00:27:30.360 --> 00:27:32.760
I will tell you, Ronnie,
that I was excited about his.

479
00:27:32.760 --> 00:27:36.070
I wasn't aware of the script
kiddie output the OS.

480
00:27:36.070 --> 00:27:39.410
For a long time, I've tried it and
I have not been successful.

481
00:27:39.410 --> 00:27:41.650
It's supposed to put it out in leet speak,

482
00:27:41.650 --> 00:27:44.920
just a little joke that he
added to the code there.

483
00:27:44.920 --> 00:27:46.500
I haven't got it to work.

484
00:27:46.500 --> 00:27:48.570
If anybody out there has any suggestions,
let me know.

485
00:27:48.570 --> 00:27:51.230
I haven't spent a lot of time on it,
but it would be cool to see.

486
00:27:51.230 --> 00:27:53.750
My favorite one is the grepable one.

487
00:27:53.750 --> 00:27:56.016
That's gonna put me out
in grepable format.

488
00:27:56.016 --> 00:27:57.455
That's fun to say.

489
00:27:57.455 --> 00:27:58.280
>> Grepable.

490
00:27:58.280 --> 00:28:00.990
>> Yeah, but I can use grep with it.

491
00:28:00.990 --> 00:28:05.750
It aligns everything in columns so
I can grep it and cut it.

492
00:28:05.750 --> 00:28:08.294
And I'll show you a great technique for

493
00:28:08.294 --> 00:28:13.240
generating a list that I can then turn
around and bring right back into Nmap.

494
00:28:13.240 --> 00:28:19.950
And then two more, I think,
v, lowercase v for verbosity.

495
00:28:19.950 --> 00:28:21.890
This is just gonna give
you more information,

496
00:28:21.890 --> 00:28:23.870
which is typically what we want.

497
00:28:23.870 --> 00:28:29.168
You can use a double v for
even more verbosity.

498
00:28:29.168 --> 00:28:32.230
The reason why I don't use that
often because usually, it's gonna

499
00:28:32.230 --> 00:28:36.120
tell me anyway, but displays the reason
a port is in a particular state.

500
00:28:36.120 --> 00:28:39.150
Whether it didn't respond or
it thinks it's filtered.

501
00:28:39.150 --> 00:28:40.880
And then this one is cool, too.

502
00:28:40.880 --> 00:28:44.260
This is a fun one to play around with,
especially as you're learning and

503
00:28:44.260 --> 00:28:45.335
getting familiar with it.

504
00:28:45.335 --> 00:28:49.780
--packet-trace show all packets sent and
received.

505
00:28:49.780 --> 00:28:52.517
So I can actually see what
Nmap is sending out and

506
00:28:52.517 --> 00:28:55.260
what that target is sending
back as a response.

507
00:28:55.260 --> 00:28:58.370
And I can capture that in a file and
go back and analyze it.

508
00:28:58.370 --> 00:28:59.560
Pretty cool there.

509
00:29:01.490 --> 00:29:05.730
And I believe that is all of the syntax

510
00:29:05.730 --> 00:29:10.050
that we are going to at least
use in these next Nmap episodes.

511
00:29:10.050 --> 00:29:11.180
But Ronnie's giving me the signal.

512
00:29:11.180 --> 00:29:14.540
And it looks like I have taken an entire
episode just to go through the options.

513
00:29:15.620 --> 00:29:19.600
>> All right, Mike, well, thank you again
for helping us at least to be able to

514
00:29:19.600 --> 00:29:23.010
see all the options that we
have available inside of Nmap.

515
00:29:23.010 --> 00:29:27.080
It is one of the fundamental tools that
we'll tend to actually be able to use

516
00:29:27.080 --> 00:29:29.450
to help us especially in getting started.

517
00:29:29.450 --> 00:29:32.000
And don't think that this
is all that there is to it.

518
00:29:32.000 --> 00:29:34.070
Mike has really only
scratched the surface.

519
00:29:34.070 --> 00:29:34.980
I know it sounds strange.

520
00:29:34.980 --> 00:29:37.300
He went through the entire list of syntax.

521
00:29:37.300 --> 00:29:40.690
But there's actually more that you can do
once you understand the combinations of

522
00:29:40.690 --> 00:29:43.280
things that can end up happening here.

523
00:29:43.280 --> 00:29:45.992
So that means that we'll
have another show.

524
00:29:45.992 --> 00:29:47.804
And Mike will show us, of course,

525
00:29:47.804 --> 00:29:50.753
how to actually get some of
these tools working in Nmap.

526
00:29:50.753 --> 00:29:53.200
And that way,
we'll actually see how it actually works.

527
00:29:53.200 --> 00:29:54.710
But that's for another episode.

528
00:29:54.710 --> 00:29:58.820
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

529
00:29:58.820 --> 00:29:59.790
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

530
00:29:59.790 --> 00:30:03.386
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Kali Linux shows.

531
00:30:03.386 --> 00:30:09.439
[MUSIC]

532
00:30:09.439 --> 00:30:12.588
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike finish looking at the basic functionality of the Nmap port/network scanner. Here they demonstrate performing common scan types like versioning(-sV), OS guessing(-O), ping sweeping(-sn), and using lists(-iL).
episodes.title: Nmap Basics Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.065 --> 00:00:03.221
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.221 --> 00:00:06.738
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.738 --> 00:00:08.235
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.235 --> 00:00:12.202
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:12.202 --> 00:00:14.251
>> All right, greeting everyone, and

6
00:00:14.251 --> 00:00:16.836
welcome to another great
episode of IT Pro TV.

7
00:00:16.836 --> 00:00:20.912
I'm your host, what would have been
Ronnie Wong, but I'm filling in for

8
00:00:20.912 --> 00:00:22.107
the Rongster today.

9
00:00:22.107 --> 00:00:25.959
I am your host, Daniel Lowrie,
we're having a good time here at IT Pro TV

10
00:00:25.959 --> 00:00:29.575
because today we're coming at you
more with our Kali Linux series.

11
00:00:29.575 --> 00:00:31.409
And it's been a lot of fun,
I know Mike and

12
00:00:31.409 --> 00:00:34.940
all the other hosts that have been
sitting in on it have had a great time.

13
00:00:34.940 --> 00:00:39.280
I'm really excited to be here today, today
we're continuing in on our Nmap basics.

14
00:00:39.280 --> 00:00:43.154
Obviously joining me in the studio,
the master himself, Mr.

15
00:00:43.154 --> 00:00:44.950
Micheal Roderick, Mike how's it going sir?

16
00:00:44.950 --> 00:00:46.746
>> Wait wait wait,
if you can be somebody else can't I be?

17
00:00:46.746 --> 00:00:47.818
I wannabe Don Pezet.

18
00:00:47.818 --> 00:00:49.720
>> You can if you want,
yeah, sweet, he's smart.

19
00:00:49.720 --> 00:00:50.579
>> Hey, can I get a raise?

20
00:00:50.579 --> 00:00:51.935
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Thanks for

21
00:00:51.935 --> 00:00:54.870
having me back Daniel, glad to be here.

22
00:00:54.870 --> 00:00:56.010
Thank you for hosting,
filling in for Ronnie today.

23
00:00:56.010 --> 00:00:57.180
>> Yeah, no problem, no problem.

24
00:00:58.360 --> 00:01:01.380
>> And, yeah, in our previous episode,
hopefully you watched that already.

25
00:01:01.380 --> 00:01:04.900
We went through Nmap and we took a look
at the man page and the help file.

26
00:01:04.900 --> 00:01:07.420
And we just talked about a lot
of the different options and

27
00:01:07.420 --> 00:01:10.190
switches that are available,
right, there was a lot to it.

28
00:01:10.190 --> 00:01:12.820
If we just scratch the surface,
there's many,

29
00:01:12.820 --> 00:01:17.090
many more parameter or
switches that we can use with it.

30
00:01:17.090 --> 00:01:21.010
You can start combining them in creative
ways and really get some meat out.

31
00:01:21.010 --> 00:01:23.100
But for now, we're just again,
we're gonna stick with the basics.

32
00:01:23.100 --> 00:01:26.920
So, now that we've talked about all that
and we understand what those options are.

33
00:01:26.920 --> 00:01:29.890
Let's take a look at actually
using them and compare the output,

34
00:01:29.890 --> 00:01:32.701
see what kind of information
we're going to be getting back.

35
00:01:32.701 --> 00:01:35.423
So let's take a look at my screen here,

36
00:01:35.423 --> 00:01:40.730
we will just start off by doing a simple
scan and let's test Nmaps defaults.

37
00:01:40.730 --> 00:01:43.093
All right, l'm just gonna type nmap and

38
00:01:43.093 --> 00:01:48.940
then 10.10.103 the IP address that l
want to scan, so single lP address.

39
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:54.460
No options, no switches, no nothing,
Nmap target specification, all right.

40
00:01:54.460 --> 00:01:57.835
So we'll let this go for a minute, and
you'll see that it's pretty darn quick,

41
00:01:57.835 --> 00:02:02.458
8.2 seconds it took to scan this machine,
all right.

42
00:02:02.458 --> 00:02:06.650
Now what we'll wanna pay attention to,
besides all the open ports and

43
00:02:06.650 --> 00:02:07.435
all the good stuff.

44
00:02:07.435 --> 00:02:10.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is this is right here,

45
00:02:10.420 --> 00:02:12.630
977 closed ports.

46
00:02:12.630 --> 00:02:16.743
There's about, well not about,
there are 33 open ports.

47
00:02:16.743 --> 00:02:19.451
Yeah, I counted them before
just top verify that.

48
00:02:19.451 --> 00:02:21.381
So 977 plus 33 Daniel?

49
00:02:21.381 --> 00:02:22.275
>> Equals 1,000.

50
00:02:22.275 --> 00:02:23.576
>> Equals 1,000, right?

51
00:02:23.576 --> 00:02:24.388
Did I do that math right?

52
00:02:24.388 --> 00:02:25.520
>> I think so, yeah.

53
00:02:25.520 --> 00:02:28.860
>> Yeah, right, I think so, and
so, remember we talked about,

54
00:02:28.860 --> 00:02:30.712
well, you don't remember
cuz you weren't here.

55
00:02:30.712 --> 00:02:31.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we've talked about,

56
00:02:31.570 --> 00:02:32.890
we've talked about it before.

57
00:02:32.890 --> 00:02:34.976
>> We have.
>> The whole top ports option, and

58
00:02:34.976 --> 00:02:36.475
that is a default in Nmap.

59
00:02:36.475 --> 00:02:39.581
Remember I said if you do
the dash dash top dash ports,

60
00:02:39.581 --> 00:02:41.383
you can specify a port number.

61
00:02:41.383 --> 00:02:45.545
But by default it does
the 1,000 top ports and

62
00:02:45.545 --> 00:02:49.550
that gets 93% of TCP 95% of UDP ports.

63
00:02:49.550 --> 00:02:55.742
So it's really efficient, it's quick and
it gets over 90% of the ports.

64
00:02:55.742 --> 00:02:59.440
If we look at this time though,
8 seconds to do that, and

65
00:02:59.440 --> 00:03:01.607
we start doing our math, right.

66
00:03:01.607 --> 00:03:05.580
What if I wanna do all 65,000 ports,
let's average it out.

67
00:03:05.580 --> 00:03:08.910
We'll say it took 10 seconds to do 1,000.

68
00:03:08.910 --> 00:03:13.744
So then I've gotta multiply that
10 seconds by 65 because there's

69
00:03:13.744 --> 00:03:15.670
65,000 ports.

70
00:03:15.670 --> 00:03:19.028
And so that comes out to-
>> Two plus two is chicken.

71
00:03:19.028 --> 00:03:19.962
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly.

72
00:03:19.962 --> 00:03:21.605
>> It's a lot.
>> It ends up taking 20,

73
00:03:21.605 --> 00:03:26.450
30 minutes to scan all 65,000 ports and
this is why we don't normally,

74
00:03:26.450 --> 00:03:30.018
at least in the beginning,
scan all 65,000 ports.

75
00:03:30.018 --> 00:03:33.100
There are gonna be times we need
to do that and we just let it run.

76
00:03:33.100 --> 00:03:36.260
But your initial scans
are usually exploratory, right.

77
00:03:36.260 --> 00:03:38.124
We're doing our initial reconnaissance,

78
00:03:38.124 --> 00:03:42.220
wanna see what's out there,
find our juicy targets if you will.

79
00:03:42.220 --> 00:03:43.780
And then we can focus in on those and

80
00:03:43.780 --> 00:03:46.480
do some of those more intensive,
deeper scans.

81
00:03:46.480 --> 00:03:50.970
So default scan is gonna do, remember it
does the little s big S, the dash sS,

82
00:03:52.010 --> 00:03:57.570
if you're running as administrator or
in our case root in our Linux systems.

83
00:03:57.570 --> 00:04:01.440
Because we've talked about
the dash s capital S and

84
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:04.710
that's a syn scan where it's
sending out a syn packet.

85
00:04:04.710 --> 00:04:08.600
It gets a packet back that has the syn and
the ACK flag raised but

86
00:04:08.600 --> 00:04:11.140
it does not respond with the final ACK.

87
00:04:11.140 --> 00:04:13.715
To do that,
you're actually rewriting package.

88
00:04:13.715 --> 00:04:18.080
You're kinda breaking the rules a little
bit not doing what it normally does and

89
00:04:18.080 --> 00:04:21.900
for that to do custom package
you need root permissions.

90
00:04:21.900 --> 00:04:26.204
If you're to run Nmap as a standard user,
then just type Nmap and a IP address,

91
00:04:26.204 --> 00:04:28.630
it would actually do little s and
capital T.

92
00:04:28.630 --> 00:04:33.080
It would do the full three way handshake,
all right.

93
00:04:33.080 --> 00:04:36.820
Results would be the same most likely,
a little bit noisier on the network.

94
00:04:36.820 --> 00:04:39.240
Might take a little bit longer
cuz you're waiting for that or

95
00:04:39.240 --> 00:04:40.795
you're sending that final acknowledgment,
all right.

96
00:04:40.795 --> 00:04:44.050
So that's our basic default scan,

97
00:04:44.050 --> 00:04:48.360
now we get great information here, it's
showing me what parts are open, all right.

98
00:04:48.360 --> 00:04:52.673
I can see TCP 20 and 21 and
all the way down the list there.

99
00:04:52.673 --> 00:04:57.280
And then out next to that it's telling me
what service is on those ports, all right.

100
00:04:57.280 --> 00:05:01.276
So port 21 is ftp, port 80 is running htp,

101
00:05:01.276 --> 00:05:05.690
2049 nfs, got vnc way down there on 5900.

102
00:05:05.690 --> 00:05:08.160
So we can see some basic
service information.

103
00:05:08.160 --> 00:05:11.100
Hey, there's vnc running on this port.

104
00:05:11.100 --> 00:05:14.030
Doesn't give me a lot of
additional information though.

105
00:05:14.030 --> 00:05:18.510
And one of the great things about Nmap is
it can do a deeper interrogation on those

106
00:05:18.510 --> 00:05:21.230
ports to figure out some
version information or

107
00:05:21.230 --> 00:05:23.880
attempt to give me some
version information.

108
00:05:23.880 --> 00:05:26.010
And with that version information,

109
00:05:26.010 --> 00:05:27.980
now we're in business cuz
we can start looking for

110
00:05:27.980 --> 00:05:32.099
known exploits for that particular version
of a service that's running on a port.

111
00:05:33.190 --> 00:05:38.079
And if we remember from our previous
episode, let me clear that screen up

112
00:05:38.079 --> 00:05:42.178
a little bit ,we're gonna do
a dash little s, upper case V.

113
00:05:42.178 --> 00:05:49.410
So let's do nmap- sV and then our IP
address again, and see what happens.

114
00:05:49.410 --> 00:05:51.220
Now this one will take
a little bit longer,

115
00:05:51.220 --> 00:05:53.797
I probably should've ran it first and
then talked about it.

116
00:05:53.797 --> 00:05:55.679
[LAUGH] Because it is
doing an interrogation.

117
00:05:55.679 --> 00:05:59.700
IF I remember right, this one on this
particular machine with 33 open ports,

118
00:05:59.700 --> 00:06:01.610
it's doing a lot of interrogation.

119
00:06:01.610 --> 00:06:04.850
So it ends up being about a minute,
minute and a half I think.

120
00:06:04.850 --> 00:06:07.750
>> One of my favorite little
cheats to help speed this up,

121
00:06:07.750 --> 00:06:11.608
especially when you're on a local network,
is to do the dash n feature.

122
00:06:11.608 --> 00:06:14.650
Which tells it don't do any DNS
resolution, just go after that and

123
00:06:14.650 --> 00:06:16.410
it really speeds things up.

124
00:06:16.410 --> 00:06:20.300
>> It does, it does, all right,
so we'll let this finish and

125
00:06:20.300 --> 00:06:24.400
then we'll compare it with our
results from our previous scan.

126
00:06:26.490 --> 00:06:32.923
All right, so let's see here, again just
stalling, waiting for it to finish here.

127
00:06:32.923 --> 00:06:35.678
>> [LAUGH] So Mike, how's the wife?

128
00:06:35.678 --> 00:06:39.540
>> [LAUGH] But it'll finish up in
just a second, we'll keep moving.

129
00:06:39.540 --> 00:06:43.350
So we'll take a look at this version and
what we'll see is, like I said earlier,

130
00:06:43.350 --> 00:06:47.770
it's going to give me a lot more
information about the service itself,

131
00:06:47.770 --> 00:06:49.390
that's on those ports.

132
00:06:49.390 --> 00:06:53.100
And then we wanna take a look at how
we can get our operating system,

133
00:06:53.100 --> 00:06:55.410
try to do some fingerprinting on there.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike attempt to solidify your Kali skills by applying them to real-world type scenarios. Here they will scan a server and use Kali along with pen testing methodology to exploit 2 known vulnerabilities with rlogin and vsftpd.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show how to take advantage of a vulnerable system.  Mike demonstrates how to use the available tools like nmap to do a port scan to find the vulnernabiility.  He then shows how to use map scripts to take advantage of nfs misconfiguration.  He runs the rpcinfo script and the nfs-showzount script to exploit the vulnerable machine.  Lastly, he sets up an ssl cert for a hidden backdoor access back into that system.
