00:16:12.580 --> 00:16:17.700
For the passphrase, I'm just gonna leave
it blank for now, for both of those.

259
00:16:17.700 --> 00:16:18.420
And there we go.

260
00:16:18.420 --> 00:16:22.908
We have generated a new
key pair that we can use.

261
00:16:22.908 --> 00:16:30.120
So now I'm gonna try to write my
keys over to the victim machine.

262
00:16:30.120 --> 00:16:36.710
So we're simply gonna use cat.ssh
switch oops I can't type.

263
00:16:36.710 --> 00:16:39.980
You know what let me bump up
to the top of the screen here.

264
00:16:39.980 --> 00:16:41.540
We'll see that a little bit better.

265
00:16:41.540 --> 00:16:45.590
We're gonna do, I'm gonna cat .ssh.

266
00:16:45.590 --> 00:16:49.160
Actually, let me get back
out to the right directory.

267
00:16:49.160 --> 00:16:51.651
Make it little bit easier
to type this command.

268
00:16:51.651 --> 00:16:58.644
One more time, cat .ssh/id_rsa.pub.

269
00:16:58.644 --> 00:17:04.776
So that's my public key and
we're going to append that.

270
00:17:04.776 --> 00:17:08.310
Notice, I've got two greater
than symbols there, not one.

271
00:17:08.310 --> 00:17:12.780
I don't wanna overwrite what's
already on that machine, wanna to it.

272
00:17:12.780 --> 00:17:17.270
The idea is not to make any changes on
the system that are gonna cause attention.

273
00:17:17.270 --> 00:17:20.670
If all of the sudden the existing
keys no longer work on that machine,

274
00:17:20.670 --> 00:17:23.400
some admin's going to go,
why can't I remote in there anymore?

275
00:17:23.400 --> 00:17:24.530
They start looking into it.

276
00:17:24.530 --> 00:17:28.610
They find your key that you've added,
and end up taking your backdoor.

277
00:17:28.610 --> 00:17:29.970
So we don't want to wipe it out.

278
00:17:29.970 --> 00:17:32.142
We just want to add to it.

279
00:17:32.142 --> 00:17:37.431
And we're going to go into temp switch

280
00:17:37.431 --> 00:17:43.228
NFS /root/.ssh/authorize_keys.

281
00:17:43.228 --> 00:17:47.435
So again, I'm just taking my public
key that I just generated and

282
00:17:47.435 --> 00:17:50.878
I'm putting it over there
on the victim's system and

283
00:17:50.878 --> 00:17:54.970
they're adding it to their
list of authorized keys.

284
00:17:54.970 --> 00:17:55.590
It's that easy.

285
00:17:55.590 --> 00:18:00.310
So we hit Enter all goes well,
we can unmount with a umount.

286
00:18:01.960 --> 00:18:04.550
Oops, did I not do that right?

287
00:18:04.550 --> 00:18:07.040
I gotta tell it what to unmount, sorry.

288
00:18:07.040 --> 00:18:10.335
Umount switch temp, switch NFS.

289
00:18:11.560 --> 00:18:15.490
So we're no longer connected
to that share anymore.

290
00:18:15.490 --> 00:18:17.520
We're gonna try connect in with SSH.

291
00:18:17.520 --> 00:18:19.170
SSH Root@

292
00:18:21.890 --> 00:18:26.567
10.10.1.103.

293
00:18:26.567 --> 00:18:29.860
And it says, hey,
are you sure you wanna trust this machine?

294
00:18:29.860 --> 00:18:30.360
Yes, I do.

295
00:18:35.180 --> 00:18:36.430
And then we wait for it.

296
00:18:40.534 --> 00:18:41.819
Can we wait just a little bit longer?

297
00:18:41.819 --> 00:18:45.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And there we go.

298
00:18:45.240 --> 00:18:45.920
I am in.

299
00:18:45.920 --> 00:18:49.520
Notice my prompt down here,
root@metasploitable.

300
00:18:49.520 --> 00:18:52.248
I'll do a little id,
you can see that I am in the root group.

301
00:18:52.248 --> 00:18:55.640
So by simply finding that
they were running NFS and

302
00:18:55.640 --> 00:19:00.890
then exploring that a little bit further
to see if any admin had potentially or

303
00:19:00.890 --> 00:19:02.955
possibly misconfigured it.

304
00:19:02.955 --> 00:19:05.290
We're able to find
a major misconfiguration.

305
00:19:05.290 --> 00:19:08.301
And using simple built in tools,

306
00:19:08.301 --> 00:19:13.470
we're able to get write access
to their root directory.

307
00:19:13.470 --> 00:19:16.200
And from there it's just
a matter of what do you wanna do?

308
00:19:16.200 --> 00:19:18.230
How do you wanna compromise the machine,
right?

309
00:19:18.230 --> 00:19:20.870
Or what else I should say do you want
to do because you've really already

310
00:19:20.870 --> 00:19:21.552
compromised it.

311
00:19:21.552 --> 00:19:26.762
>> All right Mike so let's, now that we
understand how to at least take a look and

312
00:19:26.762 --> 00:19:29.584
make this vulnerability and exploit it.

313
00:19:29.584 --> 00:19:30.947
Let's talk about prevention just for
a moment.

314
00:19:30.947 --> 00:19:33.370
So Mike what do we need to do here?

315
00:19:33.370 --> 00:19:36.261
>> Really, it's just about
some kind of a common sense,

316
00:19:36.261 --> 00:19:38.060
I won't say some common sense, but it is.

317
00:19:39.450 --> 00:19:42.750
You wanna make sure you're using
groups and adding permissions.

318
00:19:42.750 --> 00:19:46.725
If you're gonna make these mount points
available to your network because

319
00:19:46.725 --> 00:19:51.500
your users need to access certain
resources, files, forms, tools,

320
00:19:51.500 --> 00:19:53.780
software, whatever it is.

321
00:19:53.780 --> 00:19:59.048
Create a directory for that purpose and
then assign access to that directory.

322
00:19:59.048 --> 00:20:01.430
Don't just share-out the root.

323
00:20:01.430 --> 00:20:02.120
Use your groups.

324
00:20:02.120 --> 00:20:03.860
Use your permissions.

325
00:20:03.860 --> 00:20:06.110
Create the appropriate directories for
the files,

326
00:20:06.110 --> 00:20:08.678
whatever it is that you wanna share.

327
00:20:08.678 --> 00:20:12.692
And by all whatever you do, don't share
the actual root of the directory.

328
00:20:12.692 --> 00:20:17.370
>> All right Mike well that sounds
like a lot of common sense as we

329
00:20:17.370 --> 00:20:19.038
start to take a look.

330
00:20:19.038 --> 00:20:23.060
Just using some of the simple tools and
skills that we've learned about so far.

331
00:20:23.060 --> 00:20:26.470
Mike is showing us how we can actually
run that exploit, take a look and

332
00:20:26.470 --> 00:20:27.750
gain root access at times.

333
00:20:27.750 --> 00:20:30.760
Remember that this doesn't always work
especially if you haven't done what Mike

334
00:20:30.760 --> 00:20:32.690
just talked about in
terms of the prevention.

335
00:20:32.690 --> 00:20:34.170
Setting up those groups correctly and

336
00:20:34.170 --> 00:20:39.220
not sharing out the actual root would
actually help very much to prevent this.

337
00:20:39.220 --> 00:20:42.580
And even just turning off some of those
ports that we're not really using that

338
00:20:42.580 --> 00:20:45.170
have a lot of vulnerabilities
would also help.

339
00:20:45.170 --> 00:20:49.390
But that is actually a great
little demonstration for us, and

340
00:20:49.390 --> 00:20:52.150
also a great place for
us to end this episode then.

341
00:20:52.150 --> 00:20:55.900
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

342
00:20:55.900 --> 00:20:56.880
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

343
00:20:56.880 --> 00:21:00.388
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Kali Linux shows.

344
00:21:00.388 --> 00:21:06.900
[MUSIC]

345
00:21:06.900 --> 00:21:10.222
Thank you for watching, ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike dive into the passive information gathering tools.  Kali Linux provides many tools and some of them are really designed to help us to find out more about our target in penetration testing, according to Mike.  He demonstrates the use of whois, netcraft, theharvester and a brief glimpse of recon-ng.  All of these tools are designed to help us to gather publicly available information without notifying the target.
episodes.title: Passive Information Gathering
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.070 --> 00:00:01.260
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.260 --> 00:00:05.424
I'm your host Don, [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.424 --> 00:00:07.836
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.836 --> 00:00:11.276
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.276 --> 00:00:14.682
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.682 --> 00:00:17.151
You're watching the Kali Linux show.

7
00:00:17.151 --> 00:00:21.751
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong and
today we're jumping into, well,

8
00:00:21.751 --> 00:00:25.450
passive information
gathering on Kali Linux.

9
00:00:25.450 --> 00:00:27.690
And here to help us understand
what that means, and

10
00:00:27.690 --> 00:00:31.350
of course how to do this is gonna be, Mr.
Security himself, Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:31.350 --> 00:00:32.770
Mike, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:32.770 --> 00:00:34.270
>> Hey, thanks, Ronnie,
thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:34.270 --> 00:00:36.010
Excited to be here as always.

14
00:00:36.010 --> 00:00:39.240
And yeah, we're gonna start off these
episodes or this episode, talking

15
00:00:39.240 --> 00:00:44.235
a little bit about one what I mean, or
we mean by passive information gathering.

16
00:00:44.235 --> 00:00:45.940
[COUGH] And

17
00:00:45.940 --> 00:00:49.930
take a look at a couple of different
tools that we might use to do this.

18
00:00:49.930 --> 00:00:54.550
And when we talk about doing a penetration
test or when we are looking,

19
00:00:54.550 --> 00:00:58.740
as security professionals, we're trying
to see what the bad guys are seeing.

20
00:00:58.740 --> 00:01:02.910
We have to understand that they spend
a lot of time in the reconisense phase,

21
00:01:02.910 --> 00:01:04.870
that very first phase of the attack.

22
00:01:04.870 --> 00:01:11.160
Enumeration, enumeration, enumeration,
reconnisense gathering information about

23
00:01:11.160 --> 00:01:15.830
their target, in other words about us if
we're the victim of the intended target.

24
00:01:15.830 --> 00:01:18.810
They're trying to gather as
much information as they can.

25
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:21.310
So if we're a penetration
tester that's a skill we need,

26
00:01:21.310 --> 00:01:22.630
to be able to gather that information.

27
00:01:22.630 --> 00:01:26.640
And if we're trying to protect our
organization, then we might wanna get

28
00:01:26.640 --> 00:01:30.620
a grip or see what information that
the bad guys are able to get, and

29
00:01:30.620 --> 00:01:32.170
maybe there's something
we can do about it.

30
00:01:32.170 --> 00:01:35.090
We can maybe try to minimize
what information they can find.

31
00:01:35.090 --> 00:01:39.323
So we'll start of kinda talking, I said in
general we'll run a couple of tools, and

32
00:01:39.323 --> 00:01:42.127
we'll come back and
take a look a closer more in depth and

33
00:01:42.127 --> 00:01:45.190
locate some of these tools cuz
they are extremely powerful.

34
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:47.038
So when we talk about passive
information gathering, Ronnie.

35
00:01:47.038 --> 00:01:50.680
We're talking about also known as
like Open Source Intelligence.

36
00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:53.090
You might see the acronym OSINT.

37
00:01:55.190 --> 00:02:00.640
What they mean by that is, we're gathering
information that's publicly available.

38
00:02:00.640 --> 00:02:02.890
We're not hammering their servers.

39
00:02:02.890 --> 00:02:05.570
We're not trying to probe in and

40
00:02:05.570 --> 00:02:10.330
take advantage of some service, and
trying to get into the systems.

41
00:02:10.330 --> 00:02:14.290
Passive information gathering is all
about going out to public resources,

42
00:02:14.290 --> 00:02:16.640
getting publicly available information.

43
00:02:16.640 --> 00:02:18.000
And it might seem like,

44
00:02:18.000 --> 00:02:21.690
well, what good is that gonna do me if
it's publicly available information?

45
00:02:21.690 --> 00:02:24.890
And it'll do you a lot of good.

46
00:02:24.890 --> 00:02:30.120
Just getting names of people that
work in the company is a big step,

47
00:02:30.120 --> 00:02:36.301
cuz we can go over, once we get started
talking about social engineering,

48
00:02:36.301 --> 00:02:40.960
and doing phishing scams, and
spear phishing, and things like that.

49
00:02:40.960 --> 00:02:44.660
If we can drop names in there,
we can make it look realistic and

50
00:02:44.660 --> 00:02:46.190
people start to trust it.

51
00:02:46.190 --> 00:02:50.158
So just as simple as just getting names
from people that actually work in

52
00:02:50.158 --> 00:02:54.920
the organization, getting email
addresses cuz half the time your

53
00:02:54.920 --> 00:02:59.730
email address is also your login name
in your organization or can be used.

54
00:02:59.730 --> 00:03:04.110
So a lot of good information
out there that the bad guys and

55
00:03:04.110 --> 00:03:06.750
us as penetration testers
should be able to obtain.

56
00:03:06.750 --> 00:03:07.850
so where do we start?

57
00:03:07.850 --> 00:03:11.690
Well one place we can start,
Ronnie is the good old who is database.

58
00:03:11.690 --> 00:03:13.530
That one's an oldie but a goodie right?

59
00:03:13.530 --> 00:03:14.950
Been out there for a while.

60
00:03:14.950 --> 00:03:15.760
>> Yes.

61
00:03:15.760 --> 00:03:19.700
>> It has, the whois database is
basically the registrars keeping track

62
00:03:19.700 --> 00:03:23.020
of who has registered names, or

63
00:03:23.020 --> 00:03:25.930
portions of the name space I guess
would be a better way to say it.

64
00:03:25.930 --> 00:03:29.620
Like here, we have ITPRO.TV, well that's
something that we had to register.

65
00:03:29.620 --> 00:03:32.130
We had to go and
claim that name, register it.

66
00:03:32.130 --> 00:03:36.510
We'd pay a fee in order to keep that name,
DNS server's out there.

67
00:03:36.510 --> 00:03:40.630
Public DNS servers are updated with
the information pointing to our website.

68
00:03:40.630 --> 00:03:43.460
So you can guys can come to our
website and find our information.

69
00:03:44.970 --> 00:03:48.396
But we can query those
registrar databases,

70
00:03:48.396 --> 00:03:51.380
doing what's known as a whois look up.

71
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:54.712
And it will return, it should query
those registration databases and

72
00:03:54.712 --> 00:03:58.450
it will return the information
associated with that registration.

73
00:03:58.450 --> 00:04:02.475
So let's take a look at how whois works,
and we just type in whois.

74
00:04:02.475 --> 00:04:03.940
We'll get a little bit of a man page or

75
00:04:03.940 --> 00:04:08.400
some help associated with that,
there's a few different options, but

76
00:04:08.400 --> 00:04:12.910
basically you're just going to tell it
who it is that you want to look up.

77
00:04:12.910 --> 00:04:15.860
That's at the most basic level.

78
00:04:15.860 --> 00:04:22.270
So let's try it, let's do whois itpro.tv.

79
00:04:22.270 --> 00:04:23.640
Now what it does is it reaches out,

80
00:04:23.640 --> 00:04:27.750
tries to determine based
on the top level domain,

81
00:04:27.750 --> 00:04:32.540
the TLD It's gonna know which registrar
to connect to, which database to scan.

82
00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:35.300
And here we can see the information
that it's pulling back.

83
00:04:35.300 --> 00:04:41.210
It's got my domain name, who the whois
server is, when it was created.

84
00:04:41.210 --> 00:04:44.210
Last time that information was updated.

85
00:04:44.210 --> 00:04:47.830
As we go down through here,
what other good information can we get?

86
00:04:47.830 --> 00:04:50.470
And this is a good one right here.

87
00:04:50.470 --> 00:04:51.822
These named servers.

88
00:04:51.822 --> 00:04:55.858
That's definitely something I wanna keep
track of if we're going to attempt any

89
00:04:55.858 --> 00:04:59.372
attacks or redirection attacks,
we have to modify DNS information.

90
00:04:59.372 --> 00:05:02.700
It's good to know who is hosting
this organization's DNS information.

91
00:05:04.650 --> 00:05:07.910
And the rest of it as we go down
through there's a big long disclaimer

92
00:05:07.910 --> 00:05:10.210
about terms of use.

93
00:05:10.210 --> 00:05:12.140
And then we just go down
a little bit further.

94
00:05:12.140 --> 00:05:15.740
We see some more information coming back,
a lot of repeat information there.

95
00:05:15.740 --> 00:05:18.080
And then some registered information.

96
00:05:19.380 --> 00:05:22.640
Now here, we have Contact Privacy Inc.

97
00:05:22.640 --> 00:05:25.675
Customer number, so
what we're finding nowadays,

98
00:05:25.675 --> 00:05:31.015
because this was a great way to source
information, people have wised up.

99
00:05:31.015 --> 00:05:33.905
And there's now services out
there that we can use to kinda

100
00:05:33.905 --> 00:05:35.605
obfuscate our information.

101
00:05:35.605 --> 00:05:40.005
It puts this generic information in there,
so that if somebody was trying to get in

102
00:05:40.005 --> 00:05:44.705
touch with the owner of the company, or
trying to glean information out of here,

103
00:05:44.705 --> 00:05:47.350
they wouldn't find any
information about ITPRO.TV.

104
00:05:47.350 --> 00:05:52.280
It's about this third party,
Contact Privacy Inc.

105
00:05:52.280 --> 00:05:58.270
That's really all even the email address
goes back to contactprivacy.com.

106
00:05:58.270 --> 00:06:00.860
So we've done a decent job that
obvious [INAUDIBLE] our information.

107
00:06:00.860 --> 00:06:05.014
You still get DNS server information but
that's about it.

108
00:06:05.014 --> 00:06:11.094
Let's try some other one, if it's trying
something like a whois, let's do ufl.edu.

109
00:06:11.094 --> 00:06:16.230
Local college here, and
see what kind of information we get.

110
00:06:17.620 --> 00:06:20.640
This is an edu, so
it's different database that is scanning.

111
00:06:21.780 --> 00:06:24.310
As we come down and
scroll down through here though,

112
00:06:24.310 --> 00:06:28.470
here's a case where they have not
tried to hide any of that information.

113
00:06:28.470 --> 00:06:32.090
I can see who the registrant is,
who the administrative contact is.

114
00:06:33.260 --> 00:06:35.690
Assuming this information is current.

115
00:06:35.690 --> 00:06:37.030
This could be out of date.

116
00:06:37.030 --> 00:06:38.446
But it's a good starting point.

117
00:06:38.446 --> 00:06:41.200
I've got a name, I've got an address.

118
00:06:41.200 --> 00:06:43.260
I've even got a phone number.

119
00:06:43.260 --> 00:06:46.320
And an email address, although it looks
kind of a generic email address but

120
00:06:46.320 --> 00:06:50.070
again, a good start to my
information gathering.

121
00:06:50.070 --> 00:06:54.430
I've got some contact information here,
again, another phone number and

122
00:06:54.430 --> 00:06:57.240
it's different from that first one and

123
00:06:57.240 --> 00:07:01.200
that looks like an actual email,
Brad O, Brad O'Hara.

124
00:07:02.660 --> 00:07:06.130
So there's some information
that I can start using.

125
00:07:06.130 --> 00:07:08.940
Information about their names,
servers as well comes back.

126
00:07:08.940 --> 00:07:12.510
So this is an example of some of
the information that I can get

127
00:07:12.510 --> 00:07:14.710
using that whois database.

128
00:07:14.710 --> 00:07:17.920
Another thing you can do with the whois
is you can actually do reverse look ups

129
00:07:17.920 --> 00:07:19.000
as well.

130
00:07:19.000 --> 00:07:21.640
If we were to,

131
00:07:21.640 --> 00:07:26.930
let's just ping ufl.edu.

132
00:07:26.930 --> 00:07:28.370
We can actually get their return address,

133
00:07:28.370 --> 00:07:31.530
or, let's see if they gave
it to us up in our results.

134
00:07:31.530 --> 00:07:34.490
They did not.

135
00:07:34.490 --> 00:07:38.980
Pinging it forced it to resolve
that name into an IP address.

136
00:07:38.980 --> 00:07:41.088
Let's see what happens if we do a whois.

137
00:07:41.088 --> 00:07:48.009
On 128.227.9.98.

138
00:07:49.927 --> 00:07:52.781
And again,
we're getting a lot of good information.

139
00:07:52.781 --> 00:07:55.836
Actually it's like were getting
a little more information.

140

Domains-, it's under recons,

If I can type, for reporting.

00:27:47.520 --> 00:27:50.884
Right now,

Let's just leave that there.

00:28:08.670 --> 00:28:12.029
And there we go if I can

you can see the name of

Created by goes down there, so it wasn't

It has nothing to do with

We can go back and

When we get into our Recon-ng episode,

As far as, I know we've talked a little

This is the kind of

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look into active information gathering tools in Kali Linux.  Mike shows the powerful host command to find information served up by the target system.  He demonstrates multiple options with the host command.  Mike also demos a couple of other tools that can show a tremendous amount of helpful information for the pentester.
episodes.title: Active Information Gathering
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:03.101
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2

>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.372 --> 00:00:08.211
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.211 --> 00:00:11.017
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:11.017 --> 00:00:14.970
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:14.970 --> 00:00:18.060
You're watching the Kali Linux show.

7
00:00:18.060 --> 00:00:19.600

8

And today We're actually going into

9

Now we've already talked about
passive information gathering in

a previous episode,
now we're gonna explore the nature active

00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:35.080

Security himself, Mike Rodrick.

Mike, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:36.260 --> 00:00:37.110
>> Hey, thanks Ronnie.

14

Glad to be back and excited.

15

Cuz we are.

16

Yeah, we're moving on

although I will say that we're border

18

When we talked about passive information
gathering, we're going out and

19

we're getting publicly available
information Information through search

00:00:53.535 --> 00:00:57.970
engines, through who is databases,
through social media,

21

[INAUDIBLE] good stuff there or we'll just

22

IP addresses of the internet servers,

23
00:01:05.515 --> 00:01:08.375
network blocks that have been assigned

24
00:01:09.435 --> 00:01:14.225
Once we've done our passive phase, we're
going start moving into the active phase

25
00:01:14.225 --> 00:01:17.830
and that now We're actually gonna
start hitting servers, right?

26
00:01:17.830 --> 00:01:22.220
We might be doing port scans,
we might be interrogating the DNS

27
00:01:22.220 --> 00:01:24.540
server which is kinda what
we're gonna look at here.

28
00:01:24.540 --> 00:01:29.210
We're gonna start with DNS and
doing some interrogation there.

29
00:01:29.210 --> 00:01:32.880
But we are moving, as I said,
into that active phase cuz now we're

Anybody can go to Google and

33
00:01:42.660 --> 00:01:48.900
But if I start querying DNS Server and
puling back MX records and NS records.

34
00:01:48.900 --> 00:01:51.950
Again this is why I say it's kind of
bottom line because that stuff will

35

I wanted to send an email to that

36
00:01:55.250 --> 00:01:55.990
organization.

37
00:01:55.990 --> 00:01:58.150
That information has to be out there.

38
00:01:58.150 --> 00:02:01.580
But if its a privately owned DNS server.

39
00:02:01.580 --> 00:02:05.150
Right now we're going, we're having
to one get to that DNS server.

40
00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:09.880
So it is like I said kinda
borderline active passive.

41
00:02:09.880 --> 00:02:12.819
And we will move on into the full
on active phase in a little bit.

42
00:02:14.090 --> 00:02:14.680
All right so,

00:02:14.680 --> 00:02:20.030
what are some tools we can use if we're

enumeration, I guess would be a better
word for it, what tools do we wanna use?

45
00:02:25.330 --> 00:02:26.850
And there are several for this.

00:02:26.850 --> 00:02:29.570
But we're gonna start kinda
like we did in our passive

48

And that tool, the one I'm thinking of,

49
00:02:38.310 --> 00:02:41.630

00:02:41.630 --> 00:02:44.190
Did she pull it up quick

51
00:02:44.190 --> 00:02:45.805
It's all gone that I can't spell host.

52

>> [LAUGH]
>> If we type in host,

53

we'll see that there are a few different
switches that go along with this command.

54
00:02:52.150 --> 00:02:52.700
>> Just a few.

55
00:02:52.700 --> 00:02:53.670
>> Just a few.

56
00:02:53.670 --> 00:02:54.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can also do

57
00:02:54.640 --> 00:02:57.980
a I don't know what I try spell there,
host and you

00:02:57.980 --> 00:03:02.890
can get a lot more detailed information
on how to use this particular command.

59
00:03:04.050 --> 00:03:08.330
All right, I'm gonna click out of that,
clear up my screen and

60

let's just see what we can use.

61
00:03:10.690 --> 00:03:12.690
Actually, let me do host one more time.

There's a couple of switches

Lower case t is for type,

68
00:03:39.440 --> 00:03:46.700
We get four different DNS servers

69
00:03:46.700 --> 00:03:48.290
Quick and easy, right?

70
00:03:48.290 --> 00:03:51.500
Could we have gotten this

71
00:03:51.500 --> 00:03:54.990
Yeah, absolutely, other sources as well.

72
00:03:54.990 --> 00:03:56.670
Multiple tools to do the same thing.

73
00:03:56.670 --> 00:04:00.810
Always good to have a choice when it

74
00:04:00.810 --> 00:04:05.329
And plus this one is focused in on just

75
00:04:06.420 --> 00:04:07.630

76

what the IP address is of their mail

78
00:04:18.270 --> 00:04:25.790
And there, I get
ITPro-TV.mail.protection.outlook.com.

79
00:04:25.790 --> 00:04:29.960
Didn't give me I would then have to
go back and look up IP address for

80
00:04:31.200 --> 00:04:35.270
that but it gave me yeah.

81
00:04:35.270 --> 00:04:36.620
>> Find a qualified domain name.

82
00:04:36.620 --> 00:04:37.180
>> Thank you Ronnie.
>> [LAUGH]

83
00:04:37.180 --> 00:04:39.960
>> FQDN was the word that was not coming

84

85
00:04:41.630 --> 00:04:44.440
All right let's do some more here.

86
00:04:44.440 --> 00:04:46.418
Let's do what if I do host?

87

www.itpro.tv, all right

88
00:04:52.280 --> 00:04:57.050
we'll get back itpro.tv is an alias for

89
00:04:57.050 --> 00:05:02.040
address of their web server and again
it tells me who is handling their mail.

90
00:05:02.040 --> 00:05:04.750
Okay that's good information.

91
00:05:04.750 --> 00:05:11.998
What if I picked one that was invalid,
let's do Host nada.itpro.tv.

92
00:05:11.998 --> 00:05:15.010
And I get nothing.

93
00:05:15.010 --> 00:05:18.700
So what we're seeing here,
when I do host.www.itpro.tv,

94
00:05:18.700 --> 00:05:23.020
I'm really trying to guess a host name.

95
00:05:23.020 --> 00:05:28.250
When you look at the itpro.tv is
my DNS suffix, that's our domain.

96
00:05:28.250 --> 00:05:29.780

1.12 and the -t for type axfr.

322
00:19:47.700 --> 00:19:51.280
There's different zone transfer types axfr

323
00:19:51.280 --> 00:19:55.930
versus ixfr incremental is just
the changes since the last replication,

324
00:19:55.930 --> 00:20:00.180
axfr Is the full zone
whether it's changing that.

325
00:20:00.180 --> 00:20:02.350
Now, we don't have a previous replication.

326
00:20:02.350 --> 00:20:04.850
So I expect it wouldn't
really do us any good.

327
00:20:04.850 --> 00:20:07.070
Anyway, we want the whole zone file.

328
00:20:07.070 --> 00:20:11.200
So we hit enter and there we go.

329
00:20:11.200 --> 00:20:13.970
Testing NS server for
zone transfer, checking for

330
00:20:13.970 --> 00:20:17.050
zone transfer for lab at IT Pro Chat TV.

331
00:20:17.050 --> 00:20:19.130
It's found the I address, all right.

332
00:20:19.130 --> 00:20:21.340
It's verified,
there's the start of authority.

333
00:20:21.340 --> 00:20:24.614
Telling you who the DNS server is.

334
00:20:24.614 --> 00:20:28.690
It removes any duplicate IP addresses and
then it starts hitting each ones.

335
00:20:28.690 --> 00:20:32.940
So if there was more than one
record found in that zone file.

336
00:20:32.940 --> 00:20:35.630
It would do this for each DNS server.

337
00:20:35.630 --> 00:20:37.870
It will attempt to transfer.

338
00:20:37.870 --> 00:20:42.870
Here I can see has port 53 open and
then it says, yay!

339
00:20:42.870 --> 00:20:45.870
Zone transfer was successful!

340
00:20:45.870 --> 00:20:50.160
Then as I stroll down through these
results, I can see all their NS records.

341
00:20:50.160 --> 00:20:52.400
I can see all their A records.

342
00:20:52.400 --> 00:20:56.030
And again, most importantly,
to go along with those A records,

343
00:20:56.030 --> 00:20:59.810
all the SRV records telling me
who's running kerberos, right?

344
00:20:59.810 --> 00:21:01.680
Who their global catalog server is.

345
00:21:01.680 --> 00:21:04.410
Basically who their main controller is,

346
00:21:04.410 --> 00:21:07.140
it's a little teeny tiny demand
I set up a little bit ago.

347
00:21:07.140 --> 00:21:12.150
It's got one server and a couple clients,
but the point is is I was able to transfer

348
00:21:12.150 --> 00:21:17.402
that entire zone file using DNS recon.

349
00:21:17.402 --> 00:21:21.550
All right, I'll tell you most of the time
it's not gonna be quite that easy right.

350
00:21:21.550 --> 00:21:23.406
They're not gonna let us,

351
00:21:23.406 --> 00:21:28.343
like if I go back over to this server I
can show you let me log in real quick.

352
00:21:30.772 --> 00:21:32.075
I'll open up DNS.

353
00:21:35.600 --> 00:21:38.416
And I'm gonna pull up
the properties of that zone and

354
00:21:38.416 --> 00:21:42.520
on that zone transfers tab I allowed
zone transfers to any server.

355
00:21:42.520 --> 00:21:46.343
I'll tell you this used to be
the default back end serve 2000.

356
00:21:46.343 --> 00:21:51.420
And you will find,
unfortunately we still find servers set

357
00:21:51.420 --> 00:21:55.080
up this way to this day because somebody
figured out ahead and it doesn't work.

358
00:21:55.080 --> 00:21:58.800
If I just allows on transfer any server,
every thing seems to work just fine.

359
00:21:59.850 --> 00:22:01.160
Well this is not a good thing.

360
00:22:01.160 --> 00:22:05.050
If they had left it on the default,
do not allow on transfers Or

361
00:22:05.050 --> 00:22:07.640
only servers listed on
the named servers tab.

362
00:22:07.640 --> 00:22:09.120
Or the following servers.

363
00:22:10.450 --> 00:22:11.840
Let's see what that does to my recon NG.

364
00:22:11.840 --> 00:22:15.460
Try that same command again.

365
00:22:17.920 --> 00:22:19.780
Zone transfer failed.

366
00:22:19.780 --> 00:22:21.390
No answer or reset.

367
00:22:21.390 --> 00:22:24.740
That is not going to allow me
to have that zone transfer.

368
00:22:24.740 --> 00:22:25.810
All right?

369
00:22:25.810 --> 00:22:30.570
So, Just an example of one of the things
that we can do with DNS recon.

370
00:22:30.570 --> 00:22:33.953
Another tool that we wanna kinda
take a closer look at is dnsenum.

371
00:22:35.587 --> 00:22:40.790
Just another tool for
interrogating or enumerating DNS.

372
00:22:40.790 --> 00:22:45.170
The last option here, I like this note,

373
00:22:45.170 --> 00:22:51.216
the Brute Force -F Switch Is
obligatory all right.

374
00:22:51.216 --> 00:22:55.530
[LAUGH] All right so
let's see what we can do with DNS enum DNS

375
00:22:57.050 --> 00:22:59.600
let me clear that screen up and
get back to the top.

376
00:22:59.600 --> 00:23:05.005
DNS enum and
let's pick on a UFL.edu again.

377
00:23:05.005 --> 00:23:09.950
All right so what this is doing It's
basically doing a lot of the stuff that

378
00:23:09.950 --> 00:23:12.760
we would do manually
with something like host.

379
00:23:12.760 --> 00:23:14.590
I'm trying to do is own
transfer is that way.

380
00:23:14.590 --> 00:23:16.560
You can see it's going out.

381
00:23:16.560 --> 00:23:21.790
It's found an IP address for ufl.edu and
then it did some queries and

382
00:23:21.790 --> 00:23:25.100
I found name servers and
their IP addresses.

383
00:23:25.100 --> 00:23:28.600
Also found all of their mail servers And
then it's trying for

384
00:23:28.600 --> 00:23:34.330
each one of these name servers that it
found it's trying to do an extra file.

385
00:23:34.330 --> 00:23:36.760
Well it's own transfer
file from the DNA server.

386
00:23:36.760 --> 00:23:40.960
So NS refused RNS also refused.

387
00:23:40.960 --> 00:23:43.150
All right and this group force file and

388
00:23:43.150 --> 00:23:46.440
that specifys cuz I am not trying
to move force anything just yet.

389
00:23:48.590 --> 00:23:55.290
We can add an a num switch to this command
which gives me a little more information.

390
00:23:55.290 --> 00:23:58.666
By typing dnsnum-enum and

391
00:23:58.666 --> 00:24:04.153
then ufl.edu All right.

392
00:24:04.153 --> 00:24:05.710
You see it adds a little bit to it.

393
00:24:06.750 --> 00:24:11.850
Not only does it go out and
get the name servers, the mail servers.

394
00:24:11.850 --> 00:24:15.480
Again, it's just looking at those
NS records in this NX records.

395
00:24:15.480 --> 00:24:21.420
Then it tries its own transfers, and then
scraping ufl.edu sub domains from Google.

396
00:24:21.420 --> 00:24:26.929
And so it's actually going out and trying
www seeing if there's any sub domains.

397
00:24:26.929 --> 00:24:31.750
Stuff that would appear to
the left of the ufl.edu.

398
00:24:31.750 --> 00:24:39.047
And I found www.purchasing.ufl.edu and
www.honors.ufl.edu.

399
00:24:39.047 --> 00:24:43.300
So it's finding those for
us here in the google results.

400
00:24:43.300 --> 00:24:45.754
Again I can see a lot
of the same stuff and

401
00:24:45.754 --> 00:24:48.446
the IP addresses that go along with those.

402
00:24:48.446 --> 00:24:53.026
Just more information then I
can add to my research as I am

403
00:24:53.026 --> 00:24:55.856
doing that research on my target.

404
00:24:55.856 --> 00:24:58.609
Or if I am a security professional,
trying to find out,

405
00:24:58.609 --> 00:25:00.200
what information is out there.

406
00:25:00.200 --> 00:25:05.220
I can look at this and go wait why is this
available, how can I hide this stuff?

407
00:25:05.220 --> 00:25:09.280
Now that whole brute force thing is just
like we were doing with the host file.

408
00:25:09.280 --> 00:25:10.620
You feed it a word list.

409
00:25:10.620 --> 00:25:12.760
Here it's searching Google right?

410
00:25:12.760 --> 00:25:15.280
Like we did with some
of the previous tools.

411
00:25:15.280 --> 00:25:18.180
It's just trying to see if it
can find anything.ufl.edu.

412
00:25:18.180 --> 00:25:23.120
But I can provide a word list for
it and it will try those as well.

413
00:25:23.120 --> 00:25:24.310
So let's try DNS enum.

414
00:25:25.730 --> 00:25:31.232
And we'll do a -F and
then that same file hostNames.txt.

415
00:25:31.232 --> 00:25:37.250
And then a -R and the URL that
I want to brute force ufl.edu.

416
00:25:37.250 --> 00:25:42.870
And see what we come up with this time.

417
00:25:42.870 --> 00:25:45.170
So now rather than scraping Google and

418
00:25:45.170 --> 00:25:50.430
just randomly trying to find stuff It just
used the names out of my host name.text.

419
00:25:50.430 --> 00:25:52.990
So I can see it found a ufl or www.

420
00:25:52.990 --> 00:26:01.343
It found mail,
there's a couple of there mail servers.

421
00:26:01.343 --> 00:26:02.882
So there we go Ronnie,

422
00:26:02.882 --> 00:26:08.150
three different ways that we can do
some basic information gathering on DNS.

423
00:26:08.150 --> 00:26:11.228
We get that host command that
we can find from within Linux.

424
00:26:11.228 --> 00:26:15.330
And then of course,
Kali has our wonderful selection of tools.

425
00:26:15.330 --> 00:26:19.160
And we've got DNS enum as well as DNS.

426
00:26:19.160 --> 00:26:21.090
>> All right, Micheal, thank you again for

427
00:26:21.090 --> 00:26:23.800
helping us to at least learn more
a little bit more about these tools.

428
00:26:23.800 --> 00:26:28.825
We're gonna dive in to some of them
a little bit more intensely, I would say.

429
00:26:28.825 --> 00:26:30.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> In a future episode but

430
00:26:30.680 --> 00:26:33.870
this is a good taste and
a good understanding at least of some of

431
00:26:33.870 --> 00:26:37.170
the active ways that we start
gathering some more information.

432
00:26:37.170 --> 00:26:41.270
But that means that this is another great
episode that we're gonna end right now.

433
00:26:41.270 --> 00:26:43.700
Signing off for ITPro.TV.

434
00:26:43.700 --> 00:26:45.240
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

435
00:26:45.240 --> 00:26:45.940
>> And I'm Mike Rodderick.

436
00:26:45.940 --> 00:26:48.210
>> Stay tune right here for
more Kali Linux shows

437
00:26:48.210 --> 00:26:55.667
[MUSIC]

438
00:26:55.667 --> 00:26:59.326
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike demonstrate setting up and using recon-ng.  Mike shows how to get started with contact information.  Using the email address from a domain gathered through recon-ng, Mike shows some of the other data that can be gathered just based on the email address.  He demonstrates loading the module and running the module and showing the results.
episodes.title: Recon-ng
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.597
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.597 --> 00:00:05.337
[CROSSTALK]
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:05.337 --> 00:00:06.164
California.

4
00:00:06.164 --> 00:00:07.680
[CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:07.680 --> 00:00:08.413
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.413 --> 00:00:12.345
>> You're watching ITProTV.

7
00:00:12.345 --> 00:00:15.585
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

8
00:00:15.585 --> 00:00:18.110
You're watching the Kali Linux show.

9
00:00:18.110 --> 00:00:19.460
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:19.460 --> 00:00:24.670
And today, we're actually taking look
at a neat utility called Recon-ng.

11
00:00:24.670 --> 00:00:27.580
And here to help us to get a better
understanding of that of course,

12
00:00:27.580 --> 00:00:29.700
is gonna be Mr.
Security himself, Mike Rodrick.

13
00:00:29.700 --> 00:00:30.980
Mike, welcome to the studio.

14
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:31.932
>> Hey, thanks Ronnie.

15
00:00:31.932 --> 00:00:35.265
Yeah, excited today, and
we did a little prelook at Recon-ng.

16
00:00:35.265 --> 00:00:37.527
>> [LAUGH]
>> In the past episode,

17
00:00:37.527 --> 00:00:39.420
just a little teaser.

18
00:00:39.420 --> 00:00:42.531
Now we're gonna try to take a closer
look at what we can do, right?

19
00:00:42.531 --> 00:00:45.495
And if you remember right, hopefully
you've watched that previous episode.

20
00:00:45.495 --> 00:00:51.310
Recon-ng fell into the category
of passive information gathering.

21
00:00:51.310 --> 00:00:56.000
And it's funny, cuz as I sit here and
think about it, we are doing some pretty

22
00:00:56.000 --> 00:01:00.850
heavy hitting when we start doing this
reconnaissance work with Recon-ng.

23
00:01:00.850 --> 00:01:02.500
But we're not hitting the target and

24
00:01:02.500 --> 00:01:07.340
that's really what defines this
as passive, for the most part.

25
00:01:07.340 --> 00:01:10.810
It kind of blurs the lines, but
we'll leave it under passive for now.

26
00:01:10.810 --> 00:01:14.100
All right, but anyway, cool tool
either way, whether it's passive or

27
00:01:14.100 --> 00:01:17.180
active, fantastic stuff
that you can get back with.

28
00:01:17.180 --> 00:01:21.221
There's just a treasure trove
of information that's out there.

29
00:01:21.221 --> 00:01:25.660
And with this tool, really, once you get
used to the tool, and you get familiar

30
00:01:25.660 --> 00:01:30.115
with the different options, you'll find
that it's pretty easy to work with.

31
00:01:30.115 --> 00:01:32.143
It's a great way to gather information.

32
00:01:32.143 --> 00:01:35.834
It organizes it well for
you, allows for easy access.

33
00:01:35.834 --> 00:01:40.196
So it's quickly becoming one of my
faves when it comes to doing some of my

34
00:01:40.196 --> 00:01:42.172
initial reconnaissance work.

35
00:01:42.172 --> 00:01:46.556
So without further ado, Ronnie,
I say we just dive right in and

36
00:01:46.556 --> 00:01:51.570
fire it up, and see what kind of fun
we can have with gold old Recon-ng.

37
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:57.300
So, we'll type in recon-ng from
our shell and we'll load it up.

38
00:01:57.300 --> 00:01:58.180
Now I'm just gonna go ahead and

39
00:01:58.180 --> 00:02:02.540
maximize this terminal cuz we're gonna
be in here most of this episode.

40
00:02:02.540 --> 00:02:05.240
And as we saw on the previous one,

41
00:02:05.240 --> 00:02:09.000
I get a lot of errors when
I first fire up Recon-ng.

42
00:02:09.000 --> 00:02:10.170
They're not really errors.

43
00:02:10.170 --> 00:02:15.109
If you look at them closely,
it's telling me that I don't have

44
00:02:15.109 --> 00:02:19.969
an API key set for being API, or
being API key not set, right?

45
00:02:19.969 --> 00:02:23.250
There are several modules that
are included with Recon-ng.

46
00:02:23.250 --> 00:02:29.213
Some of which work fine without a key,
others require an API key.

47
00:02:29.213 --> 00:02:31.867
API, application programming interface,

48
00:02:31.867 --> 00:02:35.270
this is how you can interface
with those applications.

49
00:02:35.270 --> 00:02:38.585
For example,
if I wanted to scour LinkedIn for

50
00:02:38.585 --> 00:02:43.346
information about a certain email address,
and see what posts and

51
00:02:43.346 --> 00:02:47.782
things like that were there,
well I need a programmatic way.

52
00:02:47.782 --> 00:02:50.920
I need to interact with
LinkedIn a programmatic way.

53
00:02:50.920 --> 00:02:53.440
And that's where that API key comes in.

54
00:02:53.440 --> 00:02:59.100
I have a key that gives me access to
LinkedIn application under the hood.

55
00:02:59.100 --> 00:03:01.850
And I can start doing
stuff with that data.

56
00:03:01.850 --> 00:03:05.715
Now they are designed for
building applications, right?

57
00:03:05.715 --> 00:03:09.360
I'm supposed to go to LinkedIn and
say, hey, I'm an app developer.

58
00:03:09.360 --> 00:03:11.695
I wanna sign up for an account,
I wanna build an app.

59
00:03:11.695 --> 00:03:16.400
They're gonna give me an API
key that my application can

60
00:03:16.400 --> 00:03:20.030
then use to access their
data that they have.

61
00:03:20.030 --> 00:03:21.890
Some of these keys are freely available.

62
00:03:21.890 --> 00:03:26.720
You can just go and
set up an account typically.

63
00:03:26.720 --> 00:03:29.170
Tell them a little bit about the app
you wanna develop or something and

64
00:03:29.170 --> 00:03:30.140
you'll get a key.

65
00:03:30.140 --> 00:03:34.119
Others, you might have to pay for,
could be a one time fee,

66
00:03:34.119 --> 00:03:37.553
could be a reoccurring fee
depending on what it is.

67
00:03:37.553 --> 00:03:40.667
Like Jigsaw, I know for
one is, if I'm not mistaken,

68
00:03:40.667 --> 00:03:43.120
that is a reoccurring
fee on their API key.

69
00:03:44.240 --> 00:03:46.550
But it also gives you
a lot of information.

70
00:03:46.550 --> 00:03:50.310
So, that being said, not all these
modules will work out of the box.

71
00:03:50.310 --> 00:03:52.330
You're gonna have to kinda play around.

72
00:03:52.330 --> 00:03:54.475
I'll show you how to figure
out if they need a key or not.

73
00:03:54.475 --> 00:03:56.540
I mean, you can kinda see this list here.

74
00:03:56.540 --> 00:03:58.460
And then I can show you how.

75
00:03:58.460 --> 00:04:02.100
Well, I showed you in the last
episode how to enter a key.

76
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:03.950
I don't wanna bring up that table again.

77
00:04:03.950 --> 00:04:06.420
Remember, you can always do show keys, and

78
00:04:06.420 --> 00:04:08.650
you can get a list of all
the keys that you've entered.

79
00:04:08.650 --> 00:04:10.090
I've entered in several keys so

80
00:04:10.090 --> 00:04:11.930
that we can play around
with some of these modules.

81
00:04:11.930 --> 00:04:16.840
[LAUGH] I don't really want to bring that
up on screen, so I'm going to avoid that.

82
00:04:16.840 --> 00:04:19.620
The rest of these you see here are ones
that I don't have keys for yet or

83
00:04:19.620 --> 00:04:22.934
I haven't bothered to
enter them in to Recon-ng.

84
00:04:22.934 --> 00:04:26.600
All right, so, there we go,
we got past that initial whole block of

85
00:04:26.600 --> 00:04:29.870
red things that usually scares people
like, my gosh something is wrong.

86
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:30.670
Just letting you know,

87
00:04:30.670 --> 00:04:34.570
if you want some of the modules to work,
you're gonna need some keys.

88
00:04:34.570 --> 00:04:40.089
All right, so now we are in good old
Recon-ng developed by Black Hills InfoSec.

89
00:04:41.230 --> 00:04:43.660
And, we need to be familiar
with working our way around,

90
00:04:43.660 --> 00:04:48.050
or navigating through Recon-ng and
we'll play with some of these modules.

91
00:04:48.050 --> 00:04:51.778
I know, again, we did some highlights
there in the previous episode, but

92
00:04:51.778 --> 00:04:56.250
I really wanna focus this time on getting
comfortable with Recon-ng, all right?

93
00:04:56.250 --> 00:04:59.360
So the first thing I think we need to
know is the good old show command.

94
00:04:59.360 --> 00:05:03.880
If I just hit show and
do a tab, I'm gonna do a show,

95
00:05:03.880 --> 00:05:08.570
space, tab, tab, it'll show me all
the things that I can look at, all right?

96
00:05:08.570 --> 00:05:12.820
So tab auto-fill is a feature of Recon-ng,
it's fantastic.

97
00:05:12.820 --> 00:05:16.189
If you're familiar Metasploit,
and working with that,

98
00:05:16.189 --> 00:05:19.800
you'll definitely be comfortable
working with Recon-ng.

99
00:05:19.800 --> 00:05:21.774
It is a framework, all right?

100
00:05:21.774 --> 00:05:25.040
It's not a, I a good way to say this.

101
00:05:25.040 --> 00:05:29.365
It's a framework and people write
modules and add those modules.

102
00:05:29.365 --> 00:05:31.689
In fact, you could write a module and
you could submit it and

103
00:05:31.689 --> 00:05:32.768
have it added it into here.

104
00:05:32.768 --> 00:05:35.545
So most of these modules
are written by different people.

105
00:05:35.545 --> 00:05:38.245
Some of them by the original authors, but

106
00:05:38.245 --> 00:05:40.317
a lot of them have been
added after the fact.

107

it's like okay you found

But what about phone numbers addresses,

Yeah, we can find all of this information.

So we're building up our information.

Ronnie let's keep going with the contacts.

00:20:59.942 --> 00:21:03.640
All right, so contacts is the input

So, I've got input for any of

Thank you, sir, and there we go,

mangle, unmangle, hibp_breach, hibp_paste,

00:21:33.770 --> 00:21:38.659
migrate contacts, and full contact,

00:21:38.659 --> 00:21:39.524

>> Yeah,

[LAUGH]

Any idea what HIBP stands for Ronnie?

>> No, I don't but

it sounds painful again.
[LAUGH]

00:21:57.094 --> 00:21:58.213

They try to collect all that information

up and then you can go and search to see.

00:22:10.770 --> 00:22:14.347
Hey, it was my account I

Can I say that?

00:22:14.980 --> 00:22:16.260

Everybody knows that they got breached.

00:22:18.710 --> 00:22:19.508
>> Blahoo?
>> [LAUGH]

411
00:22:21.463 --> 00:22:24.540
[LAUGH] Yeah, you would never know

>> Yeah.
>> Secret code.

00:22:26.290 --> 00:22:26.960
All right.

But the idea is, hey,

I can find out if it was one

Here's a module that I can now use

00:22:39.270 --> 00:22:43.656
to input here,
to go search the Have I Been Pwned site.

00:22:43.656 --> 00:22:45.142
Let's see if it works, all right?

419
00:22:45.142 --> 00:22:47.799
So we're gonna say,

00:22:47.799 --> 00:22:53.853
use recon/contacts-credentials/hibp_,

let's do the breach one first.

00:22:57.842 --> 00:23:04.114
All right, so now I'm using that
module and lets do a little show info.

423
00:23:04.114 --> 00:23:09.730
All right, and we can see have
I been pwned?Breach Search.

00:23:09.730 --> 00:23:12.090
All it needs is a SOURCE.

00:23:12.090 --> 00:23:16.625
Now the source for this one, this is where
you gotta read this this show info, right?

00:23:16.625 --> 00:23:20.750
Cuz so far the ones we've been doing
it was select distinct domains from, or

427
00:23:20.750 --> 00:23:22.290
domain from domains.

428
00:23:22.290 --> 00:23:27.600
This one is SELECT DISTINCT
email FROM contacts, all right?

00:23:27.600 --> 00:23:35.840
Do we have, but we know, oops, That we

00:23:35.840 --> 00:23:38.710
I can see Don's email and
I can see Philip's email.

00:23:38.710 --> 00:23:41.720
So that's means I do have
the information it's gonna need.

432
00:23:41.720 --> 00:23:46.200
SELECT DISTINCT email FROM
contacts WHERE email IS NOT NULL.

433
00:23:46.200 --> 00:23:47.580
So let's run it.

434
00:23:47.580 --> 00:23:48.080
And see what we get?

435
00:23:53.675 --> 00:23:56.670
All right, there it finished and

00:23:56.670 --> 00:24:00.324
So that first one,

00:24:00.324 --> 00:24:04.166
But there I have a few with don@itpro.tv,
Breach found!

438
00:24:04.166 --> 00:24:10.027
Seen in the GeekedIn breach
that occurred on 2016-08-15.

439
00:24:10.027 --> 00:24:14.034
So what this is telling

440
00:24:14.034 --> 00:24:18.920
was in that database for
GeekedIn when it was compromised,

441
00:24:18.920 --> 00:24:23.000
which is kind of interesting,
I don't know.

00:24:23.000 --> 00:24:24.840
That one doesn't give me a ton of info.

443
00:24:24.840 --> 00:24:29.890
But it does tell me that with a little
more looking I might find passwords too.

444
00:24:29.890 --> 00:24:33.280
Because that account has been released.

445
00:24:33.280 --> 00:24:35.405
So that information is out there.

446
00:24:35.405 --> 00:24:37.580
It gave me the credential but

00:24:37.580 --> 00:24:40.675
it did not find any passwords

00:24:40.675 --> 00:24:46.380
He was also part of the Trillium
breach and the vBulletin breach.

449
00:24:46.380 --> 00:24:48.250
Now keep in mind,
something I should point out here.

00:24:48.250 --> 00:24:50.535
This is not, I actually talked to Don.

00:24:50.535 --> 00:24:52.800
I said, hey you're okay with me
sharing this information, right?

452
00:24:52.800 --> 00:24:55.810
He's like, yeah it's nothing, nothing bad.

453
00:24:55.810 --> 00:24:58.700
It just means that he
signed up at a company that

454
00:24:58.700 --> 00:25:00.640
didn't handle security very well.

455
00:25:00.640 --> 00:25:02.730
Probably went to one of
these sites looking for

456
00:25:02.730 --> 00:25:06.760
some information or whatever,
logged in, created an account.

457
00:25:06.760 --> 00:25:10.200
And then they got compromised,
not Don, not a weak password.

458
00:25:10.200 --> 00:25:12.200
It was Trillium that got breached.

459
00:25:12.200 --> 00:25:13.860
Their account database was stolen.

460
00:25:15.870 --> 00:25:18.930
But it did add some credentials.

461
00:25:18.930 --> 00:25:23.520
So if we take a look at
the show credentials,

462
00:25:23.520 --> 00:25:26.170
I'll now have an entry for Don.

463
00:25:26.170 --> 00:25:27.890
Again, it didn't pull back his password.

464
00:25:27.890 --> 00:25:31.470
It didn't pull back the hash or
any of that in this particular case.

00:25:31.470 --> 00:25:36.210
But depending on what's listed up
there on that Have I Been Pwned site,

466
00:25:36.210 --> 00:25:38.450
I might very well come back with a hash.

467
00:25:38.450 --> 00:25:42.820
Once I get the hash, it's just a few
steps away from breaking those hashes.

468
00:25:43.990 --> 00:25:47.470
In fact, there's a module in here that
you can use that'll take you out to,

469
00:25:47.470 --> 00:25:50.620
it'll go out to website and compare
the hashes against one of their tables

470
00:25:50.620 --> 00:25:52.220
to see if they can find the password for
you.

471
00:25:52.220 --> 00:25:53.287
They won't try to break it or anything.

472
00:25:53.287 --> 00:25:55.800
But they will do their rainbow tables.

473
00:25:58.070 --> 00:26:00.470
So, building up data, building up data.

474
00:26:00.470 --> 00:26:04.570
The other one there,
the other hipb is actually a good one.

475
00:26:04.570 --> 00:26:06.820
I don't think it's gonna return anything.

476
00:26:06.820 --> 00:26:11.481
But let's run it anyway just so

477
00:26:11.481 --> 00:26:17.660
That was /contacts-credentials/hipb_pasty?

478
00:26:17.660 --> 00:26:19.542
Yeah, paste.

479
00:26:19.542 --> 00:26:21.840
And I'll do a little show info.

480
00:26:24.510 --> 00:26:25.890
And this has two options.

481
00:26:26.900 --> 00:26:27.483
It tells you this.

482
00:26:27.483 --> 00:26:30.460
Go into the ihavebeenpwned.com.

483
00:26:30.460 --> 00:26:32.270
And it needs a source.

484
00:26:32.270 --> 00:26:35.249
And the source is email
from the contacts table.

485
00:26:35.249 --> 00:26:37.720
So we're good there,
we've got that information.

486
00:26:37.720 --> 00:26:41.800
And then it is DOWNLOAD is set to True and
it is required.

487
00:26:41.800 --> 00:26:46.012
This goes out to Pastebin.

488
00:26:46.012 --> 00:26:48.140
I'm trying to see,
it should say that somewhere.

489
00:26:48.140 --> 00:26:52.890
Paste sites supported: Pastebin, Pastie,
Slexy, Ghostbin, Quickleak, JustPaste,

490
00:26:52.890 --> 00:26:54.240
AdHocUrl.

491
00:26:54.240 --> 00:26:56.360
There are several that it goes to.

492
00:26:57.640 --> 00:26:59.620
And if you're familiar
with any of those sites,

493
00:26:59.620 --> 00:27:02.310
they're really quick file share sites.

494
00:27:02.310 --> 00:27:04.970
Like if you've got, they're not really
for, usually not for full files.

495
00:27:04.970 --> 00:27:08.340
It's more like code snippets and
things like that.

496
00:27:08.340 --> 00:27:09.810
Hey, I need Ronnie to take a look at this.

497
00:27:09.810 --> 00:27:12.620
I can put it up there in Pastebin,
give him a link.

498
00:27:12.620 --> 00:27:15.300
He can link to it and
things like that and access it.

499
00:27:15.300 --> 00:27:16.640
So here what we're doing
is we're saying hey,

500
00:27:16.640 --> 00:27:22.980
have any of those people that you've
discovered so far used any of these sites.

501
00:27:22.980 --> 00:27:27.757
So we'll say run, And

502
00:27:27.757 --> 00:27:30.900
Phillip Ford wasn't found and
Don wasn't found so they're in the clear.

503
00:27:30.900 --> 00:27:32.890
They have not been using Pastebin.

504
00:27:32.890 --> 00:27:36.200
That DOWNLOAD set to true,
do be careful with that one.

505
00:27:36.200 --> 00:27:37.530
It will automatically,

506
00:27:37.530 --> 00:27:42.830
if set to true it'll download anything
it finds in any one of those sites.

507
00:27:42.830 --> 00:27:45.730
So if you didn't wanna download,

508
00:27:45.730 --> 00:27:49.730
if you just wanted to see
if they had used it, and

509
00:27:49.730 --> 00:27:56.234
then wanna decide which ones to download,
you could do a set DOWNLOAD false.

510
00:27:56.234 --> 00:28:00.522
And then it wouldn't download
those automatically.

511
00:28:00.522 --> 00:28:03.800
So continuing on with
our user information.

512
00:28:04.860 --> 00:28:06.229
Let's back out of this module.

513
00:28:07.300 --> 00:28:10.690
And next we're gonna do
one called full contact.

514
00:28:10.690 --> 00:28:14.630
Now, full contact is a place where you
can go and get a lot of information.

515
00:28:14.630 --> 00:28:17.410
It's scary how much they have on me.

516
00:28:17.410 --> 00:28:18.950
Let's take a look at running this module.

517
00:28:18.950 --> 00:28:26.193
We're gonna say use
recon/contacts-profiles/fullcontact.

518
00:28:26.193 --> 00:28:30.990
Because in our database, we have
contacts and then we have profiles.

519
00:28:30.990 --> 00:28:33.880
Contacts are really, they're contact
information like you might think,

520
00:28:33.880 --> 00:28:36.510
phone number, email.

521
00:28:36.510 --> 00:28:40.790
Profile is all the other stuff, their
address, their business address, their

522
00:28:40.790 --> 00:28:44.620
department, more things that we can use
when we get into, say, social engineering.

523
00:28:46.350 --> 00:28:51.800
And that's what this site is designed or
geared to do, is find that information.

524
00:28:51.800 --> 00:28:53.190
So if we do a show info,

525
00:28:53.190 --> 00:28:57.166
we'll see that it's gonna go to
FullContact Contact Enumerator.

526
00:28:57.166 --> 00:28:59.744
That's the name of it, Contact Enumerator.

527
00:28:59.744 --> 00:29:01.780
Harvests contact information and

528
00:29:01.780 --> 00:29:07.760
profiles from fullcontact.com
API using email as the input.

529
00:29:07.760 --> 00:29:11.790
And it updates both the contacts table and
the profiles tables.

530
00:29:11.790 --> 00:29:14.230
Anything it finds it's
gonna dump in there.

531
00:29:14.230 --> 00:29:17.710
SOURCE, default,
DISTINCT email FROM contacts.

532
00:29:17.710 --> 00:29:19.150
So we're good to go there.

533
00:29:19.150 --> 00:29:22.364
We can just run and
let's see where we get.

534
00:29:24.139 --> 00:29:26.445
Lot of good information here.

535
00:29:26.445 --> 00:29:27.523
Now look what we are getting.

536
00:29:27.523 --> 00:29:32.139
Phillip Ford, email address,
position, Sales Manager,

537
00:29:32.139 --> 00:29:37.125
location, Gravatar information,
LinkedIn profile account.

538
00:29:37.125 --> 00:29:41.329
I mean, that's- I follow that link.

539
00:29:45.047 --> 00:29:50.213
There is Mr. Philip Ford.

540
00:29:50.213 --> 00:29:55.671
So we're starting to see the power
hopefully of some of these modules and

541
00:29:55.671 --> 00:29:57.600
what we can do with them.

542
00:29:57.600 --> 00:30:00.140
If we take a look at show profiles now,

543
00:30:00.140 --> 00:30:04.700
we'll see that we're starting
to build up some information.

544
00:30:04.700 --> 00:30:07.940
And so far we've really just been hitting,

545
00:30:07.940 --> 00:30:10.160
we've been focused on
the user side of things.

546
00:30:10.160 --> 00:30:15.560
Really haven't even started to explore the
host and domain modules that are in here.

547
00:30:15.560 --> 00:30:18.894
So that is yet to come.

548
00:30:18.894 --> 00:30:21.450
>> All right, Mike,
well thank you again for

549
00:30:21.450 --> 00:30:24.014
helping us to get started with recon-ng.

550
00:30:24.014 --> 00:30:28.370
You're starting to see the power
of what recon-ng can do.

551
00:30:28.370 --> 00:30:32.480
This entire product, it gives you
that ability instead of you having

552
00:30:32.480 --> 00:30:37.550
to manually do the searches with multiple
utilities and tools in one tool,

553
00:30:37.550 --> 00:30:41.590
you're now starting to see that snowball
effect that Mike was talking about.

554
00:30:41.590 --> 00:30:44.890
And there is a lot more for

555
00:30:44.890 --> 00:30:47.210
But that is for another episode then.

00:30:47.210 --> 00:30:51.230
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

00:30:52.340 --> 00:30:56.080

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue with using recon-ng.  Mike demonstrate some of the other modules within recon-ng.  He demonstrates how easily it leads the user to search and find more results from the results found.  Ultimately, Mike demonstrates a report that can be generated for ease of use!
episodes.title: Recon-ng Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show the vulnerability scanner nikto. Mike demonstrates its syntax and usage.  He shows how to find the vulnerabilities and find entries to help discover more information about the vulnerabilities discovered.
episodes.title: Nikto Basics

I wanna look for

We do have some info.

So not the most efficient

00:28:41.930 --> 00:28:46.691

You can hit their

And because those databases

there are new tools coming out, It doesn't

It will actually give you

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at another vulnerability tool: Sparta.  Mike explains that it has the ability to run multiple tools at once, that it can simplify information gathering and is customizable.  He demonstrates where to can customizes Sparta using the sparta.conf file.   He also runs the utility to show how to add the targets and review the results from the scan in Sparta.
episodes.title: Sparta Basics

Sparta is really conglomeration?

That maybe be the word, it's a collection

WordList was created, opened,

All right [COUGH] so

I guess probably the first

we talked a little bit about Sparta.

But, I can change that.

It'll [INAUDIBLE] immediately,

00:06:15.214 --> 00:06:19.175
I'm gonna show you a way
that you can import targets,

116
00:06:19.175 --> 00:06:22.695

117
00:06:22.695 --> 00:06:25.605
When you import them, it doesn't start.

118
00:06:25.605 --> 00:06:28.715
And then I think, and this is just me
trying to put logic to their defaults,

119
00:06:29.745 --> 00:06:34.315
the file could have several, right

120
00:06:34.315 --> 00:06:37.385
And you don't wanna just start scanning

121
00:06:37.385 --> 00:06:39.730
If you add one, it just boom,

122
00:06:39.730 --> 00:06:40.750
So if you don't like that,

123
00:06:40.750 --> 00:06:44.220

you can change this to false.

124
00:06:44.220 --> 00:06:48.200
And just simply come in here,

125
00:06:48.200 --> 00:06:52.730
Save your configuration file, restart

126
00:06:52.730 --> 00:06:56.494
So if you're one of those that doesn't

00:06:56.494 --> 00:06:57.888

133

00:07:25.950 --> 00:07:26.891
All right, so

So Sparta, there's three different ways

Hosts, click here to add host to scope.

146

148
00:08:05.767 --> 00:08:07.580

149
00:08:07.580 --> 00:08:10.300
So this is gonna do

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue to work a with Sparta.  Mike shows how to save the output of the scan to a file.  This allows us to use this file at a later time or pass it to another person for use, says Mike.  He also shows how to manipulate the sparta.conf file to add an additional tool into the Sparta Interface.
episodes.title: Sparta Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss the basics of generating wordlists for password attacks.  Mike describes the use of wordlists and that the goal is to have the most refined wordlist rather than the most words in a wordlists.  He also mentions that refining these list can begin with the basic tools that include wordlists such as found in Kali.  He also uses cell to show how to generate a word list by using websites to help you; this is good when looking at  password attack against a particular company or industry sector.
episodes.title: Generating Wordlists

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:01.327
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.327 --> 00:00:06.336
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.336 --> 00:00:08.289
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.289 --> 00:00:12.137
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.137 --> 00:00:15.325
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.325 --> 00:00:18.010
You're watching the Kali Linux Show.

7
00:00:18.010 --> 00:00:19.940
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today,

8
00:00:19.940 --> 00:00:23.960
we're gonna be taking a look at
how we can generate word lists.

9
00:00:23.960 --> 00:00:27.920
And here to help us out, it's gonna be Mr.
Security himself, Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:27.920 --> 00:00:29.530
Mike, welcome to the show.

11
00:00:29.530 --> 00:00:31.290
>> Hey Ronnie, thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:31.290 --> 00:00:33.720
Glad to be here, excited as always.

13
00:00:33.720 --> 00:00:37.345
And yeah,
word list is the topic of the day, right?

14
00:00:37.345 --> 00:00:41.578
And in a previous episode,
we had used a program, Sparta,

15
00:00:41.578 --> 00:00:43.794
if you guys remember that one.

16
00:00:43.794 --> 00:00:50.371
And at one point, Ronnie,
we had to browse and find a word list.

17
00:00:50.371 --> 00:00:55.413
And if we remember, that word list was
what we used to try to brute force or

18
00:00:55.413 --> 00:00:57.450
to crack a password.

19
00:00:57.450 --> 00:00:58.080
And so

20
00:00:58.080 --> 00:01:01.420
that's what I wanna talk about today is,
where do those word lists come from?

21
00:01:01.420 --> 00:01:03.347
What are they?

22
00:01:03.347 --> 00:01:05.010
What can we do with them?

23
00:01:05.010 --> 00:01:05.910
Things like that.

24
00:01:05.910 --> 00:01:09.900
And now Mike, as we get started here,
let's talk about that specifically,

25
00:01:09.900 --> 00:01:12.110
about where they normally come from.

26
00:01:12.110 --> 00:01:15.429
Now, in the previous episode,
you did generate a very short word list.

27
00:01:15.429 --> 00:01:18.879
I don't know if it was like four or
five, even five words long or so.

28
00:01:18.879 --> 00:01:21.993
And that will work for
the example that we did, but when

29
00:01:21.993 --> 00:01:26.744
we start hearing about the idea of people
using these, it normally is much longer.

30
00:01:26.744 --> 00:01:30.512
And so, is someone actually,
they're going, let me go ahead and

31
00:01:30.512 --> 00:01:33.030
type out these 10,000 words, Mike.

32
00:01:33.030 --> 00:01:34.340
>> Well, typically not.

33
00:01:34.340 --> 00:01:37.860
I mean, I guess maybe somebody at
some point probably started that way.

34
00:01:37.860 --> 00:01:40.510
But there's definitely
much better ways to do it.

35
00:01:40.510 --> 00:01:45.200
So let's define what a word list is,
cuz you pointed out that the other day,

36
00:01:45.200 --> 00:01:49.360
I created one myself,
on the fly here on the screen.

37
00:01:49.360 --> 00:01:53.610
And because a word list or dictionary
file, right, you might hear this term

38
00:01:53.610 --> 00:02:00.620
dictionary file, is simply a text
file with one word on each line.

39
00:02:00.620 --> 00:02:04.670
And each one of those words
represents a guess, if you will,

40
00:02:04.670 --> 00:02:07.950
that I'm going to make at what
somebody's password might be or

41
00:02:07.950 --> 00:02:11.070
something that we're
gonna try as a password.

42
00:02:11.070 --> 00:02:14.545
So when it comes to a dictionary file or
a word list, it's simply a text file.

43
00:02:14.545 --> 00:02:19.480
So you could open up nanovim,
whatever you wanted, Notepad on Windows.

44
00:02:19.480 --> 00:02:23.873
And you could write one word on each line
that you thought their password might

45
00:02:23.873 --> 00:02:28.840
be or that you wanted to try and then feed
that into your password cracking utility.

46
00:02:28.840 --> 00:02:29.570
And it would do just that.

47
00:02:29.570 --> 00:02:30.990
It would start with the first word,
try it.

48
00:02:30.990 --> 00:02:31.660
If it works, great.

49
00:02:31.660 --> 00:02:33.510
If it doesn't, move on to the next one.

50
00:02:33.510 --> 00:02:34.810
Try that one.

51
00:02:34.810 --> 00:02:37.318
Now, obviously, me typing up that list,

52
00:02:37.318 --> 00:02:41.580
like Ronnie was saying in our little demo,
I knew what the password was.

53
00:02:41.580 --> 00:02:45.425
And I just wanted a few more passwords
to make it do a little bit of work.

54
00:02:45.425 --> 00:02:46.935
But I didn't want it to take very long,
and

55
00:02:46.935 --> 00:02:49.125
I wanted it to actually
finish the process.

56
00:02:49.125 --> 00:02:50.852
So I did just that.

57
00:02:50.852 --> 00:02:53.311
I opened up a little text file,
put one word on each line,

58
00:02:53.311 --> 00:02:55.355
one of them being the right password.

59
00:02:55.355 --> 00:02:57.161
And we were good to go.

60
00:02:57.161 --> 00:02:59.835
All right, but typically,
that's not gonna work.

61
00:02:59.835 --> 00:03:05.042
And in a PIN test, in a security audit
in your organization, you're gonna

62
00:03:05.042 --> 00:03:10.596
need an actual word list that has a good
representation of possible passwords.

63
00:03:10.596 --> 00:03:16.070
So the key then is, where do I get these
word lists or these dictionary files?

64
00:03:16.070 --> 00:03:19.760
Do I obtain them, do I make them,
what is the best way to go about it?

65
00:03:19.760 --> 00:03:23.360
Because I myself, years ago,

66
00:03:23.360 --> 00:03:27.530
had this idea that the bigger my
word list was, the better off I was.

67
00:03:27.530 --> 00:03:32.320
I was gonna go out and find every single
word list that other people had created or

68
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:33.070
what have you.

69
00:03:33.070 --> 00:03:35.550
And I'm gonna start
putting them together and

70
00:03:35.550 --> 00:03:41.430
end up with this monster file that has
thousands and thousands of words in it.

71
00:03:41.430 --> 00:03:45.600
And that's gonna be my
master dictionary file.

72
00:03:45.600 --> 00:03:50.504
The problem with that logic is that
some of those words are more likely,

73
00:03:50.504 --> 00:03:54.860
some of them are less likely
to be somebody's password.

74
00:03:54.860 --> 00:03:58.584
And to go through a list of
hundreds of thousands of words,

75
00:03:58.584 --> 00:04:01.706
it is gonna take some processing power and
time.

76
00:04:01.706 --> 00:04:04.890
Time is the big one there.

77
00:04:04.890 --> 00:04:08.290
The longer the word list, the more options
and more words are in there, obviously,

78
00:04:08.290 --> 00:04:10.740
the longer it's gonna
take to go through that.

79
00:04:10.740 --> 00:04:14.030
So when we think about a word list,
yes, we want a lot of words,

80
00:04:14.030 --> 00:04:15.690
we need a lot of possibilities.

81
00:04:15.690 --> 00:04:20.810
But we wanna make sure we're approaching
it in a smart or thoughtful manner.

82
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:25.070
We don't wanna just take the Webster's
dictionary from A to Z and

83
00:04:25.070 --> 00:04:27.980
put that in a word file and use that.

84
00:04:27.980 --> 00:04:30.920
Because some of those
words that start with

85
00:04:30.920 --> 00:04:32.640
A are not likely to be their passwords.

86
00:04:32.640 --> 00:04:34.780
Some of those words that
start with T might be, right?

87
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:37.440
I'd love to have those up
at the front of the list.

88
00:04:37.440 --> 00:04:42.084
The idea is to get this word list
set up in a way that the most likely

89
00:04:42.084 --> 00:04:46.560
passwords are tried first,
the less likely are tried later.

90
00:04:46.560 --> 00:04:49.460
We'll talk about it, maybe in this
episode, maybe in another one,

91
00:04:49.460 --> 00:04:52.280
how we can kind of think about
that process and sort these.

92

00:05:04.010 --> 00:05:09.490
>> Now Mike, you say that, but if I can

00:05:09.490 --> 00:05:15.500

00:05:15.500 --> 00:05:19.240

00:05:19.240 --> 00:05:21.580
>> It's a little confusing

00:05:21.580 --> 00:05:23.740
When we talk about password attacks,

100
00:05:23.740 --> 00:05:26.290
we really refer to typically
three major types.

101
00:05:26.290 --> 00:05:29.386
We've got dictionary attacks,
where we're going through a word list, and

102
00:05:29.386 --> 00:05:30.969
we're just trying every single word.

103
00:05:30.969 --> 00:05:34.770
And if the password is not in the list,
it's not gonna be cracked, right?

104
00:05:34.770 --> 00:05:37.030
The only thing it's trying
are those words in the list.

105
00:05:37.030 --> 00:05:40.035
It's not getting creative or
doing anything else.

106
00:05:40.035 --> 00:05:43.770
You've got brute force attacks, where you
are trying every possible combination,

107
00:05:43.770 --> 00:05:48.590
AAA, AAB, AAC,
all the way up to ZZZ, right?

108
00:05:48.590 --> 00:05:51.440
That's a brute force attack on a password.

109
00:05:51.440 --> 00:05:55.145
But you will hear people
referring to brute forcing FTP.

110
00:05:55.145 --> 00:05:57.825
But what they're really doing
is a dictionary attack,

111
00:05:57.825 --> 00:05:59.600
firing words against that service.

112
00:05:59.600 --> 00:06:03.740
So they're using a dictionary
attack to brute force the service,

113
00:06:03.740 --> 00:06:08.250
but it's still a dictionary attack on
the password, so be careful with that.

114
00:06:08.250 --> 00:06:13.347
Brute forcing takes a lot of power,
a lot of computational power,

115
00:06:13.347 --> 00:06:16.269
and just a tremendous amount of time.

116
00:06:16.269 --> 00:06:20.910
And usually, what we're trying
to do is find the balance there.

117
00:06:20.910 --> 00:06:24.130
Yes, brute forcing is
guaranteed successful, right?

118
00:06:24.130 --> 00:06:26.680
You're gonna try every possible
combination of letter, number, and

119
00:06:26.680 --> 00:06:28.370
special character that's there.

00:06:28.370 --> 00:06:30.590
So eventually, you will get that password.

00:06:30.590 --> 00:06:32.975

00:06:32.975 --> 00:06:35.569

123
00:06:35.569 --> 00:06:36.334

00:06:36.334 --> 00:06:39.285

00:06:39.285 --> 00:06:41.690
it's not even feasible for

00:06:41.690 --> 00:06:45.080
You'd have to pass the job down

127
00:06:45.080 --> 00:06:49.636
So while brute forcing can break

128
00:06:49.636 --> 00:06:53.090

at least with today's technology.

129
00:06:53.090 --> 00:06:56.240
You've got the key spaces or

00:06:56.240 --> 00:06:59.410
We can't get through all the possibilities

00:06:59.410 --> 00:07:02.970

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue with wordlist generation using crunch.   Mike demonstrates the incredible options of this tool that allow you to create parameters for the wordlists you want to generate.  He also discusses it’s particular ability is truly useful when the proper parameters are provided and when the reconnaissance is done beforehand.
episodes.title: Generating Wordlists Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss the use of hashcat.  It allows you to manipulate the existing passwords by replacing characters, insert character, prepend and append characters to help you create another wordlist.  Mike shows and demonstrates how to use the options available to get the results needed!
episodes.title: Generating Wordlists Part 3

episodes.description: In this show, Mike and Cherokee look how to use John the Ripper to crack passwords. Mike explains the various modes used such as wordlist, single crack and incremental. He also specifies the default mode order if no mode is specified. Lastly, they look at KoreLogic Rules to help streamline the cracking process.
episodes.title: John the Ripper

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Mike use the tool hashcat to crack passwords. Mike explains how to use built in charsets. They use bruteforce to find the hashes of three of the four passwords.

1

Welcome to ITPRO.TV, I'm your host
>> [CROSSTALK]

[SOUND]

we're gonna go and apply some rules,

16

17

modes that we can use Hashcat in.

18

Let's look at the help file for

00:01:07.010 --> 00:01:10.320
So when you get a chance
peruse through it.

But, a couple of things that

some of these options that
we are going to use in here.

24

I see a very verbose help file,
I really like it.

25
00:01:20.670 --> 00:01:22.750
We´ll be using a couple
of different switches.

One is going to be our m switch,
m is the hash type.

27
00:01:27.815 --> 00:01:33.871
We need to tell Hashcat what type of hash

28

30

Down below, I´ll show you,

31
00:01:41.330 --> 00:01:42.689

00:01:42.689 --> 00:01:44.622
All there is actually, that's a code and

34
00:01:48.225 --> 00:01:55.385
The -a is attack mode, for
example an a 3 is actually brute force.

35
00:01:55.385 --> 00:01:59.270
Again, see reference below so

36
00:01:59.270 --> 00:02:01.786
That one is gonna be
your dictionary file and

we'll take a look at

Another important switch for

00:02:12.160 --> 00:02:13.290

That's why we're cracking

00:02:15.610 --> 00:02:19.665

pay attention to is going to be,

if I can find it here, what did I use,

let's take a look at the hash modes.

00:02:35.657 --> 00:02:38.363

you can see these different codes, and

49
00:02:43.956 --> 00:02:50.064

50
00:02:50.064 --> 00:02:54.021

51

And you can see there's a lot of

00:02:58.503 --> 00:03:00.705

There are the codes, remember I said 3

55
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:14.820
6, hybrid word list combination,
we can use dictionary file for that.

56
00:03:16.950 --> 00:03:19.509
I'm sorry, not dictionary file,

0 is my dictionary.

77
00:04:19.810 --> 00:04:23.750

78

it says hey, you don't have any GPUs.

79
00:04:26.500 --> 00:04:27.580
How are we supposed to do this?

80
00:04:27.580 --> 00:04:29.185
You can do a --force.

81
00:04:30.520 --> 00:04:34.750
To force it to use your single
CPU like in my virtual machine.

82
00:04:34.750 --> 00:04:36.292
For test purposes, that's fine.

83
00:04:36.292 --> 00:04:39.000
In the real world that

84
00:04:40.140 --> 00:04:43.259
All right, so that's some of the help

88
00:04:51.790 --> 00:04:52.380

89

00:17:49.540 --> 00:17:52.990

00:17:54.250 --> 00:17:58.280
That way when I go back to resume it

00:17:58.280 --> 00:17:59.900
It's already cracked it.

00:17:59.900 --> 00:18:03.350
So your list of hashes gets shorter,
and shorter, and shorter.

So I do like that option,

00:19:30.100 --> 00:19:35.310
